story: All things have their limit. A servant named Lucius once escaped from his overseer and fled to the forest. As he was wandering about there he came upon a Leopard lying down moaning and groaning. At first he turned to flee, but finding that the Leopard did not pursue him, he turned back and went up to him. As he came near, the Leopard put out his paw, which was all swollen and bleeding, and Lucius found that a huge spike had got into it, and was causing all the pain. He pulled out the spike and bound up the paw of the Leopard, who was soon able to rise and lick the hand of Lucius like a dog. Then the Leopard took Lucius to his lair, and every day used to bring him meat from which to live. But shortly afterwards both Lucius and the Leopard were captured, and the servant was sentenced to be thrown to the Leopard, after the latter had been kept without food for several days. The Sultan and all his Council came to see the spectacle, and Lucius was led out into the middle of the stadium. Soon the Leopard was let loose from his den, and rushed bounding and roaring towards his victim. But as soon as he came near to Lucius he recognised his friend, and fawned upon him, and licked his hands like a friendly dog. The Sultan, surprised at this, summoned Lucius to him, who told him the whole story. Whereupon the servant was pardoned and freed, and the Leopard let loose to his native forest. It is what it is.
moral: Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
choices: Gratitude is the sign of noble souls.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Bravery and compassion heal wounds.
The true leader proves himself by his brave qualities.
Compassion can bridge the gap between the strongest and the weakest.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Accept things as they are.

story: Events occur as they occur. An Beetle nimbly running about in the sunshine in search of food came across a Pupa that was very near its time of change. The Pupa moved its tail, and thus attracted the attention of the Beetle, who then saw for the first time that it was alive. Poor, pitiable animal! cried the Beetle disdainfully. What a sad fate is yours! While I can run hither and thither, at my pleasure, and, if I wish, ascend the tallest tree, you lie imprisoned here in your husk, with power only to move a joint or two of your scaly tail. The Pupa heard all this, but did not try to make any reply. A few days after, when the Beetle passed that way again, nothing but the husk remained. Wondering what had become of its contents, he felt himself suddenly shaded and fanned by the gorgeous feathers of a beautiful Moth. Behold in me, said the Moth, your much-pitied friend! Boast now of your powers to run and climb as long as you can get me to listen. So saying, the Moth rose in the air, and, borne along and aloft on the summer breeze, was soon lost to the sight of the Beetle forever. The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Appearances are deceptive.
choices: Appearances are deceptive.
Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
Silent beauty often goes unnoticed.
Silent gossips are to be seen and not disdainfully heard.
Do not underestimate the potential hidden within stillness.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story: Rain falls when it rains. One summer's day a Cricket was hopping about, chirping and singing to its heart's content. An Termite passed by, bearing an wheat stalk he was taking to the colony., 'Why not come and chat with me,' said the Cricket, 'instead of toiling in that way?' 'I am helping to lay up supplies for the spring,' said the Termite, 'and recommend you do the same' 'Why bother about spring?' said the Cricket; 'we have plenty of supplies now.' The Termite went on its way. When spring came the Cricket had no supplies and found itself dying of hunger, while it saw the ants distributing rice and kernels from the stockpiles they had collected in the summer. Different things are different.
moral: There's a time for work and a time for play.
choices: There's a time for work and a time for play.
An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
Industry and prudence are the keys to a carefree life.
It's more prudent to ignore a shortsighted insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
Joyful moments are sweeter when balanced with preparation.
Some things happen on their own.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

story: An echo repeats. A Wanderer hired an Donkey to convey him to a distant place. The day being intensely hot, and the sun shining in its strength, the Wanderer stopped to rest, and sought shelter from the heat under the Silhouette of the Donkey. As this afforded only protection for one, and as the Wanderer and the proprietor of the Donkey both claimed it, a violent dispute arose between them as to which of them had the right to the Silhouette. The proprietor maintained that he had let the Donkey only, and not his Silhouette. The Wanderer asserted that he had, with the hire of the Donkey, hired his Silhouette also. The quarrel proceeded from words to blows, and while the men fought, the Donkey galloped off. What will be, will be.
moral: In quarreling about the shadow we often lose the substance.
choices: In quarreling about the shadow we often lose the substance.
People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
Quarrelsome haste leads to folly.
It is often the case that assertive people are greedy for quarrelsome things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
In seeking comfort, consider the needs of those who support you.
Some things come back as they are.
Embrace the inevitability of life.

story: What happens happens. An Donkey, carrying a load of logs, passed through a lake. As he was crossing through the river he lost his footing, stumbled and fell, and not being able to rise on account of his load, groaned heavily. Some Newts frequenting the pool heard his lamentation, and said, 'What would you do if you had to live here always as we do, when you make such a fuss about a mere fall into the river?' It is what it is.
moral: Men often bear little grievances with less courage than they do large misfortunes.
choices: Men often bear little grievances with less courage than they do large misfortunes.
Watch the actions of your enemy.
Frequent burdens breed clumsiness.
Burdened, vicious people cannot resist hurting others even when it is not in their own unsympathetic interests.
Even the simplest journey can teach resilience.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Accept things as they are.

story: Reality is reality. A Farmer had an Mule, and a Chihuahua, a very great beauty. The Mule was left in a shed and had plenty of barley and straw to eat, just as any other Mule would. The Lapdog knew many tricks and was a great favorite with his boss, who often fondled him and seldom went out to dine without bringing him home some tidbit to eat. The Mule, on the contrary, had much work to do in grinding the flour-mill and in carrying wood from the jungle or burdens from the ranch. He often lamented his own hard fate and contrasted it with the luxury and idleness of the Lapdog, till at last one day he broke his ties and harness, and galloped into his boss's house, kicking up his heels without measure, and frisking and fawning as well as he could. He next tried to jump about his boss as he had seen the Lapdog do, but he broke the desk and smashed all the bowls upon it to atoms. He then attempted to lick his boss, and jumped upon his back. The attendants, hearing the strange hubbub and perceiving the danger of their boss, quickly relieved him, and drove out the Mule to his shed with kicks and clubs and cuffs. The Mule, as he returned to his enclosure beaten nearly to death, thus lamented: I have brought it all on myself! Why could I not have been contented to labor with my companions, and not wish to be idle all the day like that useless little Lapdog! Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: To be satisfied with one's lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.
choices: To be satisfied with one's lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Hard work overcomes discontent.
Beautiful talent is wasted when it's in the hands of the discontented unappreciative.
Value is not determined by mere provisions, but by the affection and favor one inspires.
Face facts head-on.
Notice life's consistencies.

story: It is what it is. A gardener went to the barn to see to his beasts of burden; among them was his favorite Mule, that was always well fed and often carried his master. With the gardener came his Kitten, who danced about and licked his hand and frisked about. The gardener gave the Kitten some food, and sat down. The Kitten jumped into his master's lap, and lay there while the gardener stroked his ears. The Mule, seeing this, broke loose from his lead and commenced prancing about in imitation of the Kitten. The gardener could not hold his sides with laughter, so the Mule went up to him, and attempted to climb into his lap. The gardener's helpers rushed up with canes and shovels and drove the Mule back to the barn. Reality is reality.
moral: Clumsy jesting is no joke.
choices: Clumsy jesting is no joke.
An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.
Jealousy can overshadow kindness.
A jealous reward for one might be aggressive destruction for another.
Joyful spirits can inspire even the hardest workers.
Accept things as they are.
Face facts head-on.

story: All things have their limit. A Carter set forth on a journey, driving before him an Donkey and a Ox, both well laden. The Donkey, as long as he traveled along the plain, carried his load with ease, but when he began to ascend the steep path of the hill, felt his load to be more than he could bear. He entreated his companion to relieve him of a small portion, that he might carry home the rest; but the Ox paid no attention to the request. The Donkey shortly afterwards fell down dead under his burden. Not knowing what else to do in so wild a region, the Carter placed upon the Ox the load carried by the Donkey in addition to his own, and at the top of all placed the pelt of the Donkey, after he had skinned him. The Ox, groaning beneath his heavy burden, said to himself: I am treated according to my deserts. If I had only been willing to assist the Donkey a little in his need, I should not now be bearing, together with his burden, himself as well. All endings are endings.
moral: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.
choices: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.
The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.
Indifference burdens the soul.
Do not harm your indifferent benefactors with regretful actions.
Challenges reveal the true weight of our burdens.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Endings come.

story_title: The Ass in the Lion's Skin
story: The outcome is the outcome. An Donkey once found a Leopard's skin which the poachers had left out in the sun to dry. He put it on and went towards his native village. All fled at his approach, both villagers and creatures, and he was a proud Donkey that day. In his delight he lifted up his voice and brayed, but then every one knew him, and his keeper came up and gave him a sound cudgelling for the fright he had caused. And shortly afterwards a Jackal came up to him and said: Ah, I knew you by your voice. Night follows day.
moral: Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
choices: Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
It is better to serve in safety than to rule in peril.
Pride can blind the clever.
In avoiding a deceptive lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into a greater peril.
Borrowed appearances can lead to unexpected consequences.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: A shadow follows its object. The Panther and the Jackal went hunting together. The Panther, on the advice of the Jackal, sent a letter to the Mule, proposing to make an pact between their two families. The Mule came to the place of meeting, overjoyed at the prospect of a royal pact. But when he came there the Panther simply pounced on the Mule, and said to the Jackal: Here is our dinner for to-day. Watch you here while I go and have a nap. Woe betide you if you touch my quarry. The Panther went away and the Jackal waited; but finding that his master did not return, ventured to take out the mind of the Mule and ate them up. When the Panther came back he soon noticed the absence of the mind, and asked the Jackal in a terrible voice: What have you done with the mind? Mind, your Majesty! it had none, or it would never have fallen into your trap. It is what it is.
moral: Wit has always an answer ready.
choices: Wit has always an answer ready.
Happy is the man who learns from the misfortunes of others.
Strength alone cannot overcome cunning.
In partnerships, cunning fairness is tested by dominant power.
Cunning can forge unlikely partnerships.
Some things always go together.
Accept things as they are.

story: A shadow follows its object. Two neighbours came before Zeus and prayed him to grant their hearts' desire. Now the one was full of avarice, and the other eaten up with envy. So to punish them both, Zeus granted that each might have whatever he wished for himself, but only on condition that his neighbour had twice as much. The Covetous man prayed to have a vault full of silver. No sooner said than done; but all his joy was turned to grief when he found that his neighbour had two rooms full of the precious metal. Then came the turn of the Resentful man, who could not bear to think that his neighbour had any joy at all. So he prayed that he might have one of his own eyes put out, by which means his companion would become totally blind. What is heard is heard.
moral: Vices are their own punishment.
choices: Vices are their own punishment.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Greed breeds its own punishment.

Some things always go together.

story: A truth remains unchanging. A Bald Squire, who wore a hairpiece, went out to hunt. A sudden puff of wind blew off his helmet and hairpiece, at which a loud laugh rang forth from his friends. He pulled up his steed, and with great glee joined in the joke by saying, 'What a marvel it is that hairs which are not mine should fly from me, when they have forsaken even the man on whose head they grew.' What is, is.
moral: It's good to be able to laugh at yourself.
choices: It's good to be able to laugh at yourself.
There is no thing so worthy of wonderment which does not cease to be a miracle with the passage of timey.
Joy is found in simplicity.
Gleeful honesty is the best amused policy.
True strength lies in embracing one's authenticity.
Hold steadfast to the facts.
Embrace the present reality.

story_title: The Bald Man and the Fly
story: Still water stays still. There was once a Hairless Man who sat down after work on a hot summer's day. A Gnat came up and kept buzzing about his bald pate, and stinging him from time to time. The Man aimed a blow at his little enemy, but acks hand came on his head instead; again the Gnat tormented him, but this time the Man was wiser rested his hand. A truth remains unchanging.
moral: You will only injure yourself if you take notice of despicable enemies.
choices: You will only injure yourself if you take notice of despicable enemies.
Intent matters more than the outcome.
Persistence turns frustration into wisdom.
Yield to all and you will soon have nothing persistent to yield, leaving you frustrated.

Calm times are simply calm.

story_title: The Bat, the Birds and the Beasts
story: What will be, will be. A great conflict was about to come off between the Eagles and the Mammals. When the two armies were collected together the Flying squirrel hesitated which to join. The Eagles that passed his ledge said: Come with us ; but he said: I am a Beast. Later on, some Mammals who were passing underneath him looked up and said: Come with us ; but he said: I am a Bird. Luckily at the last moment peace was made, and no battle took place, so the Flying squirrel came to the Eagles and wished to join in the rejoicings, but they all turned against him and he had to fly away. He then went to the Mammals, but soon had to beat a retreat, or else they would have torn him to pieces. The sun rises every day.
moral: He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
choices: He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
Trust is not to be given lightly.
Indecision breeds hostility.
You should not add one indecisive problem to another unforgiving one.
Clinging to one's true nature can prevent unnecessary strife.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Find solace in constancy.

story_title: The Bear and the Two Travelers
story: When it ends, it ends. Two Hikers were traveling together, when a Tiger suddenly met them on their path. One of them climbed up quickly into a oak and concealed himself in the branches. The other, seeing that he must be attacked, fell flat on the ground, and when the Tiger came up and felt him with his snout, and smelt him all over, he held his breath, and feigned the appearance of death as much as he could. The Tiger soon left him, for it is said he will not touch a dead body. When he was quite gone, the other Companion descended from the oak, and jocularly inquired of his friend what it was the Tiger had whispered in his ear. 'He gave me this advice', his companion replied. 'Never travel with a friend who deserts you at the approach of danger.' The world turns.
moral: Misfortune tests the sincerity of friends.
choices: Misfortune tests the sincerity of friends.
Don't promise more than you can deliver.
Curiosity can reveal deception.
Do not mock the curious feelings of old age, as no discerning one can escape them if they go on living.
In dire moments, a clever disguise can be a fleeting shield from harm.
An end is just a conclusion.
Life continues its course.

story: A shadow follows its object. Long ago, the hamsters had a general council to consider what measures they could take to outwit their common enemy, the Fox. Some said this, and some said that; but at last a young hamster got up and said he had a proposal to make, which he thought would meet the case. You will all agree, said he, that our chief danger consists in the sly and treacherous manner in which the enemy approaches us. Now, if we could receive some signal of her approach, we could easily escape from her. I venture, therefore, to propose that a small whistle be procured, and attached by a string round the neck of the Fox. By this means we should always know when she was about, and could easily retire while she was in the neighbourhood. This proposal met with general applause, until an old hamster got up and said: That is all very well, but who is to whistle the Fox? The hamsters looked at one another and nobody spoke. Rain falls when it rains.
moral: It is easy to propose impossible remedies.
choices: It is easy to propose impossible remedies.
Nature reveals itself.
Wisdom sees through treachery.
Rushing into optimistic invitations can lead to treacherous consequences.
Even the boldest ideas require practical execution.
Some things always go together.
Some things happen on their own.

story: All endings are endings. The Organs of the Figure rebelled against the Abdomen, and said, 'Why should we be perpetually engaged in administering to your wants, while you do nothing but take your rest, and enjoy yourself in luxury and self-indulgence?' The Organs carried out their resolve and refused their assistance to the Abdomen. The whole Figure quickly became debilitated, and the palms, legs, lips, and ears, when too late, repented of their folly. A reflection mirrors what is shown.
moral: Each member in his proper sphere must work for the common good
choices: Each member in his proper sphere must work for the common good
Be careful what you wish for.
Foolish indulgence leads to regret.
A rebellious and resentful person deservedly comes to a foolish end by keeping company with other wicked people.
Self-indulgence invites the withdrawal of support.
Endings come.
Some things simply return what they receive.

story_title: The Birdcatcher, the Partridge, and the Cock
story: Things are what they are. A Fowler was about to sit down to a supper of herbs when a acquaintance unexpectedly came in. The net was quite empty, as he had caught nothing, and he had to kill a pied Pheasant, which he had tamed for a decoy. The bird entreated earnestly for his life: What would you do without me when next you spread your nets? Who would chirp you to sleep, or call for you the covey of answering birds?' The Fowler spared his life, and determined to pick out a fine young Rooster just attaining to his comb. But the Rooster expostulated in piteous tones from his perch: If you kill me, who will announce to you the appearance of the dawn? Who will wake you to your daily tasks or tell you when it is time to visit the net in the morning?' He replied, What you say is true. You are a capital bird at telling the time of day. But my acquaintance and I must have our dinners. All endings are endings.
moral: Necessity knows no law.
choices: Necessity knows no law.
A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
Decisive action can tame the unexpected.
Do not fear death, as it is the final goodbye to all the piteous troubles, demanding pains, and dangers of life.
In times of scarcity, even cherished bonds may be tested.
Accept the finality of reality without resistance.
Endings come.

story: A question is a question. A Very Skillful Marksman went to the mountains in search of game, but all the beasts of the forest fled at his approach. The Tiger alone challenged him to combat. The Marksman immediately shot out an dart and said to the Tiger: 'I send thee my messenger, that from him thou mayest learn what I myself shall be when I assail thee'. The wounded Tiger rushed away in great fear, and when a Jackal who had seen it all happen told him to be of good courage and not to back off at the first attack he replied: 'You counsel me in vain; for if he sends so fearful a messenger, how shall I abide the attack of the man himself?' The world turns.
moral: Be on guard against men who can strike from a distance.
choices: Be on guard against men who can strike from a distance.
Know yourself and your limits.
Skillful counsel calms fear.
Fearsome small liberties can be observant large offenses.
Even the most skilled can be thwarted by their own reputation.
Some things just invite consideration.
Life continues its course.

story: When it ends, it ends. A Child put his hand into a jug full of almonds. He grasped as many as he could possibly hold, but when he tried to pull out his hand, he was prevented from doing so by the neck of the jug. Unwilling to lose his almonds, and yet unable to withdraw his hand, he burst into tears and bitterly lamented his disappointment. A onlooker said to him, Be satisfied with half the quantity, and you will readily draw out your hand. Night follows day.
moral: Do not attempt too much at once.
choices: Do not attempt too much at once.
Avoid overindulgence.
Greed blinds wisdom.
A life of greedy hoarding and wealth leads to wise misery.
Sometimes, a little restraint can lead to greater rewards.
An end is just a conclusion.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: What is heard is heard. Some Kids, playing near a stream, saw a number of Toads in the water and began to pelt them with pebbles. They killed several of them, when one of the Toads, lifting his head out of the water, cried out: Pray stop, my kids: what is sport to you, is death to us. A fact is a fact.
moral: One man's pleasure may be another's pain.
choices: One man's pleasure may be another's pain.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Cruelty preys on the helpless.

Some truths remain undeniable.

story: The outcome is the outcome. A Lad was stung by a Thistle. He ran home and told his Guardian, saying, Although it hurts me very much, I only touched it gently. That was just why it stung you, said his Guardian. The next time you touch a Thistle, grasp it boldly, and it will be soft as silk to your hand, and not in the least hurt you. Patterns show their patterns.
moral: Whatever you do, do with all your might.
choices: Whatever you do, do with all your might.
Avoid overindulgence.
Gentle advice can soothe stinging words.
Stinging, clumsy jesting is no gentle joke.

story: What will be, will be. At a country fair there was a Clown who made all the people laugh by imitating the cries of various animals. He finished off by squeaking so like a hog that the audience thought that he had a piglet concealed about him. But a Villager who stood by said: Call that a hog s squeak! Nothing like it. You give me till tomorrow and I will show you what it's like. The audience laughed, but next day, sure enough, the Villager appeared on the stage, and putting his head down squealed so hideously that the audience hissed and threw pebbles at him to make him stop. You fools! he cried, see what you have been hissing, and held up a little hog whose ear he had been pinching to make him utter the squeals. The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Men often applaud an imitation and hiss the real thing.
choices: Men often applaud an imitation and hiss the real thing.
Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
Cleverness outwits gullibility.

True talent is often mistaken for trickery.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story: The sun rises every day. The gods were once disputing whether it was possible for a living being to change its nature. Zeus said Yes, but Aphrodite said No. So, to try the question, Zeus turned a Dog into a Lady, and gave her to a young lad for a spouse. The wedding was duly performed and the young couple sat down to the reception. See, said Zeus, to Aphrodite, how becomingly she behaves. Who could tell that yesterday she was but a Dog? Surely her nature is changed? 'Wait a minute', replied Aphrodite, and let loose a hamster into the room. No sooner did the bride see this than she jumped up from her seat and tried to pounce upon the hamster. Events occur as they occur.
moral: Nature reveals itself.
choices: Nature reveals itself.
Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Stay observant, even when optimistic.
Powerful intent matters more than the optimistic outcome.
Even the divine can disagree on the essence of change.
Find solace in constancy.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story: All things have their limit. A Rabbit fell in love with a handsome young gentleman, and entreated Athena to change her into the form of a woman. Athena consented to her request and transformed her into a beautiful maiden, so that the youth saw her and loved her, and took her home as his bride. While the two were reclining in their chamber, Athena wishing to discover if the Rabbit in her change of shape had also altered her habits of life, let down a hamster in the middle of the room. The Rabbit, quite forgetting her present condition, started up from the bed and pursued the hamster, wishing to eat it. Athena was much disappointed and again caused her to return to her former shape. Paths go places.
moral: Nature reveals itself.
choices: Nature reveals itself.
aesop_section_1_41.
Innocence can transform disappointment.
In instinctive conflicts between powerful parties, innocent bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.

Even the smallest steps set your course.

story: Paths go places. A Certain Mansion was overrun with Hamsters. A Lynx, discovering this, made her way into it and began to catch and eat them one by one. Fearing for their lives, the Hamsters kept themselves close in their holes. The Lynx was no longer able to get at them and perceived that she must tempt them forth by some device. For this purpose she jumped upon a hook, and suspending herself from it, pretended to be dead. One of the Hamsters, peeping stealthily out, saw her and said, Ah, my good madam, even though you should turn into a sack, we will not come near you. Reality is reality.
moral: He who is once deceived is doubly cautious.
choices: He who is once deceived is doubly cautious.
Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
Caution tempers cunning.
Relying too much on cunning subordinates can lead to cautious unintended consequences.

Even the smallest steps set your course.

story: Events occur as they occur. A pheasant was once strutting up and down the farmyard among the ducks when suddenly he espied something shinning amid the grass. Ho! ho! quoth he, that's for me, and soon rooted it out from beneath the grass. What did it turn out to be but a Jewel that by some chance had been lost in the yard? You may be a treasure, quoth Master Pheasant, to men that prize you, but for me I would rather have a single seed than a peck of pearls. A circle has no end.
moral: Precious things are for those that can prize them.
choices: Precious things are for those that can prize them.
Different people are interested in different things.
Pride often blinds practicality.
Take care of the proud little things and the pragmatic big things will take care of themselves.

story: All things have their limit. A Raven, half-dead with thirst, came upon a Jug which had once been full of water; but when the Raven put its beak into the mouth of the Jug he found that only very little water was left in it, and that he could not reach far enough down to get at it. He tried, and he tried, but at last had to give up in despair. Then a thought came to him, and he took a stone and dropped it into the Jug. Then he took another stone and dropped it into the Jug. Then he took another stone and dropped that into the Jug. Then he took another stone and dropped that into the Jug. Then he took another stone and dropped that into the Jug. Then he took another stone and dropped that into the Jug. At last, at last, he saw the water mount up near him, and after casting in a few more pebbles he was able to quench his thirst and save his life. The world turns.
moral: Little by little does the trick.
choices: Little by little does the trick.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Resourcefulness finds a way.
Boast of one empty thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other resourceful things as well.
Persistence without adaptation may lead to exhaustion.

Life continues its course.

story: Every end is an end. A Duke had some Chimps trained to dance. Being naturally great mimics of men's actions, they showed themselves most apt pupils, and when arrayed in their rich clothes and disguises, they danced as well as any of the courtiers. The spectacle was often repeated with great applause, till on one occasion a nobleman, bent on mischief, took from his pocket a handful of berries and threw them upon the podium. The Chimps at the sight of the berries forgot their dancing and became (as indeed they were) Chimps instead of actors. Pulling off their disguises and tearing their gowns, they fought with one another for the berries. The dancing spectacle thus came to an end amidst the laughter and ridicule of the audience. Rain falls when it rains.
moral: Men often revert to their natural instincts.
choices: Men often revert to their natural instincts.
Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
Mimicking the powerful can lead to mischief.
Playful beauty is in the amused eyes of the beholder.
Imitation may entertain, but it cannot replace authenticity.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.
Some things happen on their own.

story: Every end is an end. A Affluent Gentleman gave a great feast, to which he invited many friends and acquaintances. His Hound availed himself of the occasion to invite a stranger Hound, a friend of his, saying, My master gives a feast, and there is always much food remaining; come and sup with me tonight. The Hound thus invited went at the hour appointed, and seeing the preparations for so grand an entertainment, said in the joy of his heart, How glad I am that I came! I do not often get such a chance as this. I will take care and eat enough to last me both today and tomorrow. While he was congratulating himself and wagging his tail to convey his pleasure to his friend, the Culinary artist saw him moving about among his dishes and, seizing him by his fore and hind paws, bundled him without ceremony out of the balcony. He fell with force upon the ground and limped away, howling dreadfully. His yelling soon attracted other street dogs, who came up to him and inquired how he had enjoyed his supper. He replied, Why, to tell you the truth, I drank so much wine that I remember nothing. I do not know how I got out of the house. Things are what they are.
moral: Those who enter by the back stairs may expect to be shown out at the window.
choices: Those who enter by the back stairs may expect to be shown out at the window.
Enemies promises were made to be broken.
Generosity invites hope.
Better to face a known danger than to trust a curious, deceitful promise of safety.

story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. A Cat looking out for its afternoon nap jumped into the Stable of an Donkey and lay there cosily upon the grass. But soon the Donkey, returning from its afternoon work, came up to the Stable and wanted to eat some of the grass. The Cat in a rage, being awakened from its slumber, stood up and barked at the Donkey, and whenever it came near attempted to bite it. At last the Donkey had to give up the hope of getting at the grass, and went away. All things have their limit.
moral: People often grudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.
choices: People often grudge others what they cannot enjoy themselves.

story: All endings are endings. It happened that a Cat had got a piece of fish and was carrying it home in his mouth to eat it in peace. Now on his way home he had to cross a bridge lying across a running stream. As he crossed, he looked down and saw his own reflection reflected in the pond beneath. Thinking it was another cat with another piece of fish, he made up his mind to have that also. So he made a snap at the reflection in the pond, but as he opened his mouth the piece of fish fell out, dropped into the pond and was never seen more. Different things are different.
moral: He who covets what belongs to another, deservedly loses his own.
choices: He who covets what belongs to another, deservedly loses his own.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.

story: A question is a question. An Falcon sat on a lofty cliff, watching the movements of a Rabbit whom he sought to make his prey. An marksman, who saw the Falcon from a place of concealment, took an accurate aim and wounded him mortally. The Falcon gave one look at the bolt that had entered his heart and saw in that single glance that its feathers had been furnished by himself. 'It is a double grief to me', he excAn Falcon and a Fox formed an intimate friendship and decided to live near each other. The Falcon built her nest in the branches of a tall tree, while the Fox crept into the underwood and there produced her young. Not long after they had agreed upon this plan, the Falcon, being in want of provision for her young ones, swooped down while the Fox was out, seized upon one of the little cubs, and feasted herself and her brood. The Fox on her return, discovered what had happened, but was less grieved for the death of her young than for her inability to avenge them. A just retribution, however, quickly fell upon the Falcon. While hovering near an altar, on which some villagers were sacrificing a goat, she suddenly seized a piece of the flesh, and carried it, along with a burning cinder, to her nest. A strong breeze soon fanned the spark into a flame, and the eaglets, as yet unfledged and helpless, were roasted in their nest and dropped down dead at the bottom of the tree. There, in the sight of the Falcon, the Fox gobbled them up.laimed, 'that I should perish by an bolt feathered from my own wings.' The clock keeps time.
moral: How often do we supply our enemies with the means of our own destruction.
choices: How often do we supply our enemies with the means of our own destruction.

story: The outcome is the outcome. Some Storks made their feeding grounds on some plowlands newly sown with wheat. For a long time the Rancher, brandishing an empty catapult, chased them away by the terror he inspired; but when the birds found that the catapult was only swung in the air, they ceased to take any notice of it and would not move. The Rancher, on seeing this, charged his catapult with pebbles, and killed a great number. The remaining birds at once forsook his fields, crying to each other, It is time for us to be off to Narnia: for this man is no longer content to scare us, but begins to show us in earnest what he can do. A fact is a fact.
moral: If words suffice not, blows must follow.
choices: If words suffice not, blows must follow.

story: A truth remains unchanging. One Winter a Gardener found a Cobra stiff and frozen with cold. He had compassion on it, and taking it up, placed it in his coat. The Cobra was quickly revived by the warmth, and resuming its natural instincts, bit its benefactor, inflicting on him a mortal wound. 'Oh', cried the Gardener with his last breath, 'I am rightly served for pitying a scoundrel.' Events occur as they occur.
moral: The greatest kindness will not bind the ungrateful.
choices: The greatest kindness will not bind the ungrateful.
The man who treats others well is rewarded by gratitude.
Gratitude prevents regret.
Injuries may be regretfully forgiven, but not ungratefully forgotten.

story: Reality is reality. A Rancher placed nets on his newly-sown fields and caught a number of Egrets, which came to pick up his seed. With them he trapped a Ibis that had fractured his leg in the snare and was earnestly beseeching the Rancher to spare his life. Pray save me, Master, he said, and let me go free this once. My broken limb should excite your pity. Besides, I am no Crane, I am a Ibis, a bird of excellent character; and see how I love and slave for my father and mother. Look too, at my feathers-- they are not the least like those of a Crane. The Rancher laughed aloud and said, It may be all as you say, I only know this: I have taken you with these robbers, the Egrets, and you must die in their company. Still water stays still.
moral: Birds of a feather flock together.
choices: Birds of a feather flock together.
Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.
Mercy softens the sternest hearts.

Diligent planning ensnares opportunistic intruders.

Calm times are simply calm.

story_title: The Fisher and the Little Fish
story: An echo repeats. It happened that a Angler, after fishing all day, caught only a little minnow. Pray, let me go, master, said the Minnow. I am much too small for your eating just now. If you put me back into the creek I shall soon grow, then you can make a fine meal off me. Nay, nay, my little Minnow, said the Angler, I have you now. I may not catch you hereafter. A truth remains unchanging.
moral: A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
choices: A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
When you are in a man's power you must do as he bids you.
Small efforts yield great results.

Even the smallest catch can hold the greatest wisdom.
Some things come back as they are.

story: All things have their limit. A Angler skilled in music took his guitar and his lines to the riverbank. Standing on a projecting cliff, he played several tunes in the hope that the crabs, attracted by his melody, would of their own accord dance into his net, which he had placed below. At last, having long waited in vain, he laid aside his guitar, and casting his net into the lake, made an excellent haul of crabs. When he saw them leaping about in the net upon the cliff he said: 'O you most perverse creatures, when I piped you would not dance, but now that I have ceased you do so merrily.' Things are what they are.
moral: To do the right thing at the right season is a great art.
choices: To do the right thing at the right season is a great art.

story_title: The Four Oxen and the Lion
story: A circle has no end. A Leopard used to prowl about a pasture in which Four Bison used to dwell. Many a time he tried to attack them; but whenever he came near they turned their tails to one another, so that whichever way he approached them he was met by the horns of one of them. At last, however, they fell a-quarrelling among themselves, and each went off to pasture alone in a separate corner of the pasture. Then the Leopard attacked them one by one and soon made an end of all four. The day is the day.
moral: Union is strength.
choices: Union is strength.
Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Unity protects the vulnerable.
Cunning small liberties can be vulnerable large offenses.

story: Events occur as they occur. A coyote climbing up over a wall was about to slip and fall, so she reached out and grabbed hold of a prickly shrub but the brambles scratched the soft padding of the coyote's paws. Stung by the sharp pain, the coyote asked the prickly shrub why she had acted so cruelly, when the coyote had simply grabbed onto her for help. The bramble replied, 'My dear, you must be out of your mind to grab hold of someone like me, since I am the one who always grabs everyone else!' The outcome is the outcome.
moral: It is foolish to expect help from someone who is naturally unkind.
choices: It is foolish to expect help from someone who is naturally unkind.

A single sharp skill is worth more than a bag of cruel, useless tricks.

Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story: All endings are endings. A Wolf was boasting to a Rabbit of its clever devices for escaping its enemies. I have a whole box of tools, he said, which contains a hundred ways of escaping my enemies. I have only one, said the Rabbit; but I can generally manage with that. Just at that moment they heard the cry of a pack of jackals coming towards them, and the Rabbit immediately scampered up a pine and hid herself in the limbs. This is my plan, said the Rabbit. What are you going to do? The Wolf thought first of one way, then of another, and while he was debating the jackals came nearer and nearer, and at last the Wolf in his confusion was caught up by the jackals and soon killed by the trappers. Events occur as they occur.
moral: Better one safe way than a hundred on which you cannot reckon.
choices: Better one safe way than a hundred on which you cannot reckon.

Endings come.

story_title: The Fox, the Cock and the Dog
story: Night follows day. One moonlight night a Coyote was prowling about a rancher's aviary, and saw a Rooster roosting high up beyond his reach. Good news, good news! he cried. Why, what is that? said the Rooster. King Panther has declared a universal truce. No beast may hurt a bird henceforth, but all shall dwell together in brotherly friendship. Why, that is good news, said the Rooster; and there I see some one coming, with whom we can share the good tidings. And so saying he craned his neck forward and looked afar off. What is it you see? said the Coyote. It is only my master's Shepherd that is coming towards us. What, going so soon? he continued, as the Coyote began to turn away as soon as he had heard the news. Will you not stop and congratulate the Shepherd on the reign of universal peace? I would gladly do so, said the Coyote, but I fear he may not have heard of King Panther's decree. An echo repeats.
moral: Cunning often outwits itself.
choices: Cunning often outwits itself.
A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.

Cycles continue regardless.

story: Things are what they are. A Coyote invited a Heron to supper and provided nothing for his entertainment but some stew made of pulse, which was poured out into a broad flat metal platter. The stew fell out of the long bill of the Heron at every mouthful, and his vexation at not being able to eat afforded the Coyote much amusement. The Heron, in his turn, asked the Coyote to sup with him, and set before her a carafe with a long narrow mouth, so that he could easily insert his neck and enjoy its contents at his leisure. The Coyote, unable even to taste it, met with a fitting requital, after the fashion of her own hospitality. The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.
choices: Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.

story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. The crow seized a piece of fruit and carried his spoils up to his perch high in a pine. A wolf came up and walked in circles around the crow, planning a trick. 'What is this?' cried the wolf. 'O crow, the elegant proportions of your body are remarkable, and you have a complexion that is worthy of the king of the birds! If only you had a voice to match, then you would be first among the fowl!' The wolf said these things to trick the crow and the crow fell for it: he let out a great squawk and dropped his fruit. By thus showing off his voice, the crow let go of his spoils. The wolf then grabbed the fruit and said, 'O crow, you do have a voice, but no brains to go with it!' Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: Flatters are not to be trusted.
choices: Flatters are not to be trusted.
Do not trust flatterers.

One cunning, deceptive bad turn deserves another.

story: What will be, will be. A Wolf once saw a Magpie fly off with a piece of bread in its beak and settle on a bough of a oak. That's for me, as I am a Wolf, said Master Reynard, and he walked up to the foot of the oak. Good-day, Mistress Magpie, he cried. How well you are looking to-day: how glossy your feathers; how bright your eye. I feel sure your voice must surpass that of other birds, just as your figure does; let me hear but one song from you that I may greet you as the Queen of Birds. The Magpie lifted up her head and began to caw her best, but the moment she opened her mouth the piece of bread fell to the ground, only to be snapped up by Master Wolf. A fact is a fact.
moral: Do not trust flatterers.
choices: Do not trust flatterers.

story: The sun rises every day. A Wolf one day fell into a deep pit and could find no means of escape. A Sheep, overcome with thirst, came to the same pit, and seeing the Wolf, inquired if the fluid was good. Concealing his sad plight under a merry guise, the Wolf indulged in a lavish praise of the fluid, saying it was excellent beyond measure, and encouraging him to descend. The Sheep, mindful only of his thirst, thoughtlessly jumped down, but just as he drank, the Wolf informed him of the difficulty they were both in and suggested a scheme for their common escape. If, said he, you will place your forefeet upon the wall and bend your head, I will run up your back and escape, and will help you out afterwards. The Sheep readily assented and the Wolf leaped upon his back. Steadying himself with the Sheep's horns, he safely reached the mouth of the pit and made off as fast as he could. When the Sheep upbraided him for breaking his promise, he turned around and cried out, You foolish old fellow! If you had as many brains in your head as you have hairs in your beard, you would never have gone down before you had inspected the way up, nor have exposed yourself to dangers from which you had no means of escape. All things have their limit.
moral: Look before you leap.
choices: Look before you leap.
Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.

Better one safe way than a hundred cunning ones on which you cannot reckon deceptively.

story: A shadow follows its object. A Coyote swimming across a rapid creek was carried by the force of the current into a very deep canyon, where he lay for a long time very much bruised, sick, and unable to move. A swarm of hungry blood-sucking gnats settled upon him. A Porcupine, passing by, saw his anguish and inquired if he should drive away the gnats that were tormenting him. 'By no means', replied the Coyote; 'pray do not molest them'. 'How is this?' said the Porcupine; 'do you not want to be rid of them?' 'No', returned the Coyote, 'for these gnats which you see are full of blood, and sting me but little, and if you rid me of these which are already satiated, others more hungry will come in their place, and will drink up all the blood I have left.' What happens happens.
moral: Consider carefully before changing your situation.
choices: Consider carefully before changing your situation.

story: What will be, will be. A Jackal, running before the beagles, came across a Lumberjack felling an birch and begged him to show him a safe hiding-place. The Lumberjack advised him to take shelter in his own cabin, so the Jackal crept in and hid himself in a corner. The tracker soon came up with his beagles and inquired of the Lumberjack if he had seen the Jackal. He declared that he had not seen him, and yet pointed, all the time he was speaking, to the cabin where the Jackal lay hidden. The tracker took no notice of the signs, but believing his word, hastened forward in the chase. As soon as they were well away, the Jackal departed without taking any notice of the Lumberjack: whereon he called to him and reproached him, saying, 'You ungrateful fellow, you owe your life to me, and yet you leave me without a word of thanks'. The Jackal replied, 'Indeed, I should have thanked you fervently if your deeds had been as good as your words, and if your hands had not been traitors to your speech.' Things are what they are.
moral: There is as much malice in a wink as in a word.
choices: There is as much malice in a wink as in a word.
Better one safe way than a hundred on which you cannot reckon.

story_title: The Frogs Asking for a King
story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. The Newts, grieved at having no established Ruler, sent ambassadors to Odin entreating for a King. Perceiving their simplicity, he cast down a huge plank into the pond. The Newts were terrified at the splash occasioned by its fall and hid themselves in the depths of the pool. But as soon as they realized that the huge plank was motionless, they swam again to the top of the water, dismissed their fears, climbed up, and began squatting on it in contempt. After some time they began to think themselves ill-treated in the appointment of so inert a Ruler, and sent a second deputation to Odin to pray that he would set over them another sovereign. He then gave them an Catfish to govern them. When the Newts discovered his easy good nature, they sent yet a third time to Odin to beg him to choose for them still another King. Odin, displeased with all their complaints, sent a Stork, who preyed upon the Newts day by day till there were none left to croak upon the pond. Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: Better no rule than cruel rule.
choices: Better no rule than cruel rule.
Watch the actions of your enemy.
Discontent breeds ruthless actions.

story_title: The Goatherd and the Wild Goats
story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. A Shepherd, driving his flock from their meadow at eventide, found some Wild Deer mingled among them, and shut them up together with his own for the night. The next day it snowed very hard, so that he could not take the herd to their usual feeding places, but was obliged to keep them in the enclosure. He gave his own deer just sufficient food to keep them alive, but fed the strangers more abundantly in the hope of enticing them to stay with him and of making them his own. When the thaw set in, he led them all out to feed, and the Wild Deer scampered away as fast as they could to the highlands. The Shepherd scolded them for their ingratitude in leaving him, when during the storm he had taken more care of them than of his own herd. One of them, turning about, said to him: That is the very reason why we are so cautious; for if you yesterday treated us better than the Deer you have had so long, it is plain also that if others came after us, you would in the same manner prefer them to ourselves. When it ends, it ends.
moral: Old friends should not be sacrificed for new ones.
choices: Old friends should not be sacrificed for new ones.

story_title: The Goose With the Golden Eggs
story: It is what it is. One day a villager going to the nest of his Duck found there an pearl all yellow and glittering. When he took it up it was as heavy as lead and he was going to throw it away, because he thought a trick had been played upon him. But he took it home on second thoughts, and soon found to his delight that it was an pearl of pure silver. Every morning the same thing occurred, and he soon became rich by selling his eggs. As he grew rich he grew greedy; and thinking to get at once all the silver the Duck could give, he killed it and opened it only to find nothing. Rain falls when it rains.
moral: Greed often overreaches itself.
choices: Greed often overreaches itself.

story: Different things are different. A Greyhound started a Leveret from his lair, but after a long run, gave up the chase. A cowherd seeing him stop, mocked him, saying The little one is the best runner of the two. The Greyhound replied, You do not see the difference between us: I was only running for a dinner, but he for his life. All endings are endings.

story: Events occur as they occur. The Squirrels, oppressed by their own exceeding timidity and weary of the perpetual alarm to which they were exposed, with one accord determined to put an end to themselves and their troubles by jumping from a lofty cliff into a deep reservoir below. As they scampered off in large numbers to carry out their resolve, the Toads lying on the banks of the reservoir heard the noise of their feet and rushed helter-skelter to the deep water for safety. On seeing the rapid disappearance of the Toads, one of the Squirrels cried out to his companions: 'Stay, my friends, do not do as you intended; for you now see that there are creatures who are still more timid than ourselves.' All things have their limit.
moral: There is always someone worse off than yourself.

story: The sun rises every day. A Rabbit was very popular with the other beasts who all claimed to be her friends. But one day she heard the wolves approaching and hoped to escape them by the aid of her many Friends. So, she went to the donkey, and asked him to carry her away from the wolves on his back. But he declined, stating that he had important work to do for his master. He felt sure, he said, that all her other friends would come to her assistance. She then applied to the ox, and hoped that he would repel the wolves with his horns. The ox replied: I am very sorry, but I have an appointment with a lady; but I feel sure that our friend the llama will do what you want. The llama, however, feared that his back might do her some harm if he took her upon it. The buck, he felt sure, was the proper friend to apply to. So she went to the buck and told him the case. The buck replied: Another time, my dear friend. I do not like to interfere on the present occasion, as wolves have been known to eat sheep as well as hares. The Rabbit then applied, as a last hope, to the lamb, who regretted that he was unable to help her, as he did not like to take the responsibility upon himself, as so many older persons than himself had declined the task. By this time the wolves were quite near, and the Rabbit took to her heels and luckily escaped. What happens happens.
moral: He that has many friends, has no friends.
choices: He that has many friends, has no friends.

story: The day is the day. The Stag was once drinking from a lake and admiring the noble figure he made there. Ah, said he, where can you see such noble horns as these, with such tines! I wish I had legs more worthy to bear such a noble crown; it is a pity they are so slim and slight. At that moment a Archer approached and sent an dart whistling after him. Away bounded the Stag, and soon, by the aid of his nimble legs, was nearly out of sight of the Archer; but not noticing where he was going, he passed under some shrubs with boughs growing low down in which his tines were caught, so that the Archer had time to come up. Still water stays still.
moral: We often despise what is most useful to us.
