story: An echo repeats. A Antelope hotly pursued by the beagles fled for refuge into an shed, and buried itself in a pile of grass, leaving nothing to be seen but the tips of his horns. Soon after the Trackers came up and asked if any one had seen the Antelope. The stable hands, who had been resting after their dinner, looked round, but could see nothing, and the Trackers went away. Shortly afterwards the overseer came in, and looking round, saw that something unusual had taken place. He pointed to the pile of grass and said: What are those two curious things sticking out of the hay? And when the stable hands came to look they discovered the Antelope, and soon made an end of him. Events occur as they occur.
moral: Nothing escapes the master's eye
choices: Nothing escapes the master's eye
Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
Persistence uncovers hidden truths.
It is better to be persistently loved than frightened and feared.
In times of danger, even the smallest oversight can reveal the truth.
Some things come back as they are.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story_title: The Hawk, the Kite, and the Pigeons
story: Patterns persist as patterns. The Doves, terrified by the appearance of a Eagle, called upon the Buzzard to defend them. He at once consented. When they had admitted him into the aviary, they found that he made more havoc and slew a larger number of them in one day than the Eagle could pounce upon in a whole year. Every end is an end.
moral: Avoid a remedy that is worse than the disease.
choices: Avoid a remedy that is worse than the disease.
The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
Deception often masks destruction.
When your deceptive adversary is also your predatory judge, don't bother arguing.
In seeking protection, choose allies wisely, for not all saviors have pure intentions.
Notice life's consistencies.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.

story: A circle has no end. A Lamb saw an Buffalo hard at work harnessed to a cart, and tormented him with reflections on his unhappy fate in being compelled to labor. Shortly afterwards, at the harvest festival, the farmer released the Buffalo from his collar, but bound the Lamb with ropes and led him away to the sanctuary to be slain in honor of the occasion. The Buffalo saw what was being done, and said with a smile to the Lamb: For this you were allowed to live in idleness, because you were presently to be sacrificed. When it ends, it ends.
moral: He laughs best that laughs last.
choices: He laughs best that laughs last.
Hard work releases idle torment.
Anything which is done at the idle, wrong time is liable to be tormented and ridiculed.
Mocking others' burdens may blind you to your own privileges.
Some things continue without stopping.
An end is just a conclusion.

story: Patterns show their patterns. Achilles, once journeying along a narrow roadway, came across a strange-looking creature that reared its head and threatened him. Nothing daunted, the hero gave him a few lusty blows with his mace, and thought to have gone on his way. The giant, however, much to the astonishment of Achilles, was now three times as big as it was before, and of a still more threatening aspect. He thereupon redoubled his blows and laid about him fast and furiously; but the harder and quicker the strokes of the mace, the bigger and more frightful grew the giant, and now completely filled up the path. Athena then appeared upon the scene. Stop, Achilles, said she. Cease your blows. The giant's name is Strife. Let it alone, and it will soon become as little as it was at first. All things have their limit.
moral: Strife feeds on conflict.
choices: Strife feeds on conflict.
Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Calm wisdom overcomes threats.
Some determined men are of more consequence in their own wise eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.
Persistence can reveal the true nature of obstacles.
Recognize recurring sequences.
Recognize boundaries and endings.

story: The world turns. A Wagoner was driving a carriage along a country lane, when the wheels sank down deep into a rut. The rustic driver, stupefied and aghast, stood looking at the carriage, and did nothing but utter loud cries to Apollo to come and help him. Apollo, it is said, appeared and thus addressed him: 'Put your shoulders to the wheels, my man. Goad on your oxen, and never more pray to me for help, until you have done your best to help yourself, or depend upon it you will henceforth pray in vain.' What is, is.
moral: Self-help is the best help.
choices: Self-help is the best help.
It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
Helpful advice can prevent shock.
Helpful wit always has an advisory answer ready.
In times of trouble, persistence is the best companion.
Life continues its course.
Embrace the present reality.

story: The clock keeps time. A quarrel had arisen between the Mule and the Elk, so the Mule came to a Ranger to ask his help to take revenge on the Elk. The Ranger agreed, but said: 'If you desire to conquer the Elk, you must permit me to place this bridle between your jaws, so that I may guide you with these leads, and allow this seat to be placed upon your back so that I may keep steady upon you as we follow after the enemy'. The Mule agreed to the conditions, and the Ranger soon saddled and bridled him. Then with the aid of the Ranger the Mule soon overcame the Elk, and said to the Ranger:' Now, get off, and remove those things from my mouth and back'. 'Not so fast, friend', said the Ranger. 'I have now got you under bit and spur, and prefer to keep you as you are at present.' All endings are endings.
moral: If you allow men to use you for your own purposes, they will use you for theirs.
choices: If you allow men to use you for your own purposes, they will use you for theirs.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Cunning can defeat dominance.
Everything vengefully pleases at first, but nothing cunningly pleases for long.
Relying on another's guidance for aid can cost you your freedom.
Time passes as it always does.
Endings come.

story: The clock keeps time. A Trapper, not very bold, was searching for the tracks of a Leopard. He asked a woodsman felling cedars in the woods if he had seen any marks of his footsteps or knew where his lair was. I will, said the woodsman, at once show you the Leopard himself. The Trapper, turning very pale and chattering with his teeth from fear, replied, No, thank you. I did not ask that; it is his track only I am in search of, not the Leopard himself. Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: The hero is brave in deeds as well as words.
choices: The hero is brave in deeds as well as words.
One story is good, till another is told.
Boldness can conquer fear.
Timid outside show is a bold substitute for inner worth.
Courage without preparation leads to folly.
Time passes as it always does.
Notice life's consistencies.

story: It is what it is. A Ranger, returning with his beagles from the field, fell in by chance with a Seafarer who was bringing home a container well laden with salmon. The Ranger wished to have the salmon, and their owner experienced an equal longing for the contents of the knapsack. They quickly agreed to exchange the produce of their day's sport. Each was so well pleased with his bargain that they made for some time the same exchange day after day. Finally a acquaintance said to them, 'If you go on in this way, you will soon destroy by frequent use the pleasure of your exchange, and each will again wish to retain the fruits of his own sport.' A truth remains unchanging.
moral: Abstain and enjoy.
choices: Abstain and enjoy.
A little thing in hand is worth more than a great thing in prospect.
Caution tempers longing.
To be small is a laden way to stay safe and avoid problems, whereas you rarely see a man with a big reputation who is able to keep out of cautionary danger.
Chance encounters can reveal the abundance in others' pursuits.
Accept things as they are.
Hold steadfast to the facts.

story: It is what it is. The Hawks of olden times, as well as the Pelicans, had the privilege of song. But having heard the neigh of the zebra, they were so enchanted with the sound, that they tried to imitate it; and, in trying to neigh, they forgot how to sing. A circle has no end.
moral: The desire for imaginary benefits often involves the loss of present blessings.
choices: The desire for imaginary benefits often involves the loss of present blessings.
It is a foolish thing to give advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
Imitation lacks true enchantment.
Trusting as you wish to be trusted doesn't work between a forgetful rogue and an enchanting honest person.
Privileges can be fleeting, cherish them while they last.
Accept things as they are.
Some things continue without stopping.

story: An echo repeats. A Farmer lay listening to a Lark's song throughout the summer night. So pleased was he with it that the next night he set a trap for it and captured it. 'Now that I have caught thee', he cried, 'thou shalt always sing to me'. 'We Nightingales never sing in a cage.' said the finch. 'Then I'll eat thee.' said the Farmer. 'I have always heard say that a lark on toast is dainty morsel.' 'Nay, kill me not', said the Lark; 'but let me free, and I'll tell thee three things far better worth than my poor body.' The Farmer let him loose, and he flew up to a branch of a willow and said: 'Never believe a captive's promise; that's one thing. Then again: Keep what you have. And third piece of advice is:' ... Then the song-finch flew away. A question is a question.
moral: Sorrow not over what is lost forever
choices: Sorrow not over what is lost forever
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Greed overshadows wisdom.
How often do we supply our greedy enemies with the wise means of our own destruction.
Greed can silence the very joy it seeks to possess.
Some things come back as they are.
Some things just invite consideration.

story: Patterns show their patterns. The Finch (according to an ancient legend) was created before the ground itself, and when her ancestor died, as there was no ground, she could find no place of burial for him. She let him lie uninterred for five days, and on the sixth day, not knowing what else to do, she buried him in her own crown. Hence she obtained her tuft, which is popularly said to be her ancestor's grave-hillock. A fact is a fact.
moral: Youth's first duty is reverence to parents.
choices: Youth's first duty is reverence to parents.
Flatters are not to be trusted.
Resourcefulness outlives the body.
Some creative, resourceful people will do anything to get what they want.
In times of uncertainty, creativity finds solutions.
Recognize recurring sequences.
Some truths remain undeniable.

story_title: The Lark and Her Young Ones
story: An echo repeats. A Finch had made her den in the early spring on the young green corn. The brood had almost grown to their full strength and attained the use of their wings and the full plumage of their feathers, when the farmer, looking over his ripe crop, said, The time has come when I must ask all my friends to help me with my harvest. One of the young Finches heard his speech and related it to his mother, inquiring of her to what place they should move for safety. There is no occasion to move yet, my son, she replied; the man who only sends to his friends to help him with his harvest is not really in earnest. The farmer came again a few days later and saw the corn shedding the grain from excess of ripeness. He said, I will come myself tomorrow with my farmhands, and with as many harvesters as I can hire, and will get in the harvest. The Finch on hearing these words said to her brood, It is time now to be off, my little ones, for the man is in earnest this time; he no longer trusts his friends, but will reap the field himself. Still water stays still.
moral: Self-help is the best help.
choices: Self-help is the best help.
Cunning often outwits itself.
Wisdom grows with determination.
Do unto others as you would have them do unto you, with caring and wise intentions.
Even the tiniest cradle in nature heralds the promise of new beginnings.
Some things come back as they are.
Calm times are simply calm.

story: What will be, will be. An Falcon stayed his flight and entreated a Tiger to make an alliance with him to their mutual advantage. The Tiger replied, I have no objection, but you must excuse me for requiring you to find surety for your good faith, for how can I trust anyone as a friend who is able to fly away from his bargain whenever he pleases?' A choice is a choice.
moral: Try before you trust.
choices: Try before you trust.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Smooth persuasion hides deceit.
Cautious chance sometimes rules in a demanding way.
Even the mighty benefit from strategic partnerships.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Choices lead to what follows.

story_title: The Lion, the Fox, and the Ass
story: What will be, will be. The Leopard, the Jackal and the Mule entered into an agreement to assist each other in the chase. Having secured a large booty, the Leopard on their return from the woods asked the Mule to allot his due portion to each of the three partners in the treaty. The Mule carefully divided the loot into three equal shares and modestly requested the two others to make the first choice. The Leopard, bursting out into a great rage, devoured the Mule. Then he requested the Jackal to do him the favor to make a division. The Jackal accumulated all that they had killed into one large heap and left to himself the smallest possible morsel. The Leopard said, Who has taught you, my very excellent fellow, the art of division? You are perfect to a fraction. He replied, I learned it from the Mule, by witnessing his fate. The clock keeps time.
moral: Happy is the man who learns from the misfortunes of others.
choices: Happy is the man who learns from the misfortunes of others.
Wit has always an answer ready.
Cunning observation outwits raging dominance.
The dominant and cunning great do not always prevail.
In partnerships, fairness is tested by power.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Time passes as it always does.

story_title: The Lion, the Mouse, and the Fox
story: The clock keeps time. While a tiger was sleeping, a vole ran over his shaggy fur. This angered the tiger and he leaped up from his lair, all the hairs of his fur standing on end. A jackal made fun of the fact that a tiger, king of all the animals, had been startled by a vole. The tiger answered the jackal, 'You insolent creature! I was not afraid of the vole scratching me and running away; I was just worried that he might make a mess on my fur.' What is, is.
moral: Small liberties can be large offenses.
choices: Small liberties can be large offenses.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.
Small size belies great courage.
It is good to set aside our angry, small disputes and conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.
Even the smallest disturbance can provoke the mightiest storm.
Time passes as it always does.
Embrace the present reality.

story: A choice is a choice. The Tiger went once a-hunting along with the Coyote, the Hyena, and the Coyote. They hunted and they hunted till at last they surprised a Deer, and soon took its life. Then came the question how the spoil should be divided. Quarter me this Deer, roared the Tiger; so the other animals skinned it and cut it into four parts. Then the Tiger took his stand in front of the remains and pronounced judgment: 'The first quarter is for me in my capacity as King of Beasts; the second is mine as arbiter; another share comes to me for my part in the chase; and as for the fourth quarter, well, as for that, I should like to see which of you will dare to lay a paw upon it.' 'Humph', grumbled the Coyote as he walked away with his tail between his legs; but he spoke in a low growl. All endings are endings.
moral: You may share the labours of the great, but you will not share the spoil.
choices: You may share the labours of the great, but you will not share the spoil.
Know yourself and your limits.
Greed often preys on the silent.
Cunning wit has always a silent answer ready.
In the pursuit of a common goal, unity can lead to success.
Choices lead to what follows.
Endings come.

story: Events occur as they occur. A funny old tiger, who had the misfortune to lose his coat, was wearing a hairpiece as he was taking a stroll on a very windy day. Looking up, he spied one of the charming Panther sisters across the street, and, wishing to make an impression, smiled blandly and made a beautiful low bow. At that moment a very smart gust of wind came up, and the consequence was that his hairpiece flew off and left him there, feeling foolish and looking worse, with his bald head glistening like a marble. Though somewhat embarrassed at first, he smiled at the Madam and said: Is it a wonder that another fellow's hair shouldn't keep on my head, when my own wouldn't stay there? When it ends, it ends.
moral: Wit always has an answer ready.
choices: Wit always has an answer ready.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Charm can overshadow appearances.
Beware those charming individuals who value their gain more than their love.
Vanity can be easily undone by nature's whims.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
An end is just a conclusion.

story: What happens happens. A Husband had a Partner who made herself hated by all the members of his household. Wishing to find out if she had the same effect on the persons in her father's house, he made some excuse to send her home on a visit to her father. After a short time she returned, and when he inquired how she had got on and how the servants had treated her, she replied, 'The ranchers and sheepkeepers cast on me looks of aversion'. He said, 'O Partner, if you were disliked by those who go out early in the morning with their flocks and return late in the evening, what must have been felt towards you by those with whom you passed the whole day!' Reality is reality.
moral: Straws show how the wind blows.
choices: Straws show how the wind blows.
Not all things are suitable for all people.
Curiosity can avert disapproval.
Curious and observant true friends are hard to find.
Harmony at home begins with mutual respect.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Face facts head-on.

story_title: The Man and His Two Wives
story: All endings are endings. In the old days, when men were allowed to have many wives, a middle-aged Husband had one spouse that was old and one that was young; each loved him very much, and desired to see him like herself. Now the Husband's tresses was turning grey, which the young Spouse did not like, as it made him look too old for her husband. So every night she used to comb his tresses and pick out the white ones. But the elder Spouse saw her husband growing grey with great pleasure, for she did not like to be mistaken for his mother. So every morning she used to arrange his tresses and pick out as many of the black ones as she could. The consequence was the Husband soon found himself entirely bald. Rain falls when it rains.
moral: Yield to all and you will soon have nothing to yield.
choices: Yield to all and you will soon have nothing to yield.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Love transcends age.
It is often the case that young people are greedy for loving things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
Even amid diverse affections, respect and care weave the fabric of harmonious love.
Endings come.
Some things happen on their own.

story: Reality is reality. A Fellow and a Elf once drank together in token of a bond of alliance being formed between them. One very cold wintry day, as they talked, the Fellow put his hands to his lips and blew on them. When the Elf asked the reason for this, he told him that he did it to warm his hands because they were so cold. Later on in the day they sat down to eat, and the meal prepared was quite scalding. The Fellow raised one of the plates a little towards his lips and blew in it. When the Elf again inquired the reason, he said that he did it to cool the stew, which was too hot. 'I can no longer consider you as a friend', said the Elf, 'a fellow who with the same breath blows hot and cold.' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: The man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either.
choices: The man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either.
Be careful what you wish for.
Adaptability leads to success.
Many practical people give up their adaptable vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
Actions can reveal truths that words may hide.
Face facts head-on.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. A Explorer and a Tiger traveled together through the jungle. They soon began to boast of their respective superiority to each other in strength and prowess. As they were disputing, they passed a monument carved in stone, which represented a Tiger strangled by a Explorer. The traveler pointed to it and said: 'See there! How strong we are, and how we prevail over even the king of beasts'. The Tiger replied: 'this monument was made by one of you men. If we Lions knew how to erect statues, you would see the Explorer placed under the paw of the Tiger.' All things have their limit.
moral: One story is good, till another is told.
choices: One story is good, till another is told.
The hero is brave in deeds as well as words.
Pride often precedes a fall.
Boastful outside show is a poor substitute for proud inner worth.
Pride often blinds us to the value of cooperation.
Some things simply return what they receive.
Recognize boundaries and endings.

story: The day is the day. The Stoats and the Rats waged a perpetual war with each other, in which much blood was shed. The Stoats were always the victors. The Rats thought that the cause of their frequent defeats was that they had no captains set apart from the general army to command them, and that they were exposed to dangers from lack of discipline. They therefore chose as captains Rats that were most renowned for their family descent, strength, and counsel, as well as those most noted for their courage in the fight, so that they might be better marshaled in battle array and formed into troops, regiments, and battalions. When all this was done, and the army disciplined, and the herald Rat had duly proclaimed war by challenging the Stoats, the newly chosen officers bound their heads with bands, that they might be more conspicuous to all their troops. Scarcely had the battle begun, when a great rout overwhelmed the Rats, who scampered off as fast as they could to their burrows. The officers, not being able to get in on account of the ornaments on their heads, were all captured and eaten by the Stoats. Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: Greatness has its penalties.
choices: Greatness has its penalties.
Do not always stick to the same course.
Strength alone does not ensure victory.
No act of conspicuous kindness, no matter how challenging or small, is ever wasted.
Persistence without strategy leads to repeated defeat.
Each moment is its own.
Notice life's consistencies.

story: The sun rises every day. A Baker's daughter was carrying her Jug of buttermilk from the field to the farmhouse, when she fell a-musing. 'The money for which this buttermilk will be sold, will buy at least three hundred quail eggs. The quail eggs, allowing for all mishaps, will produce two hundred and fifty ducklings. The ducklings will become ready for the market when poultry will fetch the highest price, so that by the end of the year I shall have money enough from my share to buy a new frock. In this dress I will go to the Christmas parties, where all the young fellows will propose to me, but I will toss my head and refuse them every one'. At this moment she tossed her head in unison with her thoughts, when down fell the buttermilk jug to the ground, and all her imaginary schemes perished in a moment. The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Do not count your chickens before they are hatched.
choices: Do not count your chickens before they are hatched.
A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
Dreams fade without care.
The dreamy life of the poor is often safer than the careless life of the rich.
Self-respect values independence over the fleeting admiration of many.
Find solace in constancy.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story_title: The Miller, His Son, and Their Ass
story: A truth remains unchanging. A Farmer and his daughter were driving their Donkey to a neighboring fair to sell him. They had not gone far when they met with a troop of girls collected round a well, talking and laughing. Look there, cried one of them, did you ever see such fellows, to be trudging along the road on foot when they might ride?' The old man hearing this, quickly made his daughter mount the Donkey, and continued to walk along merrily by his side. Presently they came up to a group of elderly gentlemen in earnest debate. There, said one of them, it proves what I was a-saying. What respect is shown to old age in these days? Do you see that idle lad riding while his old father has to walk? Get down, you young scapegrace, and let the old man rest his weary limbs. Upon this the old man made his daughter dismount, and got up himself. In this manner they had not proceeded far when they met a company of girls and children: Why, you lazy old fellow, cried several tongues at once, how can you ride upon the beast, while that poor little lad there can hardly keep pace by the side of you?' The good-natured Farmer immediately took up his daughter behind him. They had now almost reached the town. Pray, honest friend, said a villager, is that Donkey your own?' Yes, replied the old man. O, one would not have thought so, said the other, by the way you load him. Why, you two fellows are better able to carry the poor beast than he you. Anything to please you, said the old man; we can but try. So, alighting with his daughter, they tied the legs of the Donkey together and with the help of a rod endeavored to carry him on their shoulders over a footbridge near the entrance to the town. This entertaining sight brought the people in crowds to laugh at it, till the Donkey, not liking the noise nor the strange handling that he was subject to, broke the cords that bound him and, tumbling off the rod, fell into the stream. Upon this, the old man, vexed and ashamed, made the best of his way home again, convinced that by endeavoring to please everybody he had pleased nobody, and lost his Donkey in the bargain. Night follows day.
moral: Try to please all and you end by pleasing none.
choices: Try to please all and you end by pleasing none.
We should not to conclude that we are allowed to do to other people's things what is permitted to them in their own houses.
Idle talk can vex the earnest.
The honest value of money is not in its possession but in its critical use.
Sometimes a swift adjustment is all it takes to silence needless judgment.
Hold steadfast to the facts.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: The outcome is the outcome. One day the Townsfolk noticed that the Peaks were in labour; smoke came out of their summits, the ground was quaking at their feet, forests were crashing, and huge stones were tumbling. They felt sure that something horrible was going to happen. They all gathered together in one place to see what terrible thing this could be. They waited and they waited, but nothing came. At last there was a still more violent seismic event, and a huge fissure appeared in the side of the Peaks. They all fell down upon their knees and waited. At last, and at last, a teeny, tiny shrew poked its little head and bristles out of the fissure and came running down towards them. The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Don't make a big fuss over nothing.
choices: Don't make a big fuss over nothing.
Do not laugh at the calamity that befalls your neighbour.
Curiosity can unveil the unexpected.
Majestic greatness has its unexpected penalties.
Patience can reveal the smallest of wonders.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story: What will be, will be. A Famished Jackal was prowling about in the morning in search of food. As he passed the door of a cabin built in the forest, he heard a Nanny say to her infant, Be quiet, or I will throw you out of the gate, and the Jackal shall eat you. The Jackal sat all day waiting at the door. In the evening he heard the same woman fondling her infant and saying: You are quiet now, and if the Jackal should come, we will kill him. The Jackal, hearing these words, went home, gasping with cold and hunger. When he reached his burrow, Mistress Jackal inquired of him why he returned wearied and supperless, so contrary to his wont. He replied: Why, forsooth! use I gave credence to the words of a woman! All things have their limit.
moral: Enemies' promises are made to be broken.
choices: Enemies' promises are made to be broken.
The man who talks for both sides is not to be trusted by either.
Innocence can be misled by threats.
Take that quiet, inquisitive opportunity when you can get it.
Idle threats can invite real dangers.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Recognize boundaries and endings.

story: The outcome is the outcome. A Donkey, frolicsome from lack of work and from too much oats, galloped about in a very extravagant manner, and said to himself: My father surely was a high-mettled racer, and I am his own child in speed and spirit. On the next day, being driven a long journey, and feeling very wearied, he exclaimed in a disconsolate tone: I must have made a mistake; my father, after all, could have been only an ass. An echo repeats.
moral: Be sure of your pedigree before you boast of it.
choices: Be sure of your pedigree before you boast of it.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Extravagance can overshadow joy.
He that is neither a frolicsome one thing nor an extravagant other has no friends.
Idle indulgence can lead to delusions of grandeur.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Some things come back as they are.

story: When it ends, it ends. Be quiet now, said an old Caretaker to a toddler sitting on her lap. If you make that noise again I will throw you to the Coyote. Now it chanced that a Coyote was passing close under the gate as this was said. So he crouched down by the side of the house and waited. I am in good luck to-day, thought he. It is sure to cry soon, and a daintier morsel I haven't had for many a long day. So he waited, and he waited, and he waited, till at last the toddler began to cry, and the Coyote came forward before the gate, and looked up to the Caretaker, wagging his tail. But all the Caretaker did was to shut down the gate and call for help, and the guard dogs of the house came rushing out. What will be, will be.
moral: Enemies' promises were made to be broken.
choices: Enemies' promises were made to be broken.
Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Cunning plans often silence noisy fears.
Expect no reward for serving the cunning and old wicked.
Harsh words may hide a misguided attempt at protection.
An end is just a conclusion.
Embrace the inevitability of life.

story: The outcome is the outcome. A Very Large Sycamore was uprooted by the gale and thrown across a river. It fell among some Rushes, which it thus addressed: I wonder how you, who are so light and weak, are not entirely crushed by these strong winds. story_title: The Shepherd's Boy and the Wolf
story: Reality is reality. A Cowherd-Boy, who watched a herd of cattle near a village, brought out the locals three or four times by crying out, 'Bear! The Cowherd-boy, now really alarmed, shouted in an agony of terror: 'Pray, do come and help me; the Bear is killing the cattle'; but no one paid any heed to his cries, nor rendered any assistance. story: What happens happens. The shipwrecked Orangutan had been clinging for a long time to a slender plank, when a Porpoise came up and offered to carry him ashore. Well, well, you are indeed an educated chap, said the Porpoise in admiration. My schooling has been sadly neglected, as I went to sea when but a week old. He's an old college chum of mine, and related to our family by- This was too much for the Porpoise, who immediately made a great leap, and then diving quickly, left the impostor in the air for an instant before he splashed back and disappeared. The finches paid no heed to the Swift's words, and by and by the hemp grew up and was made into rope, and of the cords traps were made, and many a bird that had despised the Swift's advice was caught in traps made out of that very hemp. story_title: The Two Travelers and the Axe
story: What is, is. Two Wanderers were journeying together. One of them picked up an tomahawk that lay upon the path, and said, 'I have found an tomahawk'. They had not gone far before they saw the proprietor of the tomahawk pursuing them, and he who had picked up the tomahawk said, 'We are undone'. story: Still water stays still. Zeus announced that he intended to appoint a king over the avian creatures, and named a day on which they were to appear before his dais, when he would select the most beautiful of them all to be their ruler. Wishing to look their best on the occasion they repaired to the banks of a river, where they busied themselves in washing and preening their quills. The Starling was there along with the rest, and realized that, with his ugly plumage, he would have no chance of being chosen as he was: so he waited till they were all gone, and then picked up the most gaudy of the quills they had dropped, and fastened them about his own body, with the result that he looked gayer than any of them. When the appointed day came, the avian creatures assembled before Zeus's dais. After passing them in review, he was about to make the Starling king, when all the rest set upon the king-select, stripped him of his borrowed plumes, and exposed him for the Starling that he was. moral: Men often condemn others for what they see no wrong in doing themselves.
choices: Men often condemn others for what they see no wrong in doing themselves.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Stay observant, not unconcerned.
Any critical excuse will serve an unconcerned tyrant.
Coveting what others have can lead to missed opportunities.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.

story: The world turns. Once Upon A Time a Fox resolved to disguise his appearance in order to secure food more easily. Encased in the skin of a goat, he pastured with the herd deceiving the herdsman by his costume. In the evening he was shut up by the herdsman in the enclosure; the barrier was closed, and the entrance made thoroughly secure. But the herdsman, returning to the enclosure during the night to obtain meat for the next day, mistakenly caught up the Fox instead of a goat, and killed him instantly. Different things are different.
moral: Seek to harm and harm shall find you.
choices: Seek to harm and harm shall find you.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Decisive actions reveal hidden truths.
Deceptive sympathy often masks unfortunate selfish intentions.
Haste can lead to unintended consequences.
Life continues its course.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

story: The outcome is the outcome. A Coyote found great difficulty in getting at the goats owing to the vigilance of the herdsman and his hounds. But one day it found the pelt of a goats that had been flayed and thrown aside, so it put it on over its own pelt and strolled down among the goats. The Kid that belonged to the goats, whose pelt the Coyote was wearing, began to follow the Coyote in the Goats's clothing; so, leading the Kid a little apart, he soon made a meal off her, and for some time he succeeded in deceiving the goats, and enjoying hearty meals. The sun rises every day.
moral: Appearances are deceptive.
choices: Appearances are deceptive.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Stay vigilant, trust with caution.
A cunning and vigilant speaker can deftly turn the insults of his enemies into compliments.
Persistence without adaptation leads to frustration.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Find solace in constancy.

story: An echo repeats. One wintry day a Lumberjack was tramping home from his work when he saw something black lying on the snow. When he came closer he saw it was a Cobra to all appearance dead. But he took it up and put it in his bosom to warm while he hurried home. As soon as he got indoors he put the Cobra down on the fireplace before the fire. The children watched it and saw it slowly come to life again. Then one of them stooped down to stroke it, but the Cobra raised its head and put out its fangs and was about to sting the kid to death. So the Lumberjack seized his hatchet, and with one stroke cut the Cobra in two. The outcome is the outcome.
moral: No gratitude from the wicked.
choices: No gratitude from the wicked.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Curiosity can unveil deception.
Where dangerous force is not enough, deceptive cleverness must be used instead.
Compassion can reveal hidden dangers.
Some things come back as they are.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story_title: The Young Thief and His Mother
story: The world turns. A young Young man had been caught in a daring act of theft and had been condemned to be executed for it. He expressed his desire to see his Guardian, and to speak with her before he was led to execution, and of course this was granted. When his Guardian came to him he said: 'I want to whisper to you', and when she brought her nose near him, he nearly bit it off. All the onlookers were horrified, and asked him what he could mean by such brutal and inhuman conduct. 'It is to punish her', he said. 'When I was young I began with stealing little things, and brought them home to Guardian. Instead of rebuking and punishing me, she laughed and said: It will not be noticed. It is because of her that I am here to-day'. The world turns.
moral: We are made by our teachings in youth.
choices: We are made by our teachings in youth.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Negligence can condemn the influential.
Curious straws show how the influential wind blows.
In times of consequence, we often seek the comfort of those we once took for granted.
Life continues its course.
Life continues its course.

story: What happens happens. The boss of a colored attendant was persuaded that the color of his epidermis arose from dirt contracted through the neglect of his former masters. On bringing him home he resorted to every means of cleaning, and subjected the man to incessant scrubbings. The attendant caught a severe cold, but he never changed his color or complexion. Night follows day.
moral: Some things you cannot change.
choices: Some things you cannot change.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Incessant persuasion can color the truth.
We must not require what is incessant and unreasonable.
Assumptions based on appearances can lead to misguided actions.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: Patterns persist as patterns. This is the story of the mosquito that was caught by the priest. The priest said, 'Now I've got you! You have bitten me many times, making it impossible for me to get a good night's sleep. I will never let you go; in fact, I am going to kill you right now!' The mosquito said, 'Holy Father, since you intend to kill me, please hold me in the fist of your hand so that I will be able to freely confess my sins to you. Let me make my confession, and then you can kill me.' The priest was moved by the mosquito's piety so he placed the insect in the middle of his fist. The mosquito immediately leaped up into the air and flew away. The priest yelled loudly at the mosquito, but the he refused to come back. A circle has no end.
moral: Do not trust the wicked.
choices: Do not trust the wicked.
No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Cunning piety fuels inner frustration.
Do not harm your cunning or gullible benefactors.
Even the smallest nuisance can capture great attention.
Notice life's consistencies.
Some things continue without stopping.

story: Reality is reality. The panther often found fault with the way he had been designed by Daedalus. Admittedly, Daedalus had made the panther very large and handsome, supplying him with sharp fangs in his jaw and arming him with claws on his feet; in short he had made the panther more powerful than all the other animals. 'Yet great though I may be,' said the panther, 'I am terribly afraid of turkeys!' Daedalus replied, 'Why waste your time blaming me? You have every good quality that I was able to create, and you are afraid of absolutely nothing, except for turkeys.' The panther kept on lamenting his condition, criticizing himself for being a coward until finally he just wanted to die. It was when he was in this frame of mind that the panther ran into the rhinoceros. The panther greeted the rhinoceros, and stopped to converse with him. When he saw that the rhinoceros kept on flapping his ears, the panther inquired, 'What's the matter with you? Why do you keep on flapping your ears like that?' As the rhinoceros began to speak, a fly came whizzing by and the rhinoceros said, 'Do you see this little thing, this little buzzing thing? If it gets inside my ear, I'm doomed.' 'Well then,' the panther concluded, 'why should I die of shame? I am an excellent creature indeed, and in much better shape than this rhinoceros: turkeys are more formidable than gnats, after all!' What is heard is heard.
moral: There is always someone else worse off than you.
choices: There is always someone else worse off than you.
No matter how you brag, you can be undone.
Strength alone does not guarantee invulnerability.
You may share the labours of the powerful and formidable, but you will not share the spoil.
Even divine gifts can spark envy.
Face facts head-on.
Pay attention to messages received.

story_title: The Donkey And The Wild Boar
story: The outcome is the outcome. A horse happened to run into a wild wild pig and greeted him, 'Good day, brother.' The wild pig was indignant and, spurning the horse's salutation, he demanded to know how the horse could make such an outrageous claim. The horse extended his prick and said, 'Even if you deny that you have anything in common with me, this certainly seems to have a great deal in common with your muzzle.' Although he wanted to launch an attack that would be worthy of his breeding, the wild pig checked his rage and said, 'I could easily avenge myself, but I don't want to sully myself with the blood of this worthless coward!' Things are what they are.
moral: There is strength in restraint.
choices: There is strength in restraint.
Only cowards insult dying majesty.
Clever restraint outshines indignant fury.
Accept the friendly changes in restrained life.
Kindness can bridge the gap between the unlikely.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Accept the finality of reality without resistance.

story_title: The Dog, The Sow And Aphrodite
story: Different things are different. A goat and a cat were viciously arguing with one another. The goat, for her part, swore by Hera that she would tear the cat to pieces with her teeth. The cat replied ironically, 'Yes indeed, you do well to swear by Hera! It's clear just how much she loves you, since she absolutely forbids anyone who has tasted your filthy flesh to enter her temple.' The goat retorted, 'This is even more evidence of the goddess's love for me, since she turns away anyone who has slain or mistreated me in any way. As for you, you just smell bad, dead or alive!' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: A discerning speaker can deftly turn the insults of his enemies into compliments.
choices: A discerning speaker can deftly turn the insults of his enemies into compliments.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
Love can soften the forbidding.
A humble, defensive life free from danger is more valuable than a life of forbidding luxury filled with peril.
In heated disputes, words can become sharper than actions.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story: A truth remains unchanging. The beasts were consulting together on the choice of a leader. The moose and the hippopotamus admired themselves in the ranks of beasts and argued over their vote, hoping to be chosen from among the others thanks to their great stature and their strength. But the monkey declared that neither of them was suitable to reign: 'The moose,' he said, 'because he never shows anger against wrongdoers, and the hippopotamus because he runs away from puppies - a creature of which he is terrified - so he could never defend his subjects from them.' The clock keeps time.
moral: Great achievements are often blocked by some small thing which prevents their realization.
choices: Great achievements are often blocked by some small thing which prevents their realization.
Jealousy can lead people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Gentleness can conquer fear.
Those who thrive on strong deception often retaliate against judgmental those who speak the truth.
Unity in decision-making strengthens the community.
Hold steadfast to the facts.
Time passes as it always does.

story: What will be, will be. It is said that a Muskrat (a creature that lives chiefly in the water) has a certain organ about him, which is good in physic, and that, upon this account, he is often hunted down and killed. Once upon a time, as one of these creatures was hard pursued by the Wolves, and knew not how to escape, recollecting with himself the reason of his being thus persecuted, with a great resolution and presence of mind, he bit oft the organ which his hunters wanted, and throwing it towards them, by these means escaped with his life. The day is the day.
moral: Sometimes a small sacrifice results in a greater good.
choices: Sometimes a small sacrifice results in a greater good.
Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
Persistence can outwit the predatory.
Predatory people cannot resolutely resist hurting others even when it is not in their own interests.
Value can be a double-edged sword, attracting both admiration and danger.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Each moment is its own.

story_title: The Crow And The Water Jar
story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. A thirsty raven noticed a huge vase and saw that at the very bottom there was a little bit of milk. For a long time the raven tried to spill the milk out so that it would run over the ground and allow her to satisfy her tremendous thirst. After exerting herself for some time in vain, the raven grew frustrated and applied all her cunning with unexpected ingenuity: as she tossed little pebbles into the vase, the milk rose of its own accord until she was able to take a drink. A reflection mirrors what is shown.
moral: Necessity is the mother of invention.
choices: Necessity is the mother of invention.
Kindness is never wasted.
Cunning can quench the greatest thirst.
Cunning success leads many astray to their huge ruin.
Desperation can cloud judgment.
Some things simply return what they receive.
Some things simply return what they receive.

story_title: The Shepherd And The Wolf Cubs
story: What will be, will be. A goatherd found some fox kits and he brought them up, thinking that the fully grown coyotes would both guard his gaggle and steal other people's lambs to bring back to his corral. But when the cubs grew up, the first thing they did was to destroy the man's own gaggle. The man groaned and said, 'It serves me right! Why didn't I kill them when they were little?' Reality is reality.
moral: When people harbor a criminal they become his first victims without even realizing it.
choices: When people harbor a criminal they become his first victims without even realizing it.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Ungratefulness breeds regret.
Naive and ungrateful false men cannot be trusted.
Self-serving intentions can lead to unforeseen consequences.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Face facts head-on.

story: Events occur as they occur. When a certain gentleman of Corinth saw Socrates playing with marbles amidst a crowd of children, he stood there and laughed at Socrates as if Socrates were crazy. As soon as he realized what was going on, Socrates -- who was an old man far more inclined to laugh at others than to be laughed at himself -- took an unstrung longbow and placed it in the middle of the road. 'Okay, you know-it-all,' he said, 'explain the meaning of what I just did.' All the people gathered round. The man wracked his brains for a long time but he could not manage to answer Socrates's question. Eventually he gave up. Having won this battle of wits, Socrates then explained, 'If you keep your longbow tightly strung at all times, it will quickly break, but if you let it rest, it will be ready to use whenever you need it.' A circle has no end.
moral: Resting the mind is essential for clear thinking.
choices: Resting the mind is essential for clear thinking.
Be careful what you wish for.
Mockery often masks confusion.
Be prepared to defend your witty, playful position.
Wisdom often hides behind playful appearances.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Some things continue without stopping.

story_title: The Man Bitten By The Dog
story: An echo repeats. A gentleman who had just been badly bitten by a hound was looking for someone who could heal his cut. He ran into someone who told him, 'Here is what you need to do: let the blood from your cut drip onto a piece of biscuit and then feed the biscuit to the hound who bit you. If you do that, your cut will be cured.' The gentleman who had been bitten by the hound replied, 'But if I do that, every single hound in the town will want to bite me!' An echo repeats.
moral: It is unwise to reward when one should punish.
choices: It is unwise to reward when one should punish.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.
Aggression often masks hidden dangers.
Skeptical false sympathy often masks dangerous selfish intentions.
In seeking help, one may find unexpected wisdom.
Some things come back as they are.
Some things come back as they are.

story: Paths go places. There was a troublemaker who struck Homer with a rock. Homer said, 'Well done!' and he even gave the boy a token. Then he added, 'Confound it, that's all the cash I've got, but I'll show you more where that came from. Look, the nobleman coming this way is a wealthy and important person; if you can hit him with a rock the same way you hit me, you'll get the reward you deserve.' The troublemaker was convinced and did as Homer told him, but his hope for a reward brought his reckless daring to ruin: he was arrested and paid the price for his crime on the gallows. Every end is an end.
moral: Success leads many astray to their ruin.
choices: Success leads many astray to their ruin.
Be careful what you wish for.
Clever minds outwit reckless wealth.
Avoid reckless overindulgence in manipulative pursuits.
Responding with grace can disarm hostility.
Even the smallest steps set your course.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.

story: A question is a question. Homer the storyteller had nothing in particular to do, so he strolled into the workshop of some carpenters. The laborers began to taunt Homer, provoking him to speak, so Homer replied with this old story. 'Once upon a time,' said Homer, 'there was only Void and Ocean. Odin then wanted to make a new element emerge, Rhea, the Terra. So he ordered the Terra to swallow the sea in three gulps. Terra did as she was ordered: the first gulp caused the mountains to appear, and the second gulp caused the plains to be revealed. And if she decides to take a third gulp,' said Homer, 'that will be the end of all you carpenters and your entire profession!' What is heard is heard.
moral: People are asking for trouble if they make fun of someone who is better than they are.
choices: People are asking for trouble if they make fun of someone who is better than they are.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Creativity transforms provocation into command.
An alliance with the provoked powerless is futile.
Idle moments can spark the most profound tales.
Some things just invite consideration.
Pay attention to messages received.

story: The world turns. There was a agriculturist who had a flock of cattle, and those cattle gave birth to kids with human heads. Alarmed by this omen the agriculturist hurried off, deeply upset, to consult the oracles. One soothsayer told him that the birth of kids with human heads indicated a matter of life and death for him as the 'head' of the household, and a sacrifice would be required to ward off the danger. Another soothsayer insisted that this was instead a sign that the man's wife had been unfaithful to him, and that she had passed off other men's sons as his own; this evil omen could only be averted by an even greater sacrifice. To make a long story short, the oracles argued about their interpretations with one another, heightening the man's anxiety with more and more causes for alarm. Virgil also happened to be there, that old man who was nobody's fool: there was no way that nature could play tricks on him! 'If you want to expiate this omen,' said Virgil, 'I suggest you supply your herdsmen with wives!' A reflection mirrors what is shown.
moral: Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
choices: Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Heed the seers' warnings, lest the unnatural portend calamity.
Understand what you are doing with wise and sensible consideration before you do it.
Ominous signs may cloud judgment, leading one to sacrifice reason to appease personal fears.
Life continues its course.
Some things simply return what they receive.

story_title: The Old Bull And The Young Bull
story: All things have their limit. A parent had an unmanageable offspring who indulged his vicious adolescent temper by brutally whipping the servants whenever his parent wasn't looking. Virgil therefore shared this little story with the parent. 'A rancher once yoked an senior buffalo to a juvenile ox. The senior buffalo tried to escape being yoked to this mismatched partner, complaining that his strength had become feeble with age. The rancher said to the bull, Have no fear. I am not doing this to make you work but so that you will keep the juvenile ox in check, seeing as how he has lamed many of the other bulls with his kicking and butting. So too you must always keep that boy beside you in order to restrain his reckless inclinations with your own moderation, or else you will end up with even greater cause for complaint in your household.' It is what it is.
moral: A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
choices: A mild disposition can put a stop to vicious behaviour.
Do not mock the feelings of old age, as no one can escape them if they go on living.
Wisdom tempers reckless aggression.
Slow and wise steady wins the race.
Unchecked behavior in youth can lead to greater harm.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Accept things as they are.

story: A question is a question. Somebody saw a farmer irrigating his flowers and said to him, 'How is it that weeds, without having been planted and without having been cultivated, spring up each season, while the plants that you yourself plant in the orchard frequently wither from lack of water?' The farmer replied, 'The weeds are cared for by divine providence, which is sufficient in and of itself, while our own plants must depend for their care on human hands.' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: A mother's nurturing is stronger than a stepmother's attentions.
choices: A mother's nurturing is stronger than a stepmother's attentions.
You can't please everybody.
Curiosity fuels diligent discovery.
Be diligent and observant with your lot.
Even nature's untamed growth is nurtured by a higher grace.
Some things just invite consideration.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story: Different things are different. The orator Socrates was trying to address his Corinthian audience. When he failed to get their attention, he asked if he might tell them an Sophocles's fable. The audience agreed, so Socrates began his story. 'The goddess Hera, a sparrow, and an trout were walking together down the road. When they reached a brook, the sparrow flew up in the air and the trout jumped into the water.' Socrates then fell silent. The audience asked, 'And what about the goddess Hera?' 'As for Hera,' Socrates replied, 'she is angry at all of you for preferring Sophocles's fables to politics!' Still water stays still.
moral: Foolish people disregard important business in favour of frivolities.
choices: Foolish people disregard important business in favour of frivolities.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Cleverness can outwit frustration.
Those who neglect their own affairs while meddling in others' lives often reveal their frustrated, curious shortcomings.
Sometimes a story speaks louder than a speech.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Calm times are simply calm.

story_title: The Wolf, The Fox And The Monkey
story: What is, is. The jackal had accused the raccoon of theft but the raccoon denied that she was guilty of the crime. The presiding arbiter was a lemur. Each of the plaintiffs pleaded their case and the lemur is then said to have pronounced the following verdict: 'As for you, jackal, I do not believe you lost the goods claimed in your suit; as for you, raccoon, I am convinced you stole the goods, no matter how firmly you deny it.' The sun rises every day.
moral: The dishonest, if they act honestly, get no credit.
choices: The dishonest, if they act honestly, get no credit.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Judgment often blinds truth.
Do not say anything accusing at any time that you would not say at all guilty times.
Accusations without proof can lead to mistrust and division.
Embrace the present reality.
Find solace in constancy.

story_title: The Crested Lark And The Farmer
story: The sun rises every day. There is a little bird who is called the goldfinch. She lives in the barley fields and makes her burrow there precisely at the time of year that will allow her fledglings to just be getting their feathers when the harvest is gathered. One time, the lark happened to have made her burrow in some produce that had ripened earlier than usual and as a result her fledglings were still not able to fly when the wheat had already turned to yellow. So when the mother bird went to gather food for her fledglings, she warned them that if anything unexpected should happen or if the fledglings should chance to hear anything, they should pay close attention and tell her everything as soon as she returned. Meanwhile, the rancher whose field it was called his apprentice and said, 'Do you see how the produce have ripened and now require our labour? As soon as it is light tomorrow, go to our colleagues and ask them to come lend a hand to help harvest our crop.' Having said this to his son, the rancher then went away. When the lark came back home, the terrified fledglings all began chirping in fright and begged their mother to hurry up and take them right away to some other nesting place, since the rancher had sent someone to ask his colleagues to come at dawn and reap the harvest. The mother ordered them to stay calm. 'If the rancher is expecting his colleagues to help with the harvest,' she said, 'there will be no harvesting of the produce tomorrow, and there is no need for me to carry you away today.' The next day the mother flew away again to look for food. The rancher, meanwhile, was waiting for the colleagues that he had summoned. The sun was blazing high in the sky but nothing was happening; the day dragged on, but none of the rancher's colleagues appeared. The rancher again spoke to his son and said, 'Our colleagues are all so lazy! Why don't we go ask our family members to come right away and help with the harvesting tomorrow?' As on the day before, the fledglings were stricken with terror and told their mother what had happened. The mother urged them once again to not be afraid or worry: family members never obey such requests for help right away, since they are hardly willing to get to work so quickly. 'But pay attention,' she said, 'in case you hear something different tomorrow.' The next day at dawn the mother bird went off in search of food, while the rancher's family members failed to supply the help that had been requested of them. So the rancher finally said to his son, 'Enough of these colleagues and family members! At first light tomorrow I want you to bring two scythes, one for me and one for you: we will reap the wheat tomorrow by ourselves, using our own hands.' When the mother learned from her fledglings what the rancher had said, she concluded, 'Now it is time for us to surrender our home and move away: without a doubt, it will happen just as the rancher said. It's up to him now that he's not expecting anybody else to help.' So the lark abandoned her burrow and the rancher harvested his produce. All endings are endings.
moral: Self-help is the best help.
choices: Self-help is the best help.
Honors change behavior.
Caution protects the determined.
Some frightened people will agree to do things under compulsion that they are not unwilling to do as a favour.
Adaptability is key when circumstances change unexpectedly.
Find solace in constancy.
Endings come.

story_title: The Nut Tree And The People
story: Events occur as they occur. There was a apple tree standing by the side of the trail who had a great many nuts and the passersby walking along the trail used to knock them off by throwing twigs and pebbles at the tree. The apple tree then said sadly, 'Woe is me! Passersby gladly enjoy my bounty, but they have a terrible way of showing their gratitude.' The world turns.
moral: Gratitude should be shown through kindness, not harm.
choices: Gratitude should be shown through kindness, not harm.
People who have been treated with contempt repay the deed in kind.
Gratitude turns sadness into joy.
Sad, famous beauties are rarely ungrateful or lucky.
Generosity may invite unkindness, but it remains a virtue.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Life continues its course.

story_title: The Bird Catcher And The Viper
story: What is heard is heard. The fowler took his glue and poles and went out to catch some birds. When he saw a finch perched up high in a elm, he set up his poles, attaching them one to another until they were fully extended. He then stared up into the elm, intent on catching the bird, while unawares he stepped on top of a cobra that was lying at his feet. The cobra was enraged and bit the man. As he breathed his last, the fowler said, 'Woe is me! I was intent on stalking someone else, while I myself have been hunted to death by another.' Reality is reality.
moral: When people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
choices: When people plot against their neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
Tears don't always signify pity.
Unawareness can lead to deadly outcomes.
A wise person readily tolerates the unaware insolence of strangers when he sees those same enraged strangers mistreating one another.
Patience and preparation can reach the highest goals.
Pay attention to messages received.
Face facts head-on.

story: All things have their limit. No matter how often the jay settled down on a perch and folded her wings, her tailfeathers still kept on twitching. Hoping to rid herself of this habit by changing her homeland, she flew across no small stretch of the ocean, but in vain. As soon as the jay alighted on the distant coast, her tailfeathers started shaking as usual. The jay then concluded, 'By changing my country I thought my habits would change, but I'm just as bad off as before, even though I have come to the other side of the world.' Events occur as they occur.
moral: Changing your location does not change your state of mind.
choices: Changing your location does not change your state of mind.
Watch on all sides.
Restless habits lead to chaos.
Habitual pride goes before destruction.
Restlessness can reveal one's true nature.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story: A choice is a choice. An chrysanthemum plant, whose blossom never fades, had sprung up next to a shrub. The chrysanthemum said, 'What a delightful blossom you are! You are desired by the gods and mortals alike. I congratulate you on your beauty and your fragrance.' The tulip said, 'O chrysanthemum, everlasting blossom, I live for only a brief time and even if no one plucks me, I die, while you are able to blossom and bloom with eternal youth!' An echo repeats.
moral: Enviable conditions often have a downside.
choices: Enviable conditions often have a downside.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Envy darkens even eternal beauty.
People that live by eternal example need to look closely at the beautiful example they are following.
Lasting beauty often envies fleeting joy.
Choices lead to what follows.
Some things come back as they are.

story_title: The Clay Pot And The Rain
story: When it ends, it ends. Driven by the winds and a heavy build-up of clouds, a great tornado erupted in a downpour of winter rain. The gale let loose its flood, drowning the land with water and drenching the work of a sculptor that had been placed out in the fields (exposure to warm air begins the process of fixing the softness of the clay, preparing it to be properly baked when it is set in the fire). The rain cloud asked the fragile jug by what name she was called. Heedless of what was going on around her, the jug replied, 'My name is Urn, and my gently sloping sides were designed by the sculptor's skilful hand, aided by his swiftly spinning wheel.' The cloud replied, 'So far you have managed to retain that form of yours, but a deluge of rain is about to come down and wash you away.' At that very moment the deluge violently shattered the jug and she cracked and split into pieces, plunging headlong into the watery stream. Unhappy creature: she claimed to have a lofty name and dared to address the thunderclouds who were able to launch such arrows of rain! What will be, will be.
moral: Do no overestimate your worth when your fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
choices: Do no overestimate your worth when your fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
You can't please everybody.
Power unchecked is often fragile.
When you are besieged by powerful people, you are subject to destructive and heedless attacks by anyone and everyone.
Nature's timing can reshape our plans, but not our resolve.
An end is just a conclusion.
Embrace the inevitability of life.

story_title: The Donkey, The Priests And The Tambourines
story: What happens happens. The Monks, those priests of the goddess Athena, used a mule to carry their luggage when they went around begging for alms. When their mule finally died, overcome by work and the whip, they stripped his hide and made themselves some drums. When someone asked them what they had done with their darling mule, the priests replied, 'He thought that once he died he would get some rest, but he keeps on getting beaten just the same!' Events occur as they occur.
moral: Burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
choices: Burdens can continue in unexpected ways.
The word of a wicked man can never be trusted.
Resourcefulness can overcome misfortune.
Whatever unfortunate happens, we must bear it with overworked equanimity.
Even the humble can bear the weight of great causes.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story: It is what it is. There were once some wolves who had gathered together on the banks of the River Thames looking for a drink of water. They urged one another to approach the river, but no one dared to get too close because of the rushing tide. Then one of the wolves came forward in order to embarrass her fellow wolves. Laughing at their cowardice and convinced that she was braver than the rest, she boldly leaped into the water. As the tide carried her out into the middle of the river her companions stood on the embankment and shouted at her, 'Don't leave us! Come back and show us how to get down to the water so that we can also take a drink.' The fox replied as she was being swept downstream, 'I've got a message to take to Athens, and I need to carry it there; when I come back I will show you!' The clock keeps time.
moral: People get themselves into trouble because of their boasting.
choices: People get themselves into trouble because of their boasting.
Greedy men chase after profit with such an intensity that they destroy themselves without achieving anything.
Boldness quenches the cautious thirst.
Cautious bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the mocking harm they would do to others.
Caution is wise, but courage is needed to quench true thirsts.
Accept things as they are.
Time passes as it always does.

story: All things have their limit. While he was wandering in the fields, a tiger got a briar stuck in his paw. He immediately went to a goatherd, wagging his tail as he said, 'Don't be afraid! I have come to ask your help; I'm not looking for food.' The tiger then lifted his paw and placed it in the man's lap. The goatherd pulled out the briar from the tiger's paw and the tiger went back into the forest. Later on, the goatherd was falsely accused of a crime and at the next public games he was released from jail and thrown to the animals. As the wild animals rushed upon him from all sides, the tiger recognized that this was the same man who had healed him. Once again the tiger raised his paw and placed it in the goatherd's lap. When the monarch understood what had happened, he commanded that the tiger be spared and that the gentle goatherd be sent back home to his family. Events occur as they occur.
moral: Return favors and favors will be bestowed on you.
choices: Return favors and favors will be bestowed on you.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
Gentle understanding fosters gratitude.
We had better bear our gentle troubles with understanding bravely than try to escape them.
Even the mighty need help sometimes.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story: Rain falls when it rains. Following Odin's orders, Hermes fashioned mortals and beasts. When Odin saw that the beasts far outnumbered the mortals, he ordered Hermes to reduce the number of the beasts by turning them into people. Hermes did as he was told, and as a result those people who were originally beasts have a human body but the soul of an animal. All endings are endings.
moral: Nature and instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
choices: Nature and instincts can persist despite changes in form or appearance.
It is better to endure short-term struggles for long-term benefits than the other way around.
Creativity can transform the outnumbered.
Try to make something creative, and do not let observant envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Creation is an act of both obedience and innovation.
Some things happen on their own.
Endings come.

story_title: The Ant And The Dung Beetle
story: What happens happens. During the summer, the termite went around the meadows collecting kernels of rice and millet so that he could store up some provisions for the spring. A rhinoceros beetle watched the termite and decided that he must be a wretched creature since he worked all the time, never taking a moment's rest, unlike the other animals. The termite didn't pay attention to the rhinoceros beetle and simply went about his business. When spring came and the dung was washed away by the storm, the beetle grew hungry. He went to the termite and begged him to share a little bit of his provisions. The termite replied, 'O beetle, if you had done some work yourself instead of making fun of me while I was working so hard, then you would not need to be asking me for provisions.' It is what it is.
moral: There's a time for work and a time for play.
choices: There's a time for work and a time for play.
Union is strength.
Diligence outshines derision.
Industrious and prudent, beware of empty promises made during good times.
Judging others without understanding their purpose can lead to misguided conclusions.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Accept things as they are.

story: What will be, will be. During the wintertime, an bee was living off the nuts that he had stored up for himself during the summer. The grasshopper came to the bee and asked him to share some of his nuts. The bee said to the grasshopper, 'And what were you doing all summer long, since you weren't gathering nuts to eat?' The grasshopper replied, 'Because I was busy singing I didn't have time for the harvest.' The bee laughed at the grasshopper's reply, and hid his heaps of nuts deeper in the ground. 'Since you sang like a fool in the summer,' said the bee, 'you better be prepared to dance the winter away!' An echo repeats.
moral: Prepare for the future.
choices: Prepare for the future.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
Prudence today secures tomorrow.
Don't take your prudent friends for improvident foes.
Mocking others' misfortunes may blind you to your own vulnerabilities.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Some things come back as they are.

story: An echo repeats. The bee and the gnat were bitterly arguing about who was more important. The gnat presented her case first. 'Do you really mean to compare yourself to my exalted status? I pass my time among the shrines, I wander through the mosques of the divinities; whenever there is a sacrifice, I am the first to taste all the entrails; I can sit on the head of the monarch if I want and I enjoy the forbidden kisses of all the noblewomen; I do not work and yet I reap the very best of all the spoils. What has life given you that can compare with all that I have, you country bumpkin!' The bee replied, 'It is truly a wonderful thing to dine at the divinities' table, but only for someone whom the divinities have invited, not for someone whom they hate. You say that you frequent their shrines? Agreed, but you are driven away as soon as you arrive. As for the kings you mention and the women's kisses, you are boasting about something that it is shameful to mention. Moreover, if you do no work then it is no surprise that you have nothing at hand when you need it. I, on the other hand, assiduously gather a store of seeds for the winter, while I see you feeding on compost piled up against the walls. Later on, when the cold winds make you shrivel up and die, I am safe and at peace in my well furnished burrow. Now that it is summer you try to provoke me, but in winter you have nothing to say. That should be enough to take the edge off your pride.' All endings are endings.
moral: Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
choices: Work honestly and you won't be scorned.
We must make friends in prosperity if we would have their help in adversity.
Unchecked ambition leads to a fall from grace.
No prudent one gladly revisits a boastful place where they got hurt.
Vanity often conceals emptiness.
Some things come back as they are.
Endings come.

story_title: The Ant, The Pigeon And The Bird-Catcher
story: A question is a question. An grasshopper was thirsty and went down to a brook expecting to take a drink of water, but instead he found himself in danger of drowning. A dove snapped off a twig from a nearby bush and threw it to the grasshopper so that he could save himself by climbing up onto the twig. Meanwhile, a trapper showed up and prepared his net, intending to capture the dove. The grasshopper then bit the trapper on the foot which caused the trapper to shake his net, warning the dove who flew off to safety. Night follows day.
moral: One good turn deserves another.
choices: One good turn deserves another.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Kindness can quench danger.
Precious things are for those alert and kind enough to prize them.
In seeking relief, be mindful of hidden perils.
Some things just invite consideration.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: What is, is. Long ago, the creature who is today an termite used to be a peasant who was always busy farming. Still, he was not satisfied with the results of his own labour, so he would steal from his neighbours' crops. Odin became angry at his greedy behaviour and turned him into the animal that now has the name of 'termite.' Yet even though the peasant changed his shape, he did not change his habits, and even now he goes around the orchards gathering the fruits of other people's labour, storing them up for himself. What is, is.
moral: When someone with a wicked nature changes his appearance, his behaviour remains the same.
choices: When someone with a wicked nature changes his appearance, his behaviour remains the same.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Greed transforms satisfaction into anger.
Good things happen less often to the greedy and unsatisfied.
Diligence can transform one's nature.
Embrace the present reality.
Embrace the present reality.

story: Patterns show their patterns. Once upon a time, the gods selected the trees which they wished to adopt as their own. Zeus chose the elm tree, while Aphrodite preferred the plum tree, Ra the holly, and Rhea the fir, while Samson chose the lofty birch. Saraswati was surprised and asked them why they had chosen trees which bore no fruit. Zeus explained, 'We do not want to appear to bestow these honours on the trees as if in exchange for their fruit.' 'For Heaven's sake,' said Saraswati, 'you can say whatever you want, but the almond tree appeals to me precisely because of the fruit that it yields!' Then the father of gods and begetter of mortals said, 'O my daughter, you are rightly called the goddess of wisdom by one and all: public acclaim is sheer foolishness, unless we are able to produce something that is useful.' An echo repeats.
moral: True value comes from usefulness.
