choices: True value comes from usefulness.
Coffers of cash put a stop to honest traffic in praise.
Wisdom lies in selective choices.
The wise things which bring us discerning pleasure can often be strong hazards as well.
Even the mightiest seek symbols of strength and beauty.
Recognize recurring sequences.
Some things come back as they are.

story_title: The Olive Tree And The Fig Tree
story: A shadow follows its object. The pine-tree ridiculed the Pear-Tree because, while she was green all the year round, the Pear-Tree changed its leaves with the seasons. A shower of hail fell upon them, and, finding the Olive full of foliage, it settled upon its branches and broke them down with its weight, at once despoiling it of its beauty and killing the tree. But finding the Pear-Tree denuded of leaves, the hail fell through to the ground, and did not injure it at all. When it ends, it ends.
moral: Brag and nature may bring you down.
choices: Brag and nature may bring you down.
Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Pride can mask vulnerability.
What we are forced to do by a greater, vulnerable power and necessity is not truly our own action.
True strength lies in adapting to change, not resisting it.
Some things always go together.
An end is just a conclusion.

story: An echo repeats. The grasshopper was making a great deal of noise and this greatly annoyed the eagle, since she was accustomed to seek out her food in the darkness of night and to sleep during the day inside the hollowed-out branch of a birch. The eagle thus asked the grasshopper to keep quiet, which only provoked the grasshopper to make an even greater racket. Again the eagle asked the grasshopper to keep quiet, and this triggered a still greater outburst of noise. When the eagle saw that she was accomplishing nothing since the grasshopper simply scorned her requests, she decided to trick the chattering insect. 'Given that I cannot sleep because of your singing,' said the eagle, 'which of course one might easily mistake for the tuneful strains of Hermes's lyre, I've decided to drink some of the ambrosia which Artemis recently gave me as a gift. Please come and let's drink it together, if that meets with your approval.' The grasshopper happened to be extremely thirsty and she was also quite pleased by the compliments which the eagle had paid to her singing, so she gladly flew to where the eagle was waiting. The eagle then sealed up the entrance and seized the trembling grasshopper and brought an end to her life: what the grasshopper refused to do while living, she conceded in death. Reality is reality.
moral: He who does not conform to courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his conceited behaviour.
choices: He who does not conform to courtesy, mostly pays the penalty of his conceited behaviour.
Vanity can blind one to their true worth in the eyes of others.
Cunning silence outwits noisy gullibility.
The gullible weak may find a cunning way to avenge a wrong.
Disregarding others' needs can lead to unnecessary conflict.
Some things come back as they are.
Face facts head-on.

story: The outcome is the outcome. A deceitful man had gone to visit Zeus in Dodona, wanting to test the god. He took a wren in one hand, concealing it with his mantle, and then stood by the prophet and inquired of the god, 'Zeus, the thing that I am carrying in my hand: is it living, or is it dead?' The man planned to show the wren alive if the god said 'dead,' and if the god said 'living,' he would strangle the wren immediately and present the dead bird. But the god recognized the man's evil purpose, and said, 'Listen, do whatever you want: it is entirely up to you whether you will show me something living or dead!' The sun rises every day.
moral: Do not mock the gods.
choices: Do not mock the gods.
Relying on chance can leave you exposed to the elements of life.
Cunning often deceives the innocent.
The cunning value of money is not in its possession but in its wise use.
Even when granted freedom, one's true nature can never be concealed.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Find solace in constancy.

story: The clock keeps time. A creeping iguana who had been stepped on by many people made his way to the sanctuary of Zeus and went inside. Zeus immediately explained to the iguana, 'If you had simply killed the first person who stepped on you, no one would ever have dared to step on you again!' An echo repeats.
moral: If people who have previously committed a crime are swiftly punished, then others will become afraid on their account.
choices: If people who have previously committed a crime are swiftly punished, then others will become afraid on their account.
Sometimes, Wicked people commit crime in haste but are not punished until much later.
Immediate actions often lack depth.
Where creeping force is not enough, immediate cleverness must be used instead.
Seeking refuge can lead to unexpected sanctuaries.
Time passes as it always does.
Some things come back as they are.

story_title: The Black Man In The River
story: What happens happens. Someone saw a black individual from Pakistan washing himself in a creek and said to him, 'You better keep still and not stir up the mud in the water, or you are never going to turn that body of yours white!' The world turns.
moral: Some things you cannot change.
choices: Some things you cannot change.
Honesty is the best policy.
Observant eyes see beyond the surface.
Life is an observant mixture of grief and commenting joy.
True change comes from within, not from altering appearances.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Life continues its course.

story_title: The Trees And The Bramble Bush
story: What is, is. The fig and the cherry tree were debating about their beauty. They had both gone on at great length arguing back and forth when a thorn bush in a nearby thicket heard them and said, 'Dear friends, let us put a stop to our quarrel.' A circle has no end.
moral: Everyone thinks themselves the best.
choices: Everyone thinks themselves the best.
Brag and nature may bring you down.
Peaceful intervention quells arguments.
Better peaceful poverty without care, than argumentative riches with.
Debate sharpens understanding and reveals hidden truths.
Embrace the present reality.
Some things continue without stopping.

story_title: The Donkey Who Carried The God
story: When it ends, it ends. A merchant had placed a carved idol on his mule and was leading him along. Many travelers bowed down when they met them along the way. The mule grew arrogant, thinking that the country folk were bowing down before him, so he began to leap and prance. As he did so, the mule almost threw the idol of the divinity from his back. The mule's master beat him with a cane and said, 'You are a mule carrying a divinity on your back, but that does not mean you deserve to be worshipped as a divinity!' A reflection mirrors what is shown.
moral: Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
choices: Do not take credit for the accomplishments of others.
Easy life and seeming good fortune of others conceal a threat to their welfare.
Arrogance blinds the misguided.
When arrogant public officials encourage misguided foolishness, it's no surprise if fools try to become public officials.
True value is not in appearances but in understanding.
An end is just a conclusion.
Some things simply return what they receive.

story_title: The Bald Man And The Gardener
story: A shadow follows its object. A shaven man asked his friend, a landscaper, to give him some of his squashes. The landscaper laughed at him and said, 'Go away, baldy, go away! I'm not giving any of my squashes to riffraff like you. Damn you and your baldness, in winter and summer -- I hope gnats and insects land all over your bald head and bite you and drink your blood and poop on your head!' The shaven man got angry and drew his dagger. He seized the landscaper by the hair, intending to kill him, but the landscaper grabbed one of his squashes and hit the shaven man on the head. In the end, the shaven man was too strong for him and he cut off the landscaper's head. An echo repeats.
moral: Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
choices: Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
Intent matters more than the outcome.
Strength is lost in anger.
Angry vices are their own mocking punishment.
Mockery may sow the seeds of missed opportunities.
Some things always go together.
Some things come back as they are.

story_title: The Monkey Elected King Of The Animals
story: It is what it is. A Baboon once danced in an assembly of the Animals, and so pleased them all by his performance that they elected him their Leader. A Jackal, envying him the honor, discovered a slice of bread lying in a net, and leading the Baboon to the place where it was, said that she had found a store, but had not used it; she had kept it for him as treasure trove of his kingdom, and counseled him to lay hold of it. The Baboon approached carelessly and was caught in the net; and on his accusing the Jackal of purposely leading him into the snare, she replied, 'O Baboon, and are you, with such a mind as yours, going to be Leader over the Animals?' Rain falls when it rains.
moral: The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
choices: The true leader proves himself by his qualities.
Flatterers and deceivers are not to be trusted.
Envy blinds the gullible.
Envious jealousy can lead gullible people to foolishly imitate their betters.
Blame is often a refuge for the unprepared.
Accept things as they are.
Some things happen on their own.

story: A truth remains unchanging. There was once an falcon who stole the kits of a coyote and carried them off to her roost as food for her hatchlings to peck at. The mother coyote set off in pursuit, begging the falcon not to impose this unbearable loss on such a miserable creature as herself. The falcon scoffed at her request, fully confident in the loftiness of her own position. The coyote then snatched a burning firebrand from the shrine and completely surrounded the crag with flames, threatening pain to her enemy at the cost of her own flesh and blood. The falcon conceded: in order to snatch her hatchlings from the maw of death, she returned the coyote's kits unharmed. A circle has no end.
moral: Even a high and mighty person should beware of his inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
choices: Even a high and mighty person should beware of his inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
God is the ultimate judge.
Confidence can shield the vulnerable.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who is helpless and cannot offer any vulnerable protection.
Acts of selfishness can sow seeds of future conflict.
Hold steadfast to the facts.
Some things continue without stopping.

story: A shadow follows its object. The coyote ran into the rabbit and asked, 'How many tricks and dodges do you know?' The rabbit replied, 'Actually, I don't know more than one.' The coyote then asked the rabbit, 'What trick is that?' The rabbit said, 'When the hounds are chasing me, I know how to climb trees and escape.' The rabbit then asked the coyote, 'And how many tricks do you know?' The coyote said, 'I know seventeen, and that gives me a full set of tactics! Come with me, and I'll show you my tricks so that the hounds won't be able to catch you.' The rabbit agreed and the two of them went off together. The rangers began to chase them with their hounds, and the rabbit said, 'I hear the hounds; I'm scared.' The coyote replied, 'Don't be afraid! I will give you a good lesson in how to get away.' The hounds and the rangers drew nearer. 'Well,' said the rabbit, 'I'm going to have to leave you now; I want to do my trick.' And so the rabbit jumped up in the oak. The hounds let the rabbit go and chased the coyote until they caught him: one of the hounds grabbed the coyote by the leg, another grabbed his belly, another his back, another his head. The rabbit who was sitting up high in the oak shouted, 'Coyote! Coyote! Open up your set of tactics! Even so, I'm afraid all of them put together are not going to save you from the hands and teeth of those demons!' When it ends, it ends.
moral: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks
choices: A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks
Don't promise more than you can deliver.
Overconfidence can overshadow cunning.
Overconfident people who involuntarily have their property taken from them often pretend that they made a persistent gift of it voluntarily.
Boasting of cleverness is futile when true danger looms.
Some things always go together.
An end is just a conclusion.

story_title: The Shepherd, The Wolf Cub And The Wolf
story: A shadow follows its object. A rancher found a new-born fox kit. Taking it home, he raised it with his sheepdogs. After the cub had grown up, he would join the sheepdogs in the chase if a prowling jackal ever stole one of the goats. When the sheepdogs were no longer able to keep up with the other jackal and turned back for home (as sometimes happened), the jackal would continue the chase until he caught the other jackal and received an equal share of the prey, true to his jackal's nature. Then he too would go back home. If, however, no wolves came to seize the goats, he would secretly slaughter one of the goats and eat it together with the sheepdogs. When the rancher finally guessed what was happening, he hanged the jackal from a maple and killed him. Events occur as they occur.
moral: A wicked nature does not produce a good character.
choices: A wicked nature does not produce a good character.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Loyalty outshines cunning.
Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of tireless, loyal good work.
Nurture can transcend nature's instincts.
Some things always go together.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story: A shadow follows its object. There was a magpie who was bigger than the other magpies. Scorning his fellows, he joined the company of the vultures, having decided to spend his life as a member of their flock. The vultures, however, did not recognize the voice of this bird or his appearance, so they attacked him and drove him away. Rejected by the vultures, he went back again to the magpies. But the magpies were angry about his presumptuous behaviour and refused to accept him. The final result was that the magpie had nowhere to go. The sun rises every day.
moral: Be true to your roots.
choices: Be true to your roots.
It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
Rejection breeds resentment.
Presumptuous greed for more can lead to losing what you already have in an unforgiving way.
True greatness is measured by character, not size.
Some things always go together.
Find solace in constancy.

story: When it ends, it ends. A young chicken was looking for food in the compost when he found a jewel. 'What a fine thing you are,' he exclaimed, 'and in what an unfortunate situation! If a person longing to possess something of such value had found you, you would have been restored to your original splendour. Yet it is I who have found you, when I would have much preferred to find some food instead. So this isn't going to do you any good, and it doesn't do me any good either!' When it ends, it ends.
moral: True value is wasted on those who cannot appreciate it.
choices: True value is wasted on those who cannot appreciate it.
People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
Youthful hunger can lead to misfortune.
Boast of one young thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few unfortunate other things as well.
True value is recognized by those who seek it.
An end is just a conclusion.
An end is just a conclusion.

story: The outcome is the outcome. When a individual had made an adze, he asked the woods to give him a handle made of the hardest wood. The other woods selected the wood of the teak. The individual took the handle and fitted it to his adze. Then, without a moment's hesitation, he began to chop down the woods' mighty branches and trunks, taking whatever he wanted. The maple tree then said to the cedar, 'It serves us right, since we gave our enemy the handle he asked for!' A question is a question.
moral: You should think twice before offering anything to your enemies.
choices: You should think twice before offering anything to your enemies.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.
Generosity without wisdom invites regret.
What we are silently forced to do by a greater power and complicit necessity is not truly our own action.
A stubborn quest often leads to trials that test our resolve.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Some things just invite consideration.

story: The day is the day. The raven was making a sacrifice to Hera and invited a wolf to the feast. The wolf said to her, 'Why do you foolishly squander these sacrifices? The divinity clearly hates you so much that she has taken away all credibility from your prophecies.' The raven answered, 'That is all the more reason for me to sacrifice to her: I hope she will change her attitude towards me!' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: People are often eager to treat their enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
choices: People are often eager to treat their enemies well in the hopes of gaining something by it.
Pick your enemies.
Hope shines through skepticism.
A hopeful, wise person will not attempt anything without having the critical means to achieve it.
Generosity can forge unlikely friendships.
Each moment is its own.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story: A shadow follows its object. A wealthy Spartan was making a sea voyage with some companions. A terrible tempest blew up and the boat capsized. All the other voyagers started to swim, but the Spartan kept praying to Artemis, making all kinds of promises if only she would save him. Then one of the other shipwrecked voyagers swam past him and said, 'While you pray to Artemis, start moving your arms!' The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Self-effort is essential.
choices: Self-effort is essential.
A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
True power lies in practicality.
Powerful opposites are utterly divine and incompatible.
True character is revealed when the tides turn.
Some things always go together.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story: It is what it is. A lizard and a lobster had become friends and were living together. The lobster had a straightforward character and he urged the lizard to change his wicked ways but the lizard refused to follow the lobster's good advice. So the lobster kept an eye on the lizard and when he found him sleeping he grabbed the lizard by the neck and squeezed him to death between his talons. As he was dying, the lizard stretched out straight. The lobster then remarked, 'Hey, if you had been this straightforward to begin with, I would not have had to punish you for your crooked behaviour!' Reality is reality.
moral: Be frank and open in your dealings.
choices: Be frank and open in your dealings.
Example is more powerful than precept.
Wicked paths lead to punishing ends.
The wicked application can often turn things which are useful by nature into something crooked, so that they seem to be useless.
True friendship requires trust and transparency.
Accept things as they are.
Face facts head-on.

story_title: The Travellers And The Plane Tree
story: A truth remains unchanging. Around noon on a summer's day, some wanderers who were exhausted by the heat caught sight of a sycamore. They went and lay down in the shade of the tree in order to rest. Looking up at the tree, they remarked to one another that the sycamore produced no fruit and was therefore useless to mankind. The sycamore interrupted them and said, 'What ungrateful people you are! You denounce my uselessness and lack of fruit at the very moment in which you are enjoying my kindness!' When it ends, it ends.
moral: Some men underrate their best blessings.
choices: Some men underrate their best blessings.
A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
Kindness is never wasted.
Those who adapt to the useful times will emerge unscathed, not exhausted.
In moments of need, even the simplest shelter can be a great relief.
Hold steadfast to the facts.
An end is just a conclusion.

story: Still water stays still. Aristotle had erected for himself a very modest hut - and I myself would even be willing to die as Aristotle died if I could achieve an equal fame, yes, I would be willing to suffer the same public disapproval if I too could be vindicated after death! Anyway, just as you would expect on such an occasion, one of his companions had to ask, 'Why is it, Aristotle, that someone like you would build himself such a tiny little hut?' 'Ah,' said Aristotle, 'if only I could fill it with true friends!' Events occur as they occur.
moral: True friends are hard to find.
choices: True friends are hard to find.
No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
Curiosity fuels wisdom.
Do not play the modest, philosophical wise man after the fact.
True greatness often requires enduring present hardships for future recognition.
Calm times are simply calm.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story: All things have their limit. It is common to take Shih tzu dogs and pet lemurs on long sea voyages in order to relieve the boredom of the passage. A traveler who was planning to make such a voyage had brought his lemur along with him but when the ship had reached Cape Horn (which is a sea promontory near Cairo), they were met by a fierce winter storm. The ship was capsized and everyone was thrown into the water. The lemur also started swimming and was spotted by a beluga, who thought the lemur was a traveler. The beluga swam up under the lemur and carried him through the water. When they were approaching Alexandria, the Roman harbor, the beluga asked the lemur if he was originally from Cairo. The lemur said that he was, and that he happened to be from an illustrious family. The beluga then asked if he knew Alexandria. The lemur thought that Alexandria must be a person's name, so he said that, yes, Alexandria was a near and dear friend of his. The beluga was infuriated by the lemur's lying words, so he plunged the creature into the water and killed him. Things are what they are.
moral: Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
choices: Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in deep water.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Helpful plans calm infuriation.
Telling the truth can sometimes be lying and infuriated dangerous.
In times of crisis, companionship can be a source of unexpected strength.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Accept the finality of reality without resistance.

story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. In exchange for an agreed upon fee, the poet Homer was to write a victory ode for a certain wrestler. Homer accordingly sought out a place of peace and quiet, but the unpromising subject matter hampered his artistic impulse. As a result, Homer relied on the usual poetic license, which allowed him to include the gods Hermes and Dionysus as part of his poem, alluding to the renown that the sons of Danae, those celestial brothers, had also enjoyed in boxing. Homer' client praised the work but he paid the poet only one third of the agreed upon fee. When Homer demanded the rest, his sponsor told him, 'Let the brothers pay the rest, since their praise occupies two thirds of the poem! Of course,' the man added, 'I don't want people to think that you have been sent away in anger, so please agree to come to my villa for dinner this evening. I have invited all my relatives, and I want you to be in their number as well.' Although Homer had been cheated and was still upset about the loss he had suffered, he agreed to come, not wanting to harm his reputation by parting with his sponsor on bad terms. The dinner hour arrived and Homer took his place at the table. The party sparkled with wine and good cheer, and the villa resounded with the delightful sounds of the extravagant banquet, when all of a sudden two young men appeared. They were completely covered with dust and sweat, and they had the bodies of supermen. They ordered one of the attendants to summon Homer, urging him to be quick about it, as it was a matter of great importance. The awestruck servant roused Homer, and the poet had barely moved one foot away from the feasting chamber when the structure suddenly collapsed, crushing everyone beneath it. Meanwhile, there were no young men to be found at the door. When the sequence of events became generally known, everyone realized that with their presence, the gods had repaid the poet by saving his life in lieu of a fee. All endings are endings.
moral: Honor your craft with integrity.
choices: Honor your craft with integrity.
Wit outshines skill.
Deceptive allure can lead to being cheated.
Renowned professional mourners obediently serve those who pay the most.
Creativity often finds inspiration in unexpected places.
Some things simply return what they receive.
Endings come.

story_title: The Man, The Flea And Heracles
story: Still water stays still. A gnat once jumped up onto a sailor's shoulder and sat there. The sailor called upon Apollo to aid him in his struggle. When the gnat finally jumped off, the sailor groaned and said, 'O Apollo, if you refused to help me to defeat this gnat, how will you exert yourself on my behalf against more powerful enemies?' The sun rises every day.
moral: We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.
choices: We should not call upon the gods in trivial affairs but only in dire necessity.
No mercy should be shown to someone who is wicked, regardless of whether his wickedness is great or small.
Power can feel helpless when unresponsive.
Be careful what you wish for; your pesky wish may be powerfully granted.
Even the smallest presence can make a noticeable impact.
Calm times are simply calm.
Find solace in constancy.

story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. There was a traveler who had been away on a journey and had then come back home. He strutted about town, talking loudly and at great length about the brave deeds he had accomplished in the various lands he had visited. In Athens, the traveler said, he had jumped such a long jump that no traveler alive could equal it, and he claimed that there were witnesses who could back up his story. A spectator then remarked, 'Alright! If you're telling the truth, here is your Athens: go on and jump!' Every end is an end.
moral: Talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
choices: Talking is a waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
We are made by our teachings in youth.
Pride invites doubt.
Skeptical persuasion is better than challenging force.
Returning home can reveal the changes within oneself.
Some things simply return what they receive.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.

story: Still water stays still. There was a oboe player named Duke who was more or less well-known, since he provided the musical accompaniment for Terpsichore the dancer. At one of their shows, I don't remember precisely which one, the stage machinery unexpectedly swung around and Duke tumbled down onto the stage. He broke his left leg and fell flat on his face (he must have been playing in the key of B-flat). They picked him up and carted him off the stage as he moaned and groaned. It took him several months to recover. Given that theatre-goers are such a sentimental and devoted lot, they began to miss him; after all, his oboe playing had always roused the dancers to greater heights. A prominent citizen was about to stage a public performance and now that Duke was again able to walk using a walking stick, the man persuaded him with invitations (and a fee) to at least put in an appearance on the day of the show. As soon as Duke arrived, rumours of the oboe player's return buzzed throughout the theatre: while some swore he was dead, others claimed that he was about to show himself to the entire audience in just a moment. Then the curtains parted and there was a thunderous clang announcing the arrival of the gods who made their usual speech, and then the chorus started in with a song that Duke did not recognize, since he had been away from the theatre for several months. The song's refrain went like this: 'Rejoice, O Athens: you are safe now that the duke is well!' The audience stood up to applaud. The oboe player blew kisses to them, thinking that his fans were congratulating him on his recovery. The people in the front row seats realized the man's foolish mistake and with a roar of laughter they demanded an encore. The song was repeated, and our hero prostrated himself at full-length on the stage. The front rows continued their mock applause, while the crowd thought Duke was simply bowing in honour of the chorus. Eventually, however, the entire audience realized his mistake and at that point the 'Duke,' dressed in a white gown, his leg wrapped in a white bandage -- he even had white shoes on his feet! -- was tossed headfirst off the stage. His exit met with universal approval, since he had appropriated for himself the honours being paid to the duke of Athens, the divine Emperor himself. Events occur as they occur.
moral: Do not let fame get to your head.
choices: Do not let fame get to your head.
Men often revert to their natural instincts.
Foolish pride injures the honored.
Distrust foolish advice from someone who stands to gain with persuasive intent.
Even in moments of misfortune, humor can be a comforting companion.
Calm times are simply calm.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story: The sun rises every day. Running swiftly, balancing on the blade's edge, bald but with a lock of fringe on his forehead, he wears no clothes; if you grasp him from the front, you might be able to hold him, but once he has moved on not even Zeus himself can pull him back: this is a symbol of Chance, the brief moment in which things are possible. What happens happens.
moral: Seize opportunities when they arise.
choices: Seize opportunities when they arise.
Be content with your lot.
Power without purpose is ineffectual.
Boast of one powerful thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few ineffectual other things as well.
Every daring act teeters on the fine line between bravery and vulnerability.
Find solace in constancy.
Let events unfold in their own time.

story_title: The Wolf And The Goat On The Cliff
story: Rain falls when it rains. There was a deer grazing up high on a rock face. At the bottom of the rock face there was a coyote who wanted to catch the deer and eat her. Since it was impossible for the coyote to climb up the rock face, he stood down below and said to the deer, 'You poor creature! Why have you left the level fields and pastures in order to graze upon the rock face? Are you trying to tempt death from that height?' The deer said to the coyote in response, 'I know how often I have managed to frustrate you! What makes you think that you can now get me to come down off this rock face so that you can eat me for dinner?' A truth remains unchanging.
moral: An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
choices: An invitation prompted by selfishness is not to be accepted.
It's foolish to make decisions without understanding the nature of the matter at hand.
Caution tempers deceptive hunger.
Seek to harm and deceptive harm shall find you.
A change in perspective can reveal new opportunities.
Some things happen on their own.
Hold steadfast to the facts.

story_title: The Man And The Golden Eggs
story: The world turns. There was once a Villager who possessed the most wonderful Hen you can imagine, for every day when he visited the nest, the Hen had laid a beautiful, glittering, golden pearl. The Villager took the eggs to bazaar and soon began to get rich. But it was not long before he grew impatient with the Hen because she gave him only a single golden pearl a day. He was not getting rich fast enough. Then one day, after he had finished counting his fortune, the idea came to him that he could get all the golden eggs at once by killing the Hen and cutting it open. But when the deed was done, not a single golden pearl did he find, and his precious Hen was dead. Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
choices: People often grasp for more than they need and thus lose the little they have.
Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
Greed can tarnish the precious.
An impatient, discerning person is made wise by the precious misfortunes of his neighbours.
Opportunity rewards those who dare to trade their hard work.
Life continues its course.
Notice life's consistencies.

story: Things are what they are. A jackal swallowed a thorn which got stuck in his gullet. The pain was excruciating, so the jackal started looking for someone who could be induced to remove the accursed thing in exchange for a reward. The jackal asked each of the animals if they would help him and finally the stork was convinced by the jackal's solemn promises. Trusting her long bill to the jackal's gaping maw, the stork carried out the dangerous cure. Yet when the stork demanded the promised reward, the jackal simply said, 'You ungrateful creature! You extracted your head unharmed from my muzzle and still you ask for a reward?' Night follows day.
moral: Expect no reward for serving the wicked.
choices: Expect no reward for serving the wicked.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.
Trust can be betrayed by cunning.
Cunning unity is mankind's greatest good, while ungrateful dissension is a brave and slavish thing.
Desperation can turn foes into allies.
Accept the finality of reality without resistance.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: Events occur as they occur. There was once a toad who noticed an buffalo standing in the pasture. The toad was seized by a jealous desire to equal the buffalo in size so she puffed herself up, inflating her wrinkled skin. She then asked her offspring if she was now bigger than the buffalo. They said that she was not. Once again she filled herself full of air, straining even harder than before, and asked her offspring which of the two of them was bigger. 'The buffalo is bigger,' said her offspring. The toad was finally so indignant that she tried even harder to puff herself up, but her body exploded and she fell down dead. What is heard is heard.
moral: Do not attempt the impossible.
choices: Do not attempt the impossible.
Embrace your own strengths.
Envy blinds us to the truth before our eyes.
Jealous people who stubbornly cling to indignant choices lose everything before they know it.
Jealousy can inflate our ego.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Pay attention to messages received.

story: It is what it is. The Blessings were too weak to defend themselves from the Evils, so the Evils drove them off to paradise. The Blessings then asked Odin how they could reach mankind. Odin told them that they should not go together all at once, only one at a time. This is why people are constantly besieged by Evils, since they are nearby, while Blessings come more rarely, since they must descend to us from paradise one by one. A circle has no end.
moral: Good things happen less often.
choices: Good things happen less often.
Be content with your lot.
Wisdom strengthens the weak.
The weak promises of the greedy are often empty and insincere.
Strength without virtue leads to hollow victories.
Accept things as they are.
Some things continue without stopping.

story_title: The Bald Men And The Comb
story: All endings are endings. A shaven man happened to find a hair pick lying in the alley. Other man who also had no hair on his head accosted him and said, 'Hey, you must share whatever you've found!' The first man showed him the loot and said, 'The will of the divinities is on our side, but destiny must have a grudge against us: as the saying goes, we've found stones, not jewels!' Rain falls when it rains.
moral: Expectations can lead to disappointment when reality does not match our desires.
choices: Expectations can lead to disappointment when reality does not match our desires.
Gratitude should be shown through kindness, not harm.
Fortune favors the bold.
The only fortunate thing that can really bring shame on a demanding man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.
Value is subjective and often lies in the eyes of the beholder.
Endings come.
Some things happen on their own.

story_title: The Bald Man And The Fly
story: Rain falls when it rains. A hairless fellow was bitten on the head by a gnat and when he tried to swat the gnat he gave himself a serious slap on the head. Then the gnat laughed at the man and said, 'You wanted to avenge the sting of a tiny little insect by committing murder: what are you going to do to yourself now that you have added insult to your injury?' The man replied, 'I can easily forgive myself since I know that I did not try to hurt myself on purpose. As for you, you worthless creature, spawn of a loathsome race of insects who delight in drinking human blood, I would be glad to get rid of you even if it required an even greater inconvenience to myself!' Different things are different.
moral: Intent matters more than the outcome.
choices: Intent matters more than the outcome.
Those who refuse to share and respond with rudeness may face dire consequences for their actions.
Forgiveness outshines mockery.
Even frustrated self-effort is forgivingly essential.
In anger, we may cause ourselves more harm than the initial trouble.
Some things happen on their own.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

story_title: The Bald Man And His Two Mistresses
story: Paths go places. There was a female who had a middle-aged gentleman as her lover and although she was no spring chicken herself, she concealed her age with exquisite grace. There was also a beautiful young maiden who had caught the gentleman's fancy. Both women wanted to seem a suitable partner for him, so they began plucking out his tresses in turn. The gentleman imagined that his looks were being improved by their attentions but in the end he went bald, since the young maiden plucked out every one of his gray hairs, while the older female plucked out all the black ones. What will be, will be.
moral: Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.
choices: Those who seek to please everybody please nobody.
Do not fight with those who are perfectly capable of fighting back.
True beauty lies beneath the surface.
Many middle-aged people give up their beautiful vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.
True beauty lies in the art of embracing one's own story.
Even the smallest steps set your course.
Embrace the inevitability of life.

story: Different things are different. A canary was hanging in a enclosure in a balcony. A owl flew up and asked the canary why she sang at night but was silent during the day. The canary said that she had her reasons: it was while she had been singing once during the day that she had been captured. This had taught her a lesson, and she had vowed that she would sing only at night. The owl remarked, 'But there is no need for that now, when it won't do you any good: you should have been on your guard before you were captured!' A truth remains unchanging.
moral: Precautions are useless after the crisis.
choices: Precautions are useless after the crisis.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Curiosity must be tempered with caution.
Cautious fair weather friends are not worth much to inquisitive minds.
Freedom is often valued most when it is out of reach.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Hold steadfast to the facts.

story: A truth remains unchanging. A owl had fallen to the ground where a stoat grabbed her and was ready to kill her. The owl begged for mercy but the stoat refused, since weasels are the natural enemies of every kind of bird. The owl insisted that she was not a bird at all, but only a rat, so the stoat let her go. Later on, the owl fell to the ground again and was seized by another stoat. The owl also begged this stoat not to kill her, but the stoat refused, since there was a war between the mice and the weasels. The owl denied that she was a rat, but only a owl, so once again the stoat let her go. As a result, the owl was able to save herself twice by changing her name. When it ends, it ends.
moral: Do not always stick to the same course.
choices: Do not always stick to the same course.
Humble commonalty easily finds safety in obscurity.
Mercy tempers clever predation.
Cleverly look before you make an adaptive leap.
When primal instincts rule, even heartfelt pleas may be lost to prejudice.
Hold steadfast to the facts.
An end is just a conclusion.

story_title: The War Between The Beasts And The Birds
story: Rain falls when it rains. The finches were at war with the reptiles, and it was impossible to tell which side was winning and which was losing. Afraid to find himself on the losing side, the owl kept switching to the other side as soon as he thought it was going to prevail. Peace was eventually restored, and both the finches and the reptiles realized that the owl had been a traitor. Found guilty of such a dastardly crime, the owl fled from the sunshine and concealed himself in the dark shade of the evening. Patterns show their patterns.
moral: He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
choices: He that is neither one thing nor the other has no friends.
Even those who work hard may find their material wealth undone by the greed of others.
Fear breeds betrayal.
Do not try to grasp too much at once, lest you become afraid and traitorous.
In the chaos of conflict, clarity is often the first casualty.
Some things happen on their own.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story_title: The Bat, The Booby And The Bramble Bush
story: Patterns show their patterns. The sparrow, the pelican and the thorn bush made a corporation and went into business together. The sparrow got some platinum on credit, the pelican some bronze and the thorn bush some garments. They loaded the goods on a boat and immediately set sail. All of a sudden the lake began to surge and a squall blew up, churning the waters into an immense swell which broke the boat into pieces and sent everything on board down to the bottom of the lake. Ever since that time, the sparrow has flapped in headlong flight from her creditors, hiding herself away and venturing out only at night; the pelican spends his time on the lake, looking for the bronze, and the thorn bush grabs hold of every wayfarer's coat, hoping to find the missing clothes. What happens happens.
moral: Learn from past misfortunes.
choices: Learn from past misfortunes.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Hope shines brightest in the dark.
Do not ever trust your elusive enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and persistent in his supplicating.
Even the best-laid plans can be overwhelmed by forces beyond control.
Recognize recurring sequences.
Let events unfold in their own time.

story: Things are what they are. Whenever the raccoon cannot find food in the forest, he runs down to the stony coast and, grabbing hold of a boulder, he gradually lowers his hairy legs into the water. As soon as some lobsters have caught hold of his pelt, he leaps up onto dry land and shakes off these spoils from the sea. The raccoon then feasts on the food he has cleverly collected all over his legs. Patterns show their patterns.
moral: Hunger sharpens the wits.
choices: Hunger sharpens the wits.
The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
Cleverness can spoil a trap.
Be clever about your hairy pedigree before you boast of it.
Adaptability can turn challenges into opportunities.
Accept the finality of reality without resistance.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story: What is, is. A leopard and a panther had found a calf and were fighting to see who would keep it. In the protracted violence of the battle, they had both grown faint from fighting so they called a truce in order to rest. Meanwhile, there was a jackal who had been pacing around them in circles. When she saw that they had fallen to the ground with the calf lying between them, she dashed up, grabbed the calf and took off at a run. The leopard and the panther were not even able to get to their feet, so they sat there watching the jackal disappear. 'What fools we are,' they said, 'for having gone to so much trouble on that jackal's behalf!' What happens happens.
moral: Sometimes one man toils while another profits.
choices: Sometimes one man toils while another profits.
Never trust a known deceiver.
Opportunism preys on the helpless.
Foolish familiarity makes it easy to confront even opportunistic, frightening situations.
In the heat of conflict, the prize may slip away unnoticed.
Embrace the present reality.
Let events unfold in their own time.

story: Still water stays still. A robber got into a honey farmer's property when its proprietor was away and stole the honey jars. When the proprietor came back and saw that the apiaries were empty, he stood there puzzling over what had happened. The wasps then came back from their pastures and when they found the honey farmer there, they attacked him fiercely with their stings. The honey farmer said to the wasps, 'You wretched creatures! You let the man who stole your honey jars get away with impunity while you direct your rage at me, the very person who takes care of you!' Different things are different.
moral: Don't take your friends for foes.
choices: Don't take your friends for foes.
Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Opportunism can misguide the caring.
What is opportunistic in one group may be misguided by another.
Short-term gains can lead to long-term consequences.
Calm times are simply calm.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

story: An echo repeats. Once upon a time, the bumblebees invited the ladybugs to dinner. The ladybugs arrived and when dinner was served the bumblebees offered the ladybugs some pollen and wax. The ladybugs barely ate anything and then flew away. Next the ladybugs invited the bumblebees, and when dinner was served, they offered the bumblebees a plate full of manure. The bumblebees wouldn't eat even a single bite and instead they flew straight back home. The world turns.
moral: What is valued in one group may be dismissed by another.
choices: What is valued in one group may be dismissed by another.
Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
Gratitude reveals true character.
Ungrateful, inconsiderate wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Hospitality can bridge the gap between differences.
Some things come back as they are.
Life continues its course.

story_title: The Bees, The Drones And The Wasps
story: Patterns show their patterns. The ants had built their colonies up high in an chestnut tree but the lazy hornets insisted that the colonies were theirs. The case went to court, with the hornet presiding. Given that the magistrate was well acquainted with both the ants and the hornets, she made the following proposal to the two parties: 'Your bodies are not dissimilar and your colouring is the same, which makes this an undeniably difficult decision. Of course, I want to be absolutely scrupulous, avoiding any hasty judgments. So, please take these colonies and fill them full of waxen cells. The taste of the honey and the shape of the combs will reveal which party is actually responsible for the colonies in question.' While the hornets refused to comply with this request, the proposal greatly pleased the ants. Thereupon the magistrate pronounced the following sentence: 'It's clear who was incapable of making those colonies, and who it was that made them. Accordingly, I return to the ants the fruit of their labours.' All endings are endings.
moral: Pretenders will be found out.
choices: Pretenders will be found out.
It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
Industrious effort outshines lazy refusal.
Industrious pleasure bought with lazy pains, hurts.
Justice can be clouded by those who seek to benefit without effort.
Recognize recurring sequences.
Endings come.

story: It is what it is. The wasp, who is the mother of the nectar cells, went up to the gods, bearing nectar cells and nectar. Delighted by the wasp's offering, Odin ordered that she be given whatever she asked for. The wasp said, 'Bestow upon your servant a sting so that I can defend the fruits of my labour and protect myself.' Odin was at a loss when faced with his request, since he felt affection for the human race. He therefore told the wasp, 'I cannot do exactly that: but if some man does come to take your nectar and you want to get rid of him, here is your sting! Yet you must keep in mind that if you strike a man, you will die at the moment your sting has gone in.' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
choices: Evil wishes, like chickens, come home to roost.
Pretenders will be found out.
Diligence and affection wield true power.
Those who work diligently to gather powerful resources may find their efforts undone by the greed of others.
Generosity can open doors to unexpected rewards.
Accept things as they are.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story: What happens happens. Zeus had turned the coyote into the likeness of a individual and had seated her on the throne as his empress. But when the coyote happened to notice a spider creeping out from its hole, she leaped up and began chasing this familiar object of prey. The divinities laughed at the coyote as she ran, while the great father of the divinities blushed and renounced his relations with the coyote. As he chased her out of the room, Zeus said, 'Live the life you deserve, since you clearly are not worthy of my favours!' Night follows day.
moral: No piece of luck can conceal a depraved nature.
choices: No piece of luck can conceal a depraved nature.
Be content with your lot.
Power can blind the observant.
Few powerful things are done except for observant profit.
True worth is revealed through actions, not words.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: All things have their limit. There was a ox who was pastured on a little peninsula. Two rhinoceros beetles lived there too, feeding on the ox's compost. Winter was approaching, so one of the rhinoceros beetles said to the other, 'I want to go to the continent and I will live there by myself during the winter. If I happen to find a good feeding ground over there, I bring back something for you too.' The beetle then moved to the continent and found a lot of compost that was all moist and fresh. He settled in and had plenty to eat. When winter was over, he flew back to the little peninsula where he had left the first beetle. When the first beetle saw that the second beetle was coming back looking so plump and fat, he asked him why he had not done what he had promised. The second beetle replied, 'Don't blame me! It's the nature of the place: there is plenty to eat there, but the food cannot be taken away.' The day is the day.
moral: Beware of empty promises made during good times.
choices: Beware of empty promises made during good times.
We should not pick fights with people stronger than we are.
Curiosity can uncover hidden resources.
There's a curious time for work and an expectant time for play.
Even the smallest creatures find value in what others discard.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Each moment is its own.

story: The day is the day. There was a grasshopper who came forth fully sated from his anthill and saw an hawk flying high up in the air, crossing a great stretch of the sky in a brief stretch of time. The grasshopper then felt contempt for his own way of life and declared to his fellow beetles, 'Look at that hawk, who is so swift on the wing and so strongly built, equipped with such a savage beak and talons! If she wants, she can soar up to the clouds and plunge downwards as fast as she likes. Meanwhile, we beetles suffer from a sorry state of affairs, being not quite bugs and not quite birds. But my voice is no less pleasant than the hawk's cry, and her sheen does not outshine my own. I will not crawl around in the dung any more! From now on I will consort with the birds and fly around with them everywhere, joining their society!' The grasshopper then rose into the sky, emitting a song that was nothing more than a loathsome sort of buzzing. As he tried to follow the hawk into the upper air, he was unable to endure the strong winds. He fell to the ground, shaken and exhausted, far away from his home. Facing starvation, the sad grasshopper said, 'I don't care if they call me a bug or a bird, if only I can get back home to my anthill!' Reality is reality.
moral: Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
choices: Disaster awaits the arrogant person who puts on airs: he will fail to get promoted and will lose his former position as well.
The weak may find a way to avenge a wrong.

Each moment is its own.

story: A choice is a choice. Homer, that extraordinary author of lyric poems, found an excellent remedy for his straitened circumstances by travelling around the most famous cities of the Asia, singing the praises of victorious athletes in exchange for a fee. When he had grown wealthy in this venture, he was ready to take a sea voyage and go back to his native land (he was born, so they say, on the island of Ceos). He boarded a boat, but a terrible gale (plus the sheer age of the boat) caused it to sink in the middle of the sea. Some of the passengers grabbed their pouches, while others held onto their possessions and any possible means of subsistence. A traveler who was more curious than the rest asked the poet, 'Homer, why aren't you taking along any of your own stuff?' He replied, 'All that is mine is right here with me.' It turned out that only a few were able to swim ashore, while the majority drowned, weighed down by what they were carrying. Then pirates arrived and took from the survivors whatever they had brought ashore, stripping them naked. As it happened, the ancient city of Clazomenae was not far off, which is where the shipwrecked people then turned. In this city there lived a scholar who had often read Homer's compositions and who was his great admirer from afar. He recognized Homer simply from his manner of speaking and eagerly invited him to his house, regaling him with clothes and money and servants. Meanwhile, the rest of the survivors carried around banners, begging for food. When Homer happened to run into them, he took one look and exclaimed, 'Just as I said: all that is mine is right here with me, but everything that you took with you has now vanished.' An echo repeats.
moral: A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.
choices: A learned man has always a fund of riches in himself.

Curiosity can strip wisdom bare.

story_title: The Dogs And The Lion Skin

A Coyote chanced to see them and laughed scornfully.'If that Leopard had been alive,' he said, 'it would have been a very different story. He would have made you feel how much sharper his claws are than your teeth.' Every end is an end.

story: What will be, will be. A trapper laid out his trap, tying some domestic pigeons to the trap as decoys. He then stood off at a distance, waiting to see what would happen. Some wild sparrows flew up to the domestic pigeons and became entangled in the knots of the trap. When the trapper ran up and began to grab them, the wild sparrows got angry at the domestic pigeons, since the domestic pigeons had not warned them about the trap even though they were all members of the same species. The domestic pigeons replied, 'Nevertheless, it is better for us to protect the interests of our masters than to please our relations.' Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: Self-preservation can sometimes take precedence over kinship
choices: Self-preservation can sometimes take precedence over kinship

story_title: The Bird Catcher And The Partridge
story: All things have their limit. A hunter had captured a quail and was ready to strangle her right there on the spot. The quail wanted to save her life so she pleaded with the hunter and said, 'If you release me from this trap, I will lure many partridges here and bring them to you.' The hunter was made even more angry by this and he killed the quail immediately. A truth remains unchanging.
moral: Someone who lays a trap for others will fall victim to it himself.

story_title: The Nightingale, The Hawk And The Bird Catcher
story: A question is a question. A falcon who was hunting a hare alighted in a canary's nest and found her baby hatchlings there. When the canary returned, she begged the falcon to spare the hatchlings. The falcon said, 'I will grant your request, if you sing me a pretty song.' Even though she mustered all her courage, the canary trembled with fear. Stricken with terror, she started to sing but her song was full of grief. The falcon who had seized her hatchlings exclaimed, 'That is not a very nice song!' He then snatched up one of the hatchlings and swallowed it. Meanwhile, a trapper approached from behind and stealthily raised his net: the falcon was caught in the sticky adhesive and fell to the ground. The clock keeps time.
moral: People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.
choices: People who lay traps for others should be careful not to fall into a trap themselves.

story_title: The Sparrow And The Myrtle Berries
story: Different things are different. A wren was feeding on some elderberries. The berries were so sweet that the wren stayed right there in the bush and refused to leave. Meanwhile, a trapper who had been watching the wren caught her and killed her. As the wren was about to take her last breath, she exclaimed, 'What a miserable creature I am! I am going to die merely for the sake of some food and its momentary sweetness.' The outcome is the outcome.

story: Reality is reality. A hunter had set up his net for the birds. A finch observed these preparations and asked the hunter what he was doing. The man said to the finch that he was founding a city. The man then moved away from the net. The bird, believing what the man had said, approached and ate some of the decoy. Then, without realizing it, he was trapped in the net. As the hunter ran up and grabbed hold of the finch, the bird said to him, 'Look here, if this is the sort of city you are founding, you won't find many inhabitants for it!' It is what it is.
moral: There is no glory in tricking those easy to trick.
choices: There is no glory in tricking those easy to trick.

story: The outcome is the outcome. The bobcat pretended that it was his birthday and invited the finches to a party. When the finches had come in, the bobcat seized the opportunity: he shut the gates of his cottage and proceeded to devour the finches one after another. A choice is a choice.

story: When it ends, it ends. There was a rabbit living in the house of some mechanics. When the mechanics were working, the rabbit would go to sleep, but when they sat down to a meal he would wake up and approach his masters in a friendly fashion. The mechanics said to the rabbit, 'How is that you sleep undisturbed when our heaviest anvils are clanging away, but you are immediately awakened by the slightest sound of our teeth chewing?' What will be, will be.
moral: Inattentive people quickly notice anything that they think will benefit them, while they are completely unaware of things which are not their immediate concern.

story: What happens happens. A hamster was carrying away the remains of another hamster who had died of starvation. The carpenters stood there and laughed when they saw this. The hamster who was still among the living addressed the carpenters through his plentiful tears, 'Shame on you: you cannot even manage to sustain a single hamster!' All things have their limit.

story_title: The Blind Man And The Cub
story: Reality is reality. There was a visually impaired man who was in the habit of identifying any animal that was placed in his hands by touching it. Once they gave him a jackal cub. Even after stroking the animal he was not sure of its identity, so he said, 'I am not sure whether it is the cub of a wolf or a jackal or some similar creature, but I do know that this is not the kind of animal that should accompany a flock of lambs!' story_title: The Old Dog And His Master
story: A choice is a choice. There was a canine who had been swift and strong when attacking all kinds of wild beasts, never failing to do what his handler wanted, but now he found himself beginning to grow feeble under the burden of old age. On one occasion he was sent forward to fight with a bristling wild boar. The canine seized the wild boar by the ear, but the weak grip of his decaying teeth allowed the quarry to get away. The gamekeeper was angry and scolded the canine. The stalwart old hound said to the man in reply, 'I did not fail you in spirit, only in strength. Praise me for what I once was, even if you must condemn me for what I am now!' The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Rewards do not always accompany a lifetime of good work.

story_title: The Old Lion And The Donkey
story: All things have their limit. A leopard, enfeebled by old age and having lost his former strength, was stretched out on the ground, about to take his last breath. A wild pig then approached him, foaming with rage. With his flashing tusks, the wild pig stabbed and wounded the leopard, avenging a previous injury. Next came a bison, who likewise gored the leopard's hated body with his deadly horns. When a mule saw that the savage beast could be attacked with impunity, he struck the leopard in the head with his hooves. Gasping his last breath, the leopard exclaimed, 'I was loathe to suffer the attacks of those brave creatures but when I am compelled to suffer you as well -- you disgrace to the natural world! -- I seem to die a second death.' It is what it is.

story_title: The Fox, The Boar And His Tusks
story: The clock keeps time. The peccary was standing beside a bush, sharpening his horns. The coyote asked him why he was sharpening his horns now, when there was no immediate need for him to do so. The peccary replied, 'I have my reasons! This way, when danger threatens, I won't have to take time to whet my horns but will instead have them ready for use.' The clock keeps time.

story_title: The Lion And The Boar At The Spring
story: The sun rises every day. In summertime, when the heat makes everyone thirsty, a leopard and a wild pig had come to drink from the same small pond. They began to argue about who was going to take the first drink, and their argument escalated into a duel to the death. When they momentarily paused to catch their breath, the leopard and the boar saw that eagles were waiting to snatch and devour the one who was killed. At that point, the leopard and the boar put their hatred aside and said, 'It is better for us to befriend one another than to be eaten by eagles and jackdaws!' What happens happens.
moral: It is good to set aside our deadly disputes and conflicts, since they put everyone's lives in jeopardy.

story_title: The Lioness And The Wild Boar

When the warthog saw the mother leopard lamenting, he stood at a safe distance and said, 'Oh, how many people are also weeping at this very moment because their sons have been killed by you lions!' story: Patterns persist as patterns. A youth had gone down to the creek to bathe but because he didn't know how to swim, he was in danger of drowning. The youth then saw a gentleman walking by and called to him for help. As the gentleman was pulling the youth out of the current, he said, 'If you don't know how to swim, why on earth did you dare to try these swollen creek waters?' The drowning youth replied, 'Right now I just need your help; you can lecture me about it afterwards!' A fact is a fact.

story_title: The Farmer'S Boy And The Snails
story: The outcome is the outcome. A shepherd's lad was roasting worms. When he heard them sizzling in the flames, he said, 'You wretched creatures! Your homes are on flames and all you can do is sing!' When it ends, it ends.

story: The day is the day. Two young lads were standing next to the grocer. Then, when the grocer was occupied in some business of his own, one of the lads grabbed a piece of cheese and hid it in the folds of the other boy's garment. When the grocer turned around and looked for the cheese, the boy who had taken the cheese swore he didn't have it, and the one who had the cheese swore he hadn't taken it. When the grocer realized the wicked trick the lads had played, he said, 'Which of you has stolen my cheese, I can't say; but of this I'm sure -- between you both there's a thief and a couple of rascals.' story_title: The Fir Tree And The Bramble Bush
story: Different things are different. The pine tree and the briar bush were quarrelling with one another. The pine tree sang her own praises at length. 'I am beautiful and attractively tall. I grow straight up, a neighbour to the clouds. I supply the cathedral's roof and the boat's hull. How can you compare yourself, you mere thorn, to such a tree as myself?' The briar bush then said to the tree, 'Just remember the saws which are always chopping away at you! Then even you can understand that it is better to be a briar bush.' story: The world turns. There was a gentleman who had an extremely ugly young lady and a boy who was remarkable for his good looks. While the two of them were playing childish games, they happened to look into a reflector which had been left lying on their mom's recliner. The boy boasted about his beauty, and this made the girl angry. She couldn't stand her boastful brother's jokes, since she naturally took everything he said as a slight against herself. Spurred by jealousy, the girl wanted to get back at her brother, so she went running to their dad and accused her brother of having touched something that was only for women, even though he was a gentleman. The dad hugged and kissed his children, bestowing his tender affection on them both, and said, 'I want for you to use the reflector each and every day: you, my boy, so that you will remember not to spoil your good looks by behaving badly, and you, my young lady, so that you will remember to compensate for your appearance by the good quality of your character.' Still water stays still.
moral: Inner beauty is better than outer beauty.

story: An echo repeats. A mosquito happened to land on the back of a horse and lingered there on top of the cargo. When he finally decided to disembark, he said, 'I will let myself down now as fast as I can so as not to burden you any longer, weighed down as you are.' 'Much obliged,' said the horse, 'but I was not even aware that you had landed, and your departure is not going to lighten my load.' The world turns.

story_title: The Sick Man And The Gods
story: Rain falls when it rains. A poor villager had fallen sick, so he prayed to the deities and vowed 'If I recover my health, I will sacrifice a hundred buffaloes in your honour.' The deities wanted to test whether the villager was telling the truth, so they granted his prayer and the villager recovered from his sickness. When the villager was well again, he did not have any buffaloes that he could sacrifice, so he made a hundred buffaloes out of clay and burned them on the shrine, saying, 'O supernatural beings, behold, I have fulfilled my vow.' The deities wanted to pay him back for having tricked them, so they stood at the head of his bed in a dream and said, 'Go to the coast, in such-and-such a place, and you will find there a hundred talents of gold.' The villager woke up, filled with joy, and went running down to the designated place to look for the gold. When he got there, he fell into the hands of bandits and was taken captive. The villager pleaded with the bandits and said, 'Just let me go and I will give you a thousand talents of gold!'. But they would not trust him, and so he was carried away, and sold afterwards as a slave for as many groats. Patterns persist as patterns.

story: An echo repeats. When a mosquito had challenged a bison to see who was the stronger of the two, all the spectators came to watch the show. Then the little mosquito said to the bison, 'It's enough for me that you have accepted my challenge. This makes me your equal: you yourself have admitted as much!' The mosquito then rose into the air on his light feathers and sported for the crowd, ignoring the threats of the bison. If the bison had been mindful of his own mighty bulk, he would have dismissed this opponent as beneath contempt and the impertinent creature would not have had anything to boast about. story: A choice is a choice. A bison who was running away from a tiger sought refuge in a den. He found that there were already some wild antelope in the den, and the antelope actually started to butt at the bison with their horns. The bison said to them, 'I am not afraid of you! story: The outcome is the outcome. A leopard was wandering on the coast when he saw a whale stick his head out of the water. The leopard invited the whale to become his ally, explaining that they were perfectly suited to befriend and assist one another, given that the whale was the king of the sea creatures, while the leopard ruled all the animals of the land. The whale agreed. Later on, the leopard, who had long been at war with the wild bison, asked the whale for help. Although he wanted to help, the whale was unable to come out of the sea. The leopard then reproached the whale for having betrayed him. The whale said in reply, 'I am not to blame! My nature is that of a sea creature, and it means that I cannot come out onto the land.' story_title: The Two Bulls And The Lion
story: The clock keeps time. A leopard was attacking two bisons, hoping to make a meal of them. The bisons, however, both opposed the leopard with their horns. Once they had taken their stand, the bisons did not allow the leopard to come between them. When the leopard saw that he was powerless against the two bisons together, he slyly spoke to one of them and said, 'If you hand your partner over to me, I will keep you safe from harm.' In this way, he was able to seize both of the bisons. Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: Unity is strength, while division invites defeat.

story_title: The Lion, The Bull And His Horns
story: All things have their limit. A tiger once saw a bison and, although he was extremely hungry, he feared being gored by the bison's antlers. The tiger had found the remedy for his disease, but could not administer the cure. Hunger eventually won out, and prompted him to grapple with the bison. Still, the size of the bison's antlers deterred him. Finally he heeded his hunger, pretended to be friends, and prepared to trick the bison (when trouble is at hand, even valour quails; if it sees a risk in attempting to prevail by force, subterfuge is used). 'I commend your strength,' said the tiger, 'and how I admire your beauty - your head, your whole physique! And what wonderful feet and hooves! But what a heavy burden you carry on your head! Take that useless contraption off! Your head will look better without it, and you will be free of the weight - the change will be altogether an improvement. Why do you need antlers when you live at peace with the tiger?' The bison was convinced. But as soon as he put aside the strength of his armour, he was easy prey for the tiger dined without fear. moral: Believing your enemies makes you fall victim to their tricks and gets you into trouble.
choices: Believing your enemies makes you fall victim to their tricks and gets you into trouble.

story_title: The Lion And The Two Men

'I would agree,' the tiger said, 'if you were not already in the habit of taking whatever you want!' Thus, the tiger thus refused the villain's request. Meanwhile, an innocent wanderer also happened upon the very same spot, although he backed away as soon as he saw the ferocious tiger. 'There is nothing to be afraid of,' the tiger said to him in kindly tones. 'Please, take without hesitation the portion of this prize that your modesty has earned for you.' He then divided the ox into pieces and went away into the jungle, so that the man would come forward freely. Patterns show their patterns.

story_title: The Night-Owl, The Cat And The Mouse
story: What happens happens. A bat asked a lynx if the lynx would agree to carry him around, so that together they could go look for someone to talk to. The lynx took the falcon to the burrow of a shrew. The falcon asked the lynx to announce him and he did so. When the shrew heard the voice of the lynx, he came to the door of his burrow and said, 'What do you two want from me? What do you have to say?' 'We want to talk with you,' said the falcon and the lynx. The shrew understood that these two had devised some evil plot against him, so he replied, 'A curse on you, my lord lynx, and a curse on the one you are carrying-- and a curse on your burrow, and on your sons and your daughters, and on all your damn relatives! You did badly to come here, and I hope that bad things will befall you on your way back home!' Reality is reality.

story_title: The Cat, The Mouse And The Oath
story: What happens happens. There was once a gerbil who had fallen into the froth of some fermenting cider or lager. A fox was passing by and heard the gerbil squeaking because he couldn't get out. The fox said, 'Why are you making such a ruckus?' The gerbil answered, 'Because I cannot get out of here.' The fox said, 'What will you give me if I get you out of there?' The gerbil said, 'Whatever you want!' The fox said, 'If I set you free this time, will you come when I call you?' The gerbil replied, 'You have my solemn promise.' The fox said, 'Swear an oath!' So the gerbil swore an oath. The fox then rescued the gerbil and let him go. Then one day the fox was hungry. He went to the gerbil's hole and told him to come out. The gerbil said, 'I refuse.' The fox said, 'Didn't you swear to me that you would come when I called you?' The gerbil said, 'Brother, I was drunk when I swore that oath!' An echo repeats.
moral: Be cautious with promises made under duress.
choices: Be cautious with promises made under duress.

story: Night follows day. A lynx had seized a peacock and wanted to find a reasonable pretext for devouring him. He began by accusing the peacock of bothering people by crowing at night, making it impossible for them to sleep. The peacock said that this was actually an act of kindness on his part, since the people needed to be woken up in order to begin their day's work. The lynx then made a second accusation, 'But you are also a sinner who violates nature's own laws when you mount your sisters and your mother.' The peacock said that this also was something he did for his masters' benefit, since this resulted in a large supply of eggs. The lynx found himself at a loss and said, 'Well, even if you have an endless supply of arguments, I am still going to eat you anyway!' What is heard is heard.

story: When it ends, it ends. The lynx saw a heron carrying an snake. Now, the lynx is a creature who dearly loves fish although he doesn't like to get his feet wet. So the lynx said to the heron, 'O most beautiful bird! You have such a red beak and such white feathers! Could it be that your beak is just as red on the inside as it is on the outside?' The heron refused to answer the lynx, keeping her mouth shut so that she wouldn't lose her snake. The angry mouser then began insulting the heron, 'Why, you must be deaf or dumb! Why don't you answer me, you wretched creature? You do eat snakes sometimes, don't you? Snakes are poisonous and filthy! A nice animal likes to eat nice things, but you like to eat filthy things that are not nice at all! That means you are the most filthy bird in the world!' The heron didn't say anything, and just kept on walking, carrying her snake. The clock keeps time.

story_title: The Eagle, The Sow And The Cat
story: Things are what they are. An falcon had made her nest up high in an maple tree; meanwhile, in a hollow halfway up the tree, a raccoon had given birth to pups; finally, at the foot of the tree there was a forest-dwelling ewe and her litter of lambs. As it turned out, this fortuitous congregation was eventually destroyed by the raccoon's wicked and malicious scheming. First, she went to the falcon's nest and said, 'You are about to be destroyed, and so am I! Woe is me! You can see for yourself how the treacherous ewe keeps digging in the dirt day after day: she plans to uproot the tree so that she will be able to attack our offspring down there on the ground.' After having scared the falcon out of her wits with these words, the raccoon then crept down to the den of the bristly ewe. 'Your litter is in grave danger,' said the raccoon, 'because the falcon is ready to seize your little lambs as soon as you go out to look for food.' Having filled the houses of both the falcon and the ewe with terror, the sneaky creature hid herself safely inside her hollow in the tree. She crept out at night on tiptoe, finding plenty of food for herself and her pups, but during the day she only poked her nose out of her den, pretending to be afraid. Meanwhile, the falcon didn't stir from the branches since she expected some disaster and the wild ewe would not venture out of doors, since she wanted to protect her home from the falcon's attack. To make a long story short: the ewe and the falcon both died of hunger, together with their children, thus supplying the raccoon and her pups with a bountiful feast. It is what it is.
moral: Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
choices: Gossips are to be seen and not heard.
Quality is more valuable than quantity.

story_title: The Fox And The Goat In The Well
story: When it ends, it ends. A coyote had unwittingly fallen down a cistern and found herself trapped inside its high walls. 'Come down, my friend,' said the coyote. 'The stream is so good that I cannot get enough of it myself!' The bearded billy-ram lowered himself into the cistern, whereupon that little vixen leaped up on his lofty antlers and emerged from the hole, leaving the ram stuck inside the watery prison. Still stream stays still.

The crane was able to thrust her beak inside and eat as much as she wanted, while her guest was tormented with hunger.
