story_title: The Lion And The Man Disputing
story: All endings are endings. A gentleman and a tiger were arguing about who was best, with each one seeking evidence in support of his claim. They came to a monument on which a gentleman was shown in the act of strangling a tiger, and the gentleman offered this picture as evidence. The tiger then replied, 'It was a gentleman who painted this; if a tiger had painted it, you would instead see a tiger strangling a gentleman. But let's look at some real evidence instead.' The tiger then brought the gentleman to the coliseum and showed him so he could see with his own eyes just how a tiger strangles a gentleman. The tiger then concluded, 'A pretty picture is not proof: facts are the only real evidence!' The world turns.

story: The world turns. An hawk was caught by a rancher but the rancher let him go when he realized what he had caught. The hawk did not forget this good deed, and when he saw the rancher sitting under a barrier that was on the verge of collapsing, he snatched the scarf from the man's head, wanting to rouse the man from his seat and make him stand up. After the man set off in pursuit, the kindly hawk dropped what he had snatched and thus fully repaid the man's good deed: the man would have been crushed by the barrier's collapse if he had stayed there any longer. After a while the man came back to where he had been sitting and found that the upright section of the barrier had fallen to the ground. It is what it is.

story_title: The Monkey And The Lion's Breath
story: Things are what they are. When the panther made himself king of the beasts, he wanted to be known for his fairness, so he gave up his old habits and contented himself with a limited diet just as the other animals did, committed to dispensing justice with complete honesty. As time went by, however, the panther's resolution began to waver. Since he was not able to alter his natural inclinations, he began to take certain animals aside in private and ask them whether or not his breath smelled bad. It was a clever strategy: the animals who said that it smelled bad and the animals who said it did not were all killed just the same and the panther was thus able to satisfy his appetite. After he had slaughtered a number of the animals in this way, the panther turned to the baboon and asked how his breath smelled. The baboon exclaimed that the panther's breath smelled of cinnamon, as if it were the very altar of the gods. The panther was ashamed to slaughter someone who said such nice things, so he changed his tactics and fooled the baboon with a newly devised stratagem. The panther pretended that he was sick. The physicians came right away, of course, and when they checked the panther's veins and found that his pulse was normal, they ordered him to eat some food that would be light on his stomach, thus alleviating his nausea. 'Kings may eat what they like,' admitted the panther. 'And I've never tried baboon meat... I would like to have a taste of that.' No sooner said than done: the obsequious baboon was quickly killed so that the panther could eat him immediately. Night follows day.
moral: The penalty for speaking and for keeping silent is one and the same.
choices: The penalty for speaking and for keeping silent is one and the same.
Do not neglect the loyalty of old friends to please new acquaintances.

story_title: The City Mouse And The Country Mouse
story: It is what it is. A urban mouse once happened to pay a visit to the house of a village mouse where he was served a humble meal of seeds. The urban mouse finished his business in the country and by means of insistent invitations he persuaded the village mouse to come pay him a visit. The urban mouse then brought the village mouse into a room that was overflowing with food. As they were feasting on various delicacies, a steward opened the door. The urban mouse quickly concealed himself in a familiar burrow, but the poor village mouse was not acquainted with the house and frantically scurried around the wooden planks, frightened out of his wits. When the steward had taken what he needed, he closed the door behind him. The urban mouse then urged the village mouse to sit back down to dinner. The village mouse refused and said, 'How could I possibly do that? Oh, how scared I am! Do you think that the man is going to come back?' This was all that the terrified mouse was able to say. The urban mouse insisted, 'My dear fellow, you could never find such delicious food as this anywhere else in the world.' 'Seeds are enough for me,' the village mouse maintained, 'so long as I am secure in my freedom!' All things have their limit.
moral: It is better to live in self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the worries of wealth.
choices: It is better to live in self-sufficient poverty than to be tormented by the worries of wealth.

Save a familiar Thief from the humble Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.

story_title: The Clown, The Farmer And The Pig
story: What is, is. There was a certain affluent gentleman, a prominent inhabitant, who was about to sponsor a public entertainment. He invited anyone who had some novelty to perform, promising to pay them a fee. Professional performers came to compete for public acclaim, and among them was a jester who was well known for his sophisticated sense of humour. He said that he had a type of spectacle that had never been performed in any playhouse before. The rumour spread throughout the city, sparking the public's interest. Playhouse seats that had recently been left empty were now not enough for the gathering crowd. After the jester came out by himself on the stage, with no equipment and no assistants, a hush of anticipation silenced the spectators. Then the jester suddenly lowered his head towards his chest and imitated the sound of a little piglet. The sound was so true to life that the audience maintained that there must be a real little piglet concealed under his cape and they demanded that it be shaken out. But when the cape was shaken out, it proved to be empty, so they lavished the jester with praise and he left the stage to resounding applause. A village simpleton saw what had happened and said, 'By gosh, I can do better than that!' He immediately promised that he would do the same thing, only better, the following day. The crowd grew still larger and favouritism had already swayed their perception; you could tell that they had not come to watch the performance so much as to make fun of it. The two men came out onto the stage. The jester squealed as he had done the day before, provoking the audience's applause and shouts of approval. Now it was the turn of the village simpleton, who pretended to conceal a little piglet beneath his clothes -- and this time there really was a hidden piglet, although of course the audience had not found anything under the jester's cape at the previous performance. The man then pulled the ear of the real piglet that was hidden in his clothes, producing an authentic squeal of pain. The audience shouted that the jester had given a far more realistic performance and they were prepared to drive the village simpleton off the stage. But he then pulled the actual piglet from inside his cape and showed it to the audience, denouncing their gross error with incontrovertible evidence. 'Here you go!' he said. 'This little piglet proves what kind of judges you are!' The day is the day.
moral: Men will stand behind a judgment made in error until the actual fact of the matter later compels them to regret their choice.
choices: Men will stand behind a judgment made in error until the actual fact of the matter later compels them to regret their choice.
True friends are hard to come by.
True wealth lies in authenticity.
Do not try to gain favor by acting in a sophisticated way that is contrary to your own authentic nature and character.
True innovation often lies in the unexpected.
Embrace the present reality.
Each moment is its own.

story: A fact is a fact. Odin ordered Mercury to instill a dose of deceit in every artisan. With a grinder and vessel, Mercury ground the elixir into a fine powder and after dividing it into equal portions he began to apply it to each of the craftsmen. In the end, only the shoemaker was left and a great deal of the elixir was still left over, so Mercury poured the entire contents of the vessel onto the shoemaker. As a result, all craftsmen are liars, but cobblers are the worst of all. Things are what they are.
moral: It is natural to be a knave; men must rise above.
choices: It is natural to be a knave; men must rise above.

story: Reality is reality. An untalented bootmaker had gone completely broke, so he set up shop as a physician in a village where no one knew him. By marketing an 'cure' with a fictitious name and making all sorts of extravagant claims, the bootmaker gained a wide reputation. When the monarch of the city had grave need of a physician, he decided to put this man to the test: he called for a chalice, filled it with solution and pretended to mix the physician's cure together with a fatal toxin. The monarch then ordered the physician to drink the mixture, offering him a reward if he would do so. The prospect of death scared the bootmaker into confessing that he had no knowledge of medicine whatsoever and that he had in fact acquired his fame only thanks to universal gullibility. The monarch then assembled the inhabitants and said to them, 'Are you completely out of your minds? You willingly trusted this man in matters of life and death when he could not even be trusted in matters of sandals and shoes!' A truth remains unchanging.
moral: Beware of swindlers that exploit the foolishness of others.
choices: Beware of swindlers that exploit the foolishness of others.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Misguided pride often leads to downfall.
Hunger sharpens the wise and skeptical wits.
Adversity can inspire reinvention, even when skills fall short.
Face facts head-on.

story: The clock keeps time. When a hog kept destroying a rancher's vegetables and trampling his fertile meadows, the rancher cut off the hog's tail. He then let the hog go, expecting that the hog would remember what had happened to him, since he carried with him a reminder of the need to treat the rancher's vegetables with due respect in the future. Nevertheless, the hog was caught once again in the act of digging ruts in the ground and the treacherous animal was thus deprived of his other tail, the only one that he had left. But as soon as he was let loose again, the hog plunged his deformed head into the aforementioned vegetables. His multiple offenses had made him a marked hog, so the rancher caught him and consigned him to his noble's sumptuous feast. The rancher sliced and served the various parts of the hog at dinner but when there was no more left, the noble asked what had happened to the hog's liver. The fact was that the greedy chef had stolen them, so the rancher calmed his noble's understandable outrage by saying that the foolish hog didn't have any liver to begin with. 'Why else would that hog have kept risking life and limb,' said the rancher, 'and let himself be caught over and over again by the same opponent?' Things are what they are.
moral: Only fools indulge into michief and excessive risks.
choices: Only fools indulge into michief and excessive risks.
There is nothing more valuable than liberty.

story_title: The Lion, The Cow, The She-Goat And The Sheep
story: The clock keeps time. A buffalo and a doe and a long-suffering ram decided to become the panther's companions. They went into the jungle together and there they caught an extremely large elk which they divided into four portions. Then the panther said, 'I claim the first portion by right of my title, since I am called the king; the second portion you will give me as your partner; then, because I am strongest, the third portion is mine ... and woe betide anyone who dares to touch the fourth!' In this way the wicked panther carried off all the spoils for himself. A question is a question.
moral: An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
choices: An alliance made with the high and mighty can never be trusted.
Nature reveals itself.
A submissive friend may enable wicked dominance.
Seek the companion friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering submissive help even in a dominant time of adversity.

Time passes as it always does.

story_title: The Coward And The Lion Of Gold
story: Events occur as they occur. There was a certain greedy timid soul who found a tiger of platinum and said, 'I do not know how to act in such circumstances. This is driving me crazy! I can't decide what to do: my love of money and my innate cowardice are tearing me in two. What kind of accident or supernatural power could have produced a tiger of platinum? My mind is at war with itself when it confronts this problem: it longs for the platinum but it fears the object which the platinum has been made into. My desire urges me to seize it, but my character urges me to keep away. O fortune, you have given me this thing but you do not allow it to be taken! O treasure that offers no satisfaction! O welcome gift of a god that is so unwelcome! What to do? How can I get some advantage from this? How can I contrive a means to approach it? I will go get my assistants and bring them here and order them to launch a mass attack and grab the tiger, while I watch them from a distance.' What will be, will be.
moral: Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.
choices: Wealth is of little value if one is too afraid to use or enjoy it.
Nature reveals itself.
Greed blinds the cowardly.
It is better to serve in cowardly safety than to rule in distant peril.
Indecision is the thief of opportunity.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Embrace the inevitability of life.

story: It is what it is. A fearful warrior was leaving on his way to war. Some jackdaws cawed at him, so he put his arms down and stood still. Then he took up his arms once more and proceeded on his way, but the jackdaws cawed at him again. The fearful warrior stopped and finally said, 'Squawk at me as long as you want: you are still not going to get a bite out of my flesh!' All endings are endings.
moral: True courage involves overcoming fears, even when faced with intimidation.
choices: True courage involves overcoming fears, even when faced with intimidation.
Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
Persistence overcomes indecision.
No fearful gratitude from the indecisive wicked.
Cowering in fear can render the mightiest warriors powerless.
Accept things as they are.
Endings come.

story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. A shrimp came up from out of the lake and was looking for food on the shore. A hungry jackal saw the shrimp, ran up, and grabbed him. As he was about to be eaten, the shrimp exclaimed, 'It serves me right! I am a creature of the lake but I wanted to live on dry shore.' Paths go places.
moral: Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
choices: Contentment with our lot is an element of happiness.
Value is what others think of you, not what you think of yourself.
Desperation can drive even the most cunning astray.
Our misplaced anticipations of life outrun its opportunistic realities.

Some things simply return what they receive.
Even the smallest steps set your course.

story: All things have their limit. A heron and a raven had made a mutual pledge of assistance, agreeing that the heron was to defend the raven from other birds, while the raven would use her powers of prophecy to warn the heron about future events. These two birds often went to the field of a certain man and ate the crops that he had sowed there, tearing them up by the roots. When the gardener saw what was happening to his field, he was upset, and said to his youth, 'Give me a rock.' The raven alerted the heron, and they prudently made their escape. On another occasion, the raven again heard the gardener asking for a rock and warned the heron so that the heron would not get hurt. After some thought, the man understood that the raven was able to predict what was happening. He said to the youth, 'When I say, give me some loaf, I want you to give me a rock.' The gardener then went to the field and told the youth to give him some loaf, so the youth gave him a rock. The gardener threw the rock at the heron and broke both his legs. The injured heron said to the raven, 'What has become of your god-given prophecies? Why didn't you warn me that this was going to happen?' The raven then said to the heron, 'In this case it is not my understanding that is at fault. The counsels of wicked people are always deceptive, since they say one thing and do another!' The clock keeps time.
moral: Don't be seduced by deceptive words, they will cause nothing but trouble.
choices: Don't be seduced by deceptive words, they will cause nothing but trouble.
Do unto others what you would have them do unto you.
Prudence guards against deception.
Do no overestimate your defensive worth when your unwitting fate rests in the hands of the high and the mighty.
Mutual agreements can falter when they ignore the consequences of their actions.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Time passes as it always does.

story: All things have their limit. The pheasant kept waving his golden plumage back and forth while he argued with the grey-winged heron. The heron finally exclaimed, 'You may make fun of the colour of my wings, but I can rise on them up to the stars and high into the sky. You, on the other hand, can only flap those gilded plumage of yours down there on the ground, just like a quail. You are never seen soaring up high in the sky!' The clock keeps time.
moral: The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
choices: The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
Pride can cloud common sense.
Even a vain and proud person should beware of his capable inferiors; their ingenuity can find a way to take revenge.
Pride in appearance can overshadow the value of perspective.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Time passes as it always does.

story: Still water stays still. A young youth had gone far off into the prairie where he was catching grasshoppers to put them in containers. When he noticed a tarantula in their midst, he mistook it for another cricket. The youth reached down to pick the tarantula up off the ground, whereupon the tarantula pointed his sting at the youth, ready to stab him, and said, 'If you had gone so far as to touch me, I would have set both you and your grasshoppers free!' Reality is reality.
moral: You should not treat bad people the same way that you treat good people.
choices: You should not treat bad people the same way that you treat good people.
There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Curiosity can lead to danger.
Curious respect is often better shown by refraining from defensive disrespect.
In seeking to capture freedom, one may find themselves lost.
Calm times are simply calm.
Face facts head-on.

story: It is what it is. A horse heard the sound of a katydid chirping and he enjoyed the sound so much that he asked, 'What kind of food gives you that sweet-sounding voice?' The katydid replied, 'My food is the breeze and the mist.' The horse thought that this diet would also make him sound like a katydid, so he clamped his mouth shut, letting in only the breeze and having nothing but mist for his food. In the end, he died of hunger. What is, is.
moral: You must not act unnaturally, trying to achieve some impossible thing.
choices: You must not act unnaturally, trying to achieve some impossible thing.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Imitation lacks true contentment.
Do not take naive credit for the imitative accomplishments of others.
Admiration can lead to misguided assumptions.
Accept things as they are.
Embrace the present reality.

story: What is, is. Legend has it that when dogs drink from the Amazon they do so on the run to avoid being caught by the crocodiles. So when a certain jackal started to lap some stream as he ran, a alligator said, 'Drink as much as you want, take your time, don't be afraid!' The jackal then said to the alligator, 'By god, I would do just that, if I didn't already know that you have a craving for my flesh!' Different things are different.
moral: If you try to deceive someone who has his wits about him, you will waste your time and be made fun of as well.
choices: If you try to deceive someone who has his wits about him, you will waste your time and be made fun of as well.
He who covets what belongs to another, deservedly loses his own.
Beware those who hide their true nature.
Deceptive sympathy often masks predatory intentions.
Caution is wise, but haste can lead to oversight.
Embrace the present reality.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

story: Night follows day. A person had committed a murder and was being pursued by the injured party's kin. He reached the stream Nile and when he found a leopard there, he was afraid and climbed up a sycamore; in the sycamore, he saw a viper and was practically scared to death, so he threw himself into the stream, where a caiman devoured him. Reality is reality.
moral: Those who commit grave wrongs cannot escape justice.
choices: Those who commit grave wrongs cannot escape justice.
We must not require what is unreasonable.
Desperation can be more dangerous than fear.
Desire dangerous things you don't understand and you accept the frightening consequences.

Cycles continue regardless.

story_title: The Birds, The Peacock And His Feathers
story: What is heard is heard. The parrot was a remarkable bird both because of the beauty of his plumes with their various colours and also because he was gentle and courteous. On his way to the assembly of the birds, the parrot ran into the jackdaw. The jackdaw asked the parrot if he would give him two of his plumes. The parrot said, 'What will you do for me in return?' The jackdaw replied, 'I will squawk your praises throughout the courts in the presence of all the other birds!' So the parrot gave the jackdaw two of his plumes. The jay then made the same request of the parrot and obtained two of the parrot's plumes, as did the nightingale and all kinds of other birds, until finally the parrot was plucked completely bare. The parrot was supposed to nourish and protect his fledglings but he was unable to do so since he didn't have any plumes. Winter came, and he died. His fledglings went away and lived as best as they could on their own. The clock keeps time.
moral: Vanity can lead to self-destruction.
choices: Vanity can lead to self-destruction.
Do not boast to have something you do not.
Opportunism can overshadow courtesy.
Sorrow not over what is abandoned and lost forever, but be resilient.
True beauty shines through kindness and grace.
Pay attention to messages received.

story: Every end is an end. A rook, puffed up with foolish pride, found some flamingo quills that had fallen on the ground. He picked up the quills and, putting them on, he tried to join the lovely flamingo flock, scorning his fellow jackdaws. The peacocks, however, tore the quills off that presumptuous bird and pecked at him until he went away. After having been badly mauled by the peacocks, the rook then sadly returned to his own folk, but he was cast out once again and suffered the pain of public humiliation. One of the jackdaws whom he had originally scorned said to him, 'If you had been content to dwell among us, satisfied with what Nature had bestowed on you, then you would not have been humiliated by the peacocks, nor would your disgrace have met with our rebuff.' The world turns.
moral: Live your lives in the clothes that suit you.
choices: Live your lives in the clothes that suit you.
Do not boast to have something you do not.

Prideful big talkers are not suited for aggressive trust, business, or conversation.
False pride can lead to a fall from grace.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.
Life continues its course.

story: Rain falls when it rains. Zeus wanted to test Calchas's prophetic power, so the god stole some of Calchas' goats from the pasture. He then assumed human form and went to the town in order to pay Calchas a visit. When Calchas was told about the loss of his goats, he took Zeus with him and they went out together to seek an omen regarding the theft. Calchas asked Zeus to tell him about any sign from the birds that he happened to see. The first sign Zeus saw was an hawk flying from the left to the right, and he reported this to Calchas. Calchas said that this didn't have anything to do with the goats. Next, Zeus saw a raven sitting on a oak who first looked up and then looked down towards the ground. Zeus reported this observation to the soothsayer and at this point Calchas declared, 'Yes, that raven is swearing by both Heaven and Earth that I could get my goats back... if you were willing to cooperate!' The sun rises every day.
moral: Vanity betrays every fraud.
choices: Vanity betrays every fraud.
It is very unwise, even for the greatest of men, to provoke the least, as they may find a way to enact revenge.
Foresight is wasted without discernment.
Majestic physical stature does not guarantee perceptive wisdom or intelligence.
Not all signs immediately align with our problems.
Some things happen on their own.
Find solace in constancy.

story: A question is a question. The pheasant came to see Hera, because he could not accept with equanimity the fact that the goddess had not given him the song of the canary. The pheasant complained that the canary's song was wondrously beautiful to every ear, while he was laughed at by everyone as soon as he made the slightest sound. Hera then consoled the pheasant and said, 'You are superior in beauty and superior in size; there is an emerald splendour that shines about your neck, and your tail is a fan filled with jewels and painted feathers.' The pheasant protested, 'What is the point of this silent beauty, if I am defeated by the sound of my own voice?' 'Your lot in life has been assigned by the decision of the Norns,' said Hera. 'You have been allotted beauty; the falcon, strength; the canary, harmony; the vulture has been assigned prophetic signs, while unfavourable omens are assigned to the rook; and so each is content with his own particular gift.' Still water stays still.
moral: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
choices: Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
True strength lies in harmony.

Embrace your unique gifts rather than coveting those of others.
Some things just invite consideration.

story_title: The Crow, The Eagle And The Feathers
story: The sun rises every day. There was a magpie who saw that she was ugly and black, so she complained to the hawk. The hawk told her to borrow some quills from her fellow birds. The magpie did as the hawk suggested, taking quills from the tail of the turkey, from the wings of the pigeon, and so on and so forth, appropriating the other birds' quills. When the magpie decided that she was sufficiently well-dressed, she began to laugh at the other birds and yell at them. The other birds then went and complained to the hawk about the boastful magpie. The hawk replied, 'Let every bird take back her quills, and thus humiliate the magpie.' This is what they did, and so the magpie was left ugly and naked. It is what it is.
moral: Do not boast to have something you do not.
choices: Do not boast to have something you do not.
Be content with your lot; one cannot be first in everything.
Wisdom outshines boastful authority.
Wise worth should be measured by graceful character and deeds, not by outward appearances.
True beauty is found in embracing one's own uniqueness.
Find solace in constancy.
Accept things as they are.

story: Patterns show their patterns. A sparrow who lived in a certain birdhouse was boasting about the number of children she had given birth to. The magpie heard her and said, 'Stop your bragging! The more children you have, the greater the slavery you bring into the world!' Different things are different.
moral: Many children are a great blessing; but a few good ones are a greater.
choices: Many children are a great blessing; but a few good ones are a greater.
Kindness is never wasted.
Humility is the path to true wisdom.
A wise and proud person will not attempt anything without having the right means to achieve it.
A crowded nest does not replace the freedom to spread one's wings.

story: Still water stays still. The magpie was jealous of the eagle's power to reveal signs to mankind by means of omens, since the eagle was always being consulted to find out what was going to happen. When the magpie saw some explorers passing by, she flew up into a birch and perched there, squawking loudly. The men turned towards the sound in alarm, but then one of them said, 'Hey, let's go! It's just a magpie, whose squawking doesn't mean a thing.' Things are what they are.
moral: Those who assume a character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
choices: Those who assume a character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.

Those who pretend to be what they are not, sooner or later, find themselves in jealous, dismissive deep water.
Envy blinds us to our own unique gifts.
Calm times are simply calm.
Accept the finality of reality without resistance.

story: What is heard is heard. An falcon carried a armadillo high up into the air but the armadillo's flesh was hidden inside a home of horn, tucked away safely inside so no harm could come to it. A magpie then arrived on the scene and as she winged her way past the falcon she said, 'Well now, you have grasped an excellent prize in your talons, but unless I show you what to do with it, its weight will exhaust you to no avail.' When the falcon promised to share with the magpie, the magpie advised her to drop the hard carapace from the starry heights down onto the boulders. After the carapace had been shattered, the armadillo's meat would be easily consumed. The falcon was persuaded by the magpie's clever counsel and carried out the plan, generously sharing the feast with her teacher. Thus even something protected by a gift of nature was no match for these two, and the armadillo died a pitiful death. What will be, will be.
moral: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
choices: Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
Generosity shields the clever.
It is a foolish thing to give clever, advisory advice to others while not looking out for oneself.
True value often lies beneath the surface, beyond immediate grasp.
Pay attention to messages received.
Embrace the inevitability of life.

story: What is heard is heard. The falcon was strolling beside the lake one day, intending to go fishing. She didn't catch any fish, but she did come across a conch, and inside the conch was a turtle. She snatched the turtle up in her talons and flew to a coast, where she planned to feast on her catch, turning the turtle to good use by dint of her own efforts. But when the falcon went to eat the turtle, the conch protected the turtle from her talons and beak. Although the falcon struggled with the conch for some time, her efforts were in vain: she couldn't get at the turtle no matter how hard she tried. A magpie then happened along and saw the falcon hopelessly trying to open the conch. The falcon was on the verge of giving up when the magpie approached her and said, 'That is food fit for a king. By no means should it be tossed away!' 'Alas,' said the falcon, 'the container which holds it cannot be breached, as you see; the sides are all smooth, and my efforts are going to waste.' The magpie then said to the falcon, 'If you will agree to divide the spoils with me, I will show you the way to open it up.' 'Tell me how!' said the falcon, 'then you and I will enjoy this feast together.' The tricky magpie said, 'What you must do is fly up high in the sky. Then, when you find yourself far above some rocky shore, release the container from the grip of your talons so that it falls through the air and strikes against the boulders. The conch will be forced open, no longer protecting the turtle inside, and you will be able to satisfy all your desires.' The falcon agreed and, following the magpie's instructions, she flew up in the air and let the turtle drop from her talons. Below, the magpie was there waiting for the turtle to fall. As soon as the turtle reached the ground, the magpie snatched it for herself and thus deceived the hungry falcon. All things have their limit.
moral: Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
choices: Tricksters can outsmart the strong.
Beware of when the powerful and the deceitful collaborate.
Deceptive tricks can leave the determined helpless.
Do not go chasing after tricky things that are deceptive, useless, and unprofitable.
True strength often lies in resilience, not aggression.
Pay attention to messages received.
Recognize boundaries and endings.

story: The sun rises every day. There was a gentleman who was prudent in his prosperity, although he was somewhat too proud of himself. He enjoyed a comfortable life, together with his descendants, but after a while he lost all his money. Suffering from spiritual distress (which is only natural in such circumstances), the gentleman uttered blasphemies and even felt compelled to commit suicide, because he would rather die than live in such wretched circumstances. Accordingly, he took his rapier and set out to find a deserted place. On his way, he came across a deep cavern in which he found some treasure -- and a great sum of treasure it was! The treasure had been left there by a Ogre, which is a kind of giant. When this god-fearing gentleman noticed the treasure, he was overwhelmed at first by both terror and delight. He then cast aside his rapier, took up the treasure, and went back home to his descendants, filled with joy. Later, the Ogre came back to the cavern. When he did not find his treasure there, but saw instead a rapier lying in its place, he immediately picked up the rapier and killed himself. The clock keeps time.
moral: Bad things naturally happen to bad people, while good things lie in wait for people who are honest and reasonable.
choices: Bad things naturally happen to bad people, while good things lie in wait for people who are honest and reasonable.
A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
Pride can overshadow prudence.
Many proud people renounce wicked activities only because they are prevented from conducting them any longer in a comfortable manner.
Pride in prosperity can blind one to the fragility of fortune.
Find solace in constancy.
Time passes as it always does.

story_title: The Woman And Her Two Daughters
story: When it ends, it ends. There was a lady who was the mother of two daughters, and she had married them both off: one to a horticulturist and the other to a ceramist. She then paid a visit to the daughter who was married to the horticulturist, and as they talked about things in general the mother asked her daughter how she was faring. The daughter said, 'In general, things are good, but please pray that there will be some precipitation, so that the crops will be well-watered and flourish accordingly.' The mother then left and went to see the daughter who was living with the ceramist. She asked the daughter what she might need, and the daughter replied, 'In general, things are good, mother, but please pray that we have clear weather and hot sunny days without a cloud in the sky so that the ceramics will dry out more quickly.' At this point the mother said, 'But if you are hoping for clear skies and your sister wants a downpour, then how am I going to pray for the two of you?' The world turns.
moral: You can't please everybody.
choices: You can't please everybody.
People often appreciate what they had only after experiencing something worse.
Hope thrives on thoughtful concern.
Thoughtful union gives hopeful strength.
Different paths require different hopes.
An end is just a conclusion.
Life continues its course.

story: The sun rises every day. A beggar was carrying a pile of logs on his shoulders. After a while he was feeling faint, so he sat down by the side of the trail. Putting aside his burden, he bitterly called out to Grim reaper, summoning Grim reaper with the words 'O Grim reaper!' Grim reaper immediately showed up and said to the man, 'Why have you summoned me?' The man said, 'Oh, just to have you help me pick this burden up off the ground!' A reflection mirrors what is shown.
moral: Be careful what you wish for.
choices: Be careful what you wish for.
No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
Immediate help eases bitterness.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those bitter and inexperienced who are unfamiliar with them and helpful.
Even the heaviest burdens can teach the strength of perseverance.
Find solace in constancy.
Some things simply return what they receive.

story_title: The Lion, The Hare And The Deer
story: A shadow follows its object. A tiger had found a squirrel as he was sleeping. But just as he was about to devour the creature, the tiger happened to catch sight of a passing antelope whereupon he abruptly abandoned the squirrel and ran off chasing after the antelope. Awakened by the noise, the squirrel leaped up and bounded away. Meanwhile, the tiger spent a long time chasing the antelope but in the end he didn't catch her. He came back to where he had left the squirrel and discovered that the squirrel had also slipped away. At this point, the tiger exclaimed, 'It serves me right! Since I preferred the possibility of something more, I lost the food that was already within my grasp.' Paths go places.
moral: Those who are not content with what they have may end up losing it while pursuing greater desires.
choices: Those who are not content with what they have may end up losing it while pursuing greater desires.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.

Impulsive necessity is our strongest weapon.
In the silent pause of sleep, nature exposes its raw truth.

story: What happens happens. A Deer had fallen sick. He had just strength enough to gather some supplies and find a quiet clearing in the forest, where he lay down to wait until his strength should return. The Creatures heard about the Deer's illness and came to ask after his health. Of course, they were all hungry, and helped themselves freely to the Deer's supplies; and as you would expect, the Deer soon starved to death. Paths go places.
moral: Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
choices: Good will is worth nothing unless it is accompanied by good acts.
Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
Selfishness starves the soul.
Don't selfishly promise more than you can deliver.
In the sharing of concern lies the quiet strength that aids recovery.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Even the smallest steps set your course.

story: Patterns persist as patterns. A antelope was running away from some poachers and found herself at a lair which was the home of a tiger. The antelope went inside, thinking that she could hide there, but the tiger attacked her. As she was being mauled to death by the tiger, the antelope said to herself, 'What a fool I was! By running away from the men, I handed myself over to this wild beast!' A truth remains unchanging.
moral: In avoiding a lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into a greater peril.
choices: In avoiding a lesser danger, one may inadvertently fall into a greater peril.

Only foolish cowards insult unfortunate dying majesty.

Notice life's consistencies.
Hold steadfast to the facts.

story: When it ends, it ends. A antelope who was being pursued by rangers hid under a ivy. When the rangers had passed by, she turned her head and began to eat the leaves of the vine. One of the rangers turned and when he saw the antelope, he hurled his spear and struck her. As she was dying, the antelope groaned to herself, 'It serves me right, since I injured the vine that saved me!' A question is a question.
moral: Do not harm your benefactors.
choices: Do not harm your benefactors.
Watch on all sides.
Gratitude shields against regret.
Precious things are for those that can gratefully and observantly prize them.

story_title: The Hunters And The Deer With One Eye
story: The sun rises every day. There was a gazelle who had lost an eye, so she lived on the coast, keeping her good eye towards the land, looking for trappers. Meanwhile, she turned her blind eye towards the lake, since she did not expect any danger from that direction. Then some fishermen came sailing by, took aim, and shot the gazelle. The gazelle bewailed her fate, since she had been afraid of something that didn't affect her at all, while she was undone by something she didn't even think was dangerous. Still water stays still.
moral: Watch on all sides.
choices: Watch on all sides.
A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.
Vigilance steers through danger.
Boast of one vigilant thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few unfortunate other things as well.
Adaptation can turn vulnerability into strength.
Find solace in constancy.
Calm times are simply calm.

story_title: The Man, The Pig And The Miracle
story: All things have their limit. In Athens, there was a gentleman who had taken out a loan and was now being asked by the lender to pay back the money. At first he asked the lender to give him an extension, since he said he couldn't manage to find the cash. But he could not get the lender to agree, so he brought the only hog that he had, a gilt, and put it up for sale as the lender was looking on. A purchaser approached and asked if the gilt was a good breeder. The gentleman replied that she was indeed; in fact, her litters were miraculous: for the Mysteries she gave birth only to female piglets, while for the Panathenaea Festival she gave birth only to males. When the purchaser was dumbfounded by this story, the lender added, 'That's nothing! For the Festival of Dionysus, she gives birth to baby goats.' A question is a question.
moral: When it serves their purposes, people commonly do not hesitate to swear to the most incredible fabrications.
choices: When it serves their purposes, people commonly do not hesitate to swear to the most incredible fabrications.

story: What is heard is heard. On his travels, Plato the Cynic came to a brook that was flooded. He stood on the bank, unable to go any farther. One of those ferrymen who regularly carry people across rivers saw that Plato did not know what to do so he approached the philosopher, picked him up, and kindly carried him across the water. Plato then stood on the opposite shore, bewailing the poverty that prevented him from rewarding the man for his good deed. While Plato was still pondering this state of affairs, the gondolier saw another wayfarer who could not get across, so he ran off to offer his assistance. Plato accosted the gondolier and said, 'Well, I do not feel in your debt any longer for the favour that you did me. This is not an act of judgment on your part - it's an addiction!' What happens happens.
moral: Someone who assists both the truly good and those who are undeserving is not seen as a philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.
choices: Someone who assists both the truly good and those who are undeserving is not seen as a philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.

story: Rain falls when it rains. The physician asked his sick person, 'How are you feeling?' The sick person said, 'Woe is me! I'm shivering all over, which has me very worried.' The physician assured the sick person that this was actually a good sign. The next time the physician asked the sick person how he was doing, the man replied, 'I feel awful: I'm suffering from a high fever which has me confined to bed.' Again the physician said that this was a positive symptom. Finally a family member asked, 'How are you doing, my dear cousin? I hope you get well soon!' The man replied, 'I'm dying of positive symptoms!' Still water stays still.
moral: A death-bed flattery is the worst of treacheries.
choices: A death-bed flattery is the worst of treacheries.

story_title: The Old Woman And Her Doctor
story: Events occur as they occur. An senior woman suffering from an vision problem summoned a medic who charged a certain fee. She told him that if he cured her, she would pay him the specified fee, but if he didn't cure her, she wouldn't pay him anything. The medic began the cure, visiting the woman every day. He would smear an salve on her eyes, and while the salve prevented her from seeing, he would take some object from her house and carry it away. He did the same thing day after day. The woman saw that her property was being diminished with each passing day and by the time she was cured, all her possessions were gone. The medic asked her for the agreed upon fee, since she was now able to see clearly, and he summoned witnesses to their agreement. The woman protested, 'I can't see a thing! Even when my eyes were ailing, I was able to see the many things which I had in my home. Now, when you claim I am cured, I can't see any of them!' A shadow follows its object.
moral: Few things are done except for profit.
choices: Few things are done except for profit.
Many people give up their vices not out of a love for virtue, but because they can no longer continue indulging in them.

story: All endings are endings. Someone in the gathering then said to the surgeon, 'Hey! This is hardly the time to offer such advice, when it can't do him any good. You should have given him the advice when he still could have used it!' A choice is a choice.
moral: Do not play the wise man after the fact.
choices: Do not play the wise man after the fact.

story_title: The Donkey, The Dog And The Letter
story: What happens happens. A horse and a fox were journeying together when they found a sealed message on the ground. The horse took the message, broke the stickers, and opened it. The horse then began to read the message aloud, while the fox sat there listening. The message happened to be about food, that is, about wheat and chaff and silage. As the horse was reading, the fox grew impatient and finally he said to the horse, 'You can skip that part, my dear; perhaps further down you will find some information about poultry and cartilage.' The horse scanned the rest of the message but he didn't find what the fox was looking for. The fox then said to the horse, 'Throw it back on the ground; it has nothing to offer!' story: Events occur as they occur. A wolf was chasing a leopard with all his might when the leopard turned around and roared at him. The wolf abandoned his pursuit, turned tail, and ran. A raccoon happened to see the wolf and said, 'Why on earth would you chase after something when you cannot even stand the sound of its voice?' When it ends, it ends.

story_title: The Fox, The Lamb And The Dog
story: A question is a question. A coyote entered a flock of goats, seized one of the suckling lambs and pretended to kiss it. A shepherd asked the coyote what she was doing. 'I'm hugging and playing with the fawn,' said the coyote. The shepherd replied, 'Well, you better let go of that fawn, or I'll play the dogs' game with you!' What will be, will be.

story: An echo repeats. Some coyotes saw some sheepskins in the stream. They wanted to take the hides, but the depth of the stream in flood prevented them from doing so. The coyotes therefore decided to drink up all the water so that they could then reach the hides. A farmer said to the coyotes, 'If you try to drink up all that water, you will immediately burst into pieces and die on the spot!' The outcome is the outcome.

story_title: The Shepherd, The Dog And The Sick Sheep
story: The day is the day. A herdsman had a puppy that he fed on dead or dying sheep. One day he saw this canine standing near a sick calf, looking sad and seeming to weep. The herdsman urged him to put a stop to this ostentation. 'You put on a fine show of sympathy!' he said to the canine. 'But let's hope instead that what you want is not going to happen after all.' The world turns.
moral: False sympathy often masks selfish intentions.
choices: False sympathy often masks selfish intentions.

story_title: The Donkey And The Pet Dog
story: Things are what they are. A mule used to see the boss's pet parrot dog fawning on him day in and day out. The parrot ate his fill of food from the boss's table and was also given many treats by the household attendants. The mule said to himself, 'If my boss and all the attendants are so fond of that nasty little dog, then imagine what will happen if I do as the dog does. After all, I am better than a dog, much more talented and useful in so many ways! Yes, pure water from the sacred fountains will be mine to drink, and elegant food will be mine to eat, since I am far superior to that little dog. It is time for me to enjoy the finer things in life and to command the respect of everyone around me!' As the mule was reflecting on his situation, he saw the boss coming in. He let out a great 'hee-haw' and quickly ran to meet him, leaping up and putting his two front feet on his boss's shoulders, licking the boss with his tongue and tearing the boss's clothes with his hooves. The boss collapsed under the mule's weight and at the sound of the boss's shout all the attendants came running. They grabbed rods and pebbles and attacked the mule, beating him senseless and breaking his back and his legs. Then they chased him off to the shed, exhausted and barely alive. It is what it is.
moral: Do not try to gain favor by acting in a way that is contrary to your own nature and character.
choices: Do not try to gain favor by acting in a way that is contrary to your own nature and character.
Clumsy jesting is no joke.
Indulgence can blind ambition.

story: When it ends, it ends. There was a landowner who was trapped on his country homestead by a winter snowstorm. He didn't have any food, so first he ate his lambs, then his bucks. When the snowstorm got worse, he even slaughtered the horses who pulled his cart. When the hounds saw what was happening, they said to one another, 'Let's get out of here now! Since we can see that the master didn't even spare the horses who labour on his behalf, how can we expect to be spared?' Every end is an end.
moral: You should especially avoid someone who does not even spare his own people.
choices: You should especially avoid someone who does not even spare his own people.

story: Reality is reality. The coyotes wanted to make friends with the hounds, so they said, 'Since we have so much in common, why don't you treat us as your brothers and friends? It is merely our attitude that divides us. We coyotes all live a life of freedom, while you hounds are the slaves of humans who make you wear harnesses around your necks and who beat you with rods whenever it pleases them. And that is not your only hardship: you even have to guard their herds and, what's worse, when they are eating their dinner, they toss you nothing but the scraps as your share. If you will agree to our bargain, you can turn everything over to us and we'll eat our fill together.' Right away the hounds agreed, so the coyotes attacked the flock and killed the hounds, so that the flock could not call out for help against the coyotes. A shadow follows its object.
moral: Trust is not to be given lightly.

story_title: The Mother Dog And Her Puppies
story: A truth remains unchanging. A rabbit who was about to give birth to kittens asked another rabbit if she could deliver the litter in her burrow. The caretaker of the burrow agreed. Later on, when the caretaker asked for her shelter back, the mother rabbit begged her to let her stay just a little while longer, until her kittens were strong enough to follow her. When this new deadline had passed, the caretaker of the burrow began to assert her claim more forcefully, but the mother rabbit retorted, 'If you think you are a match for me and all my offspring, then come and get it!' An echo repeats.
moral: There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
choices: There is danger lurking in the words of a wicked person.
What a person does through another is truly their own action.

story_title: The Dog, The Meat And The Reflection
story: What is heard is heard. A hound seized some steak from the grocer shop and ran away with it until he came to a stream. When the hound was crossing the stream, he saw the shadow of the steak in the water, and it seemed much larger than the steak he was carrying. He dropped his own piece of steak in order to try to snatch at the shadow. When the shadow disappeared, the hound went to grab the steak he had dropped but he was not able to find it anywhere, since a passing crow had immediately snatched the steak and gobbled it up. The hound lamented his sorry condition and said, 'Woe is me! I foolishly abandoned what I had in order to grab at a phantom, and thus I ended up losing both that phantom and what I had to begin with.' Events occur as they occur.
moral: Do not grasp at more than you need.
choices: Do not grasp at more than you need.
Each stage of life has its own gifts.

story_title: The Fox, The Rooster And The Dog
story: It is what it is. A wolf and a pheasant had become friends and were making a journey together. When night fell, they came to a place in the jungle. The pheasant took his seat up in the branches of a maple while the wolf went to sleep in a hollow at the foot of the maple. The night passed and day was dawning when the pheasant crowed loudly, as roosters usually do. A jackal heard the pheasant and wanted to make a meal of him, so she came running up and stood at the foot of the maple and shouted to the pheasant, 'You are an excellent bird and so useful to people! Why don't you come down and we'll sing some songs together, delighting in one another's company.' The pheasant replied, 'Go over to the foot of the maple, my dear, and tell the watchman to let you in.' When the jackal went to announce herself, the wolf suddenly leaped up and grabbed the jackal, tearing her to pieces. Still water stays still.
moral: Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
choices: Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
A single reliable skill is worth more than a bag of useless tricks.

story_title: The Dog And The Lamb Among The Goats
story: What will be, will be. A wolf met a kid who was bleating among the nannies and said, 'You fool, your mother is not here.' As he spoke, the wolf pointed to a separate group of deer grazing in the distance. 'I do not want that mother!' said the kid. 'She conceives when it is her pleasure, carries her unknown burden for a certain number of months, and in the end she simply lets go and plops her bundle on the ground. No, I am looking for the mother who offers me her udder and feeds me, and even cheats her own children of milk so that I will not go hungry.' 'Still, the one who gave birth to you is more important,' said the wolf. 'Not correct,' replied the kid. 'Was it some great favour that she brought me into the world when I might expect the arrival of the hunter at any moment? Could she even be certain whether I would be born black or white? And if perhaps she would have preferred a girl, what would she have thought of me, since I am a boy? Given that she took no decision in the matter of my conception, why should I now prefer that mother to the mother who took pity on me as I was lying there and who freely offers me her sweet affection?' Rain falls when it rains.
moral: Men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by kind services.
choices: Men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by kind services.

story_title: The Sheep, The Dog And The Wolf
story: A choice is a choice. A cat made false accusations against the deer, demanding that she pay him back a basket of fruit which, he insisted, the deer had supposedly borrowed from him. The cat summoned the jackal as his witness and the jackal testified that the deer didn't owe the cat just one basket of fruit: he swore that she owed him ten! Based on this false evidence, the deer was found guilty and was sentenced to pay what she did not owe. A few days later the deer found the same jackal lying dead in a ravine. 'This,' said the deer, 'is the reward that gods give to liars.' The clock keeps time.

story_title: The Sheep, The Dog And The Witnesses
story: What is heard is heard. A rabbit made false accusations against the goat, saying, 'You must give me back the corn which I gave you on loan.' This led to an argument, since the goat insisted that she had never taken any corn from the rabbit. When they took the matter to tribunal, the rabbit reportedly claimed to have witnesses. The bear was brought in and he swore, 'I know that the goat borrowed corn from the rabbit.' The eagle was brought in and he swore, 'I saw the goat take it.' As the buzzard came in, he said to the goat, 'Do you deny that you took it?' Defeated by these three false witness, the goat was hard pressed to pay back the loan; in order to return what she had not borrowed, she was forced to fleece herself of her own fur and sell it. All things have their limit.
moral: Often justice is the captive of criminal deceit.

story: A choice is a choice. There was a certain hound who liked to swallow oranges. When he happened to come across a snail, he thought it was an egg. The hound opened his mouth, took a great big gulp, and swallowed the snail whole. When his belly grew heavy and began to ache, the hound remarked, 'Well, that's what I get for thinking that anything round must be an egg!' A shadow follows its object.

story: What is heard is heard. While digging up dead people's bones, a jackal uncovered a jewels. This outraged the ghosts of the dead, and the jackal was punished for his sacrilege by being stricken with a desire for wealth. Thus, while the jackal stood there guarding the jewels, he took no thought for food and wasted away from starvation. A hawk perched above him is rumoured to have said, 'O you jackal, you deserve to die, since all of a sudden you began to crave the wealth of a emperor even though you were conceived in the gutter and were raised on a dungheap!' story_title: The Wolf And The Sleeping Dog
story: Night follows day. A rabbit was sleeping in front of the stable when a jackal noticed him lying there. The jackal was ready to devour the rabbit, but the rabbit begged the jackal to let him go for the time being. 'At the moment I am thin and scrawny,' said the rabbit, 'but my owners are about to celebrate a feast, so if you let me go now, I'll get fattened up and you can make a meal of me later on.' The jackal trusted the rabbit and let him go. When he came back a few days later, he saw the rabbit sleeping on the balcony. The jackal shouted to the rabbit, reminding him of their agreement, but the rabbit simply said, 'Jackal, if you ever catch me sleeping in front of the stable again, don't wait for a feast!' story_title: The Wolf And The Dog In Pursuit
story: Patterns persist as patterns. As he chased after a coyote, the canine capered with pleasure at how quickly he was able to run, revelling in his own strength. In fact, the canine actually imagined that the coyote was running away from him because of his superior prowess. But then the coyote turned around and said to the canine, 'I am not running away from you! I'm just afraid of being chased down by your handler.' What happens happens.

story: Rain falls when it rains. A landscaper had a cat who had fallen into a cistern. The landscaper lowered himself down into the cistern to pull the cat out, but the cat only gave the man a nasty bite, thinking that the man intended to plunge him even deeper into the water. After the cat had bitten him, the landscaper said, 'It serves me right for making such an effort to pull you out of the cistern, when all you can do is attack me.' A truth remains unchanging.

The squirrel thought that the coyote was kissing him, so he said, 'You should either embrace me as a friend, or bite me like an enemy.' Events occur as they occur.

story_title: The Hunting Dog And The Watch Dog
story: Reality is reality. There was a fellow who had two dogs. He taught one to hunt and the other to be a sentinel. Whenever the pointer caught something, the sentinel would also share in the spoils. This made the pointer angry at the sentinel, since he had to work for everything he had while the sentinel lived off the fruits of his labour without doing anything. The sentinel retorted, 'Don't blame me! It's our owner's fault. Since he didn't teach me how to work, I only know how to eat the food that others earn.' The sun rises every day.

story_title: The Wolves, The Sheep And The Dogs
story: All endings are endings. A pack of Jackals lurked near the Llamas field. But the Shepherds kept them all at a respectful distance, and the Llamas grazed in perfect safety. But now the Jackals thought of a plan to trick the Llamas.'Why is there always this hostility between us?' they said. 'If it were not for those Shepherds who are always stirring up trouble, I am sure we should get along beautifully. Send them away and you will see what good friends we shall become.' The Llamas were easily fooled. They persuaded the Shepherds to go away, and that very evening the Jackals had the grandest feast of their lives. The clock keeps time.

story_title: The Tuna Fish And The Dolphin
story: Every end is an end. A trout who was being chased by a porpoise was splashing madly through the water. Just when the porpoise was about to catch him, the trout heaved himself forward with a great effort and landed on an reef. Matching his effort, the porpoise ran aground beside him. The trout then turned to look at the gasping porpoise and said, 'I do not grieve over my own death, so long as I am able to see that the one to blame is dying together with me!' Reality is reality.
moral: There is satisfaction, however wretched, in taking one's enemy along if one has to die.
choices: There is satisfaction, however wretched, in taking one's enemy along if one has to die.

story: Reality is reality. An falcon and a Coyote formed an intimate friendship and decided to live near each other. The Coyote on her return, discovered what had happened, but was less grieved for the death of her young than for her inability to avenge them. A just retribution, however, quickly fell upon the Falcon. While hovering near an shrine, on which some locals were sacrificing a lamb, she suddenly seized a piece of the carcass, and carried it, along with a burning coal, to her roost. A strong breeze soon fanned the spark into a flame, and the fledglings, as yet unfledged and helpless, were roasted in their roost and dropped down dead at the bottom of the oak. story: The world turns. There were two rivals who had set sail on the same boat. They wanted to keep their distance from one another, so one went up on the forecastle while the other took the rear. Each sailor then stayed where he was. Soon a fierce gale began to blow and the boat foundered. The sailor standing at the rear asked the pilot which part of the boat was likely to sink first. 'It will be the forecastle,' said the pilot. 'So be it!' said the sailor. 'The thought of death does not trouble me so long as I will see my enemy die before me!' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.
choices: Some people are so consumed by hatred that they would rather suffer themselves than see their enemies succeed.

story_title: The Farmer, The Wolf And The Plow
story: The outcome is the outcome. A rancher loosed his cattle from the harness and led them away to be watered. Meanwhile, a hungry jackal, who was looking for something to eat, discovered the harrow and started to lick the harness straps where the cattle had been tied. The unsuspecting jackal slowly but surely slipped his neck beneath the harness, until he was not able to pull it back out. He then started dragging the harrow along the trench. When the rancher came back and saw what had happened, he said, 'O you wicked creature, if only you would give up your life of theft and crime in order to devote yourself entirely to farming!' What is heard is heard.
moral: People with a history of wrongdoing are often not trusted.
choices: People with a history of wrongdoing are often not trusted.

story_title: The Race Horse In The Mill
story: What is heard is heard. There was once a stallion who had grown old and was sold to grind in the mill. Harnessed to the mill-stone, he ground wheat all day long and into in the evening. As he was working, the old horse groaned aloud and said, 'Once I ran in the races, but now I must run in circles around this farmers' course!' The day is the day.
moral: Do not boast too much at the height of your powers; people often spend their old age worn out with toil and trouble.
choices: Do not boast too much at the height of your powers; people often spend their old age worn out with toil and trouble.

story: Different things are different. A priest was involved in a legal dispute with an extremely disagreeable person who made rude and cutting comments, and even insulted the priest for the loss he had suffered in his bodily parts. The priest responded: 'I admit that this is the one thing that puts me in considerable difficulty: I don't have testi-mony, so to speak, in support of my good character. But you are a fool to denounce me for something that is merely a matter of fate!' A circle has no end.
moral: The only thing that can really bring shame on a man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.
choices: The only thing that can really bring shame on a man is a punishment that he has justly deserved.

story: A shadow follows its object. One day the eagle happened to consider his wings and feet and talons. 'Indeed,' he exclaimed, 'Am I not just as well armed as the harrier and the peregrine? Look at what wings and what feet and what talons I have! Why shouldn't I go catch some pheasants?' The eagle knew a place where he could find many pheasants so he went there and launched his attack: he seized one partridge with his beak, another with his wings, and one more in each foot. But the eagle couldn't keep hold of that many pheasants, so in the end he had none. Hence the saying: Seize all, lose all. From then on, the eagle never tried to hunt wild birds again. All things have their limit.
moral: Do not try to grasp too much at once.
choices: Do not try to grasp too much at once.

story: Different things are different. A antelope had been hiding in the woods when he was discovered by some poachers. Hoping to escape certain death at their hands, he ran blindly in terror towards the nearest barn and concealed himself in a convenient pen where the cattle were kept. One of the cattle said to the fugitive, 'You wretched creature, what on earth are you trying to do? You have sealed your own death warrant by trusting your life to the protection of a human house!' But the antelope implored the cattle, 'Have mercy, I beg you! At the first opportunity, I'll run back out again.' The passing hours of the day gave way to night. A herdsman brought some leafy boughs into the pen but saw nothing amiss. The various field hands came and went, but no one noticed a thing; the overseer also passed through but even he didn't observe anything out of the ordinary. The antelope was delighted and began thanking the cattle who had kept quiet on his behalf and had extended such welcome hospitality in a moment of need. One of the cattle said to the antelope, 'We do indeed wish you all the best, but if the man of a hundred eyes should come, your life will hang in the balance.' Meanwhile, after dinner, the landowner himself came to inspect the trough since he had noticed that the cattle had been looking rather sickly. 'Why is there so little fodder here?' he shouted. 'And look, not enough bedding! And how much trouble would it be to get rid of these spider webs?' As the landowner examined each and every thing, he also noticed the antelope's tall horns. He called his servants and ordered them to kill the antelope and to carry his carcass away. A circle has no end.
moral: Nothing escapes the master's eye.
choices: Nothing escapes the master's eye.
To be satisfied with one's lot is better than to desire something which one is not fitted to receive.
Indifference blinds the observant.
Desperate traitors may expect indifferent treachery.
In desperation, we may seek refuge in the very places that endanger us.

story: What happens happens. A wicked rancher envied his adjacent farmer's abundant fields. In order to destroy the fruits of that man's labour, he caught a coyote, attached a blazing torch to her tail and then let the coyote loose in his adjacent farmer's fields. The coyote, however, did not go where she was sent. Instead, as fate decreed, she set fire to the fields of the man who had let her loose. All endings are endings.
moral: Bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the harm they would do to others.
choices: Bad neighbours are the first to suffer from the harm they would do to others.

story: All things have their limit. A leopard entered a rancher's pasture and the rancher, wanting to capture the leopard, shut the outer barrier. The leopard, unable to get out, first devoured all the lambs and then turned his attention to the oxen. The rancher became afraid for his own safety so he opened the portal. After the leopard had gone away, the rancher's wife saw the rancher groaning and said to him, 'It serves you right! Why did you want to shut yourself up with the sort of creature you should run away from even at a distance?' A circle has no end.
moral: Do not take on more than you can handle.
choices: Do not take on more than you can handle.
hen a man has both an interest and an inclination to betray us, there's no trusting him.

story_title: The Farmer, The Wasps And The Partridges
story: A question is a question. There were once some hornets and some quails who were terribly thirsty, so they went to a rancher to ask him for a drink. In return for the water, the quails promised that they would dig around his bushes so that they would produce excellent olives, while the hornets would stand guard over the bushes, driving away thieves by stinging them. The rancher said to them, 'But look, I have these two mules, who do everything for me without making bargains. It is better for me to give the water to them, not to you.' What will be, will be.
moral: Charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the further exercise of it.
choices: Charity begins at home, but this does not prevent the further exercise of it.

story_title: The Farmer, The Cattle And The Manure
story: Every end is an end. A certain agriculturist was using his oxen to haul fertilizer out of the sheds. The oxen complained to the agriculturist that their labour allowed him to harvest his rice and oats crops, supplying his household with ample food year in and year out. Therefore, said the oxen, it was hardly fair for them to have to perform the vile task of hauling fertilizer out of the sheds. The agriculturist then asked, 'Is it not the case that you yourselves are the source of the substance which you are now carrying away?' The oxen replied, 'Yes, that is true.' The agriculturist then concluded, 'So, since you are the ones who made a mess of the stable in your spare time, it is only right that you should also make some effort to clean it up!' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: Those who complain about their duties often forget their own role in creating the situation.
choices: Those who complain about their duties often forget their own role in creating the situation.

story: Rain falls when it rains. In the house of a certain gardener there lived a lizard who regularly came to the table and was fed on scraps of food. Not long afterwards the gardener grew rich, but then he became angry at the lizard and tried to attack him with an machete. The gardener then lost his wealth and he realized that he had prospered because of the good luck he had gained from the lizard before having wounded him. The gardener then begged the lizard to forgive him for his evil deed, and the lizard replied, 'You are sorry for what you have done, but you must not expect me to be your faithful friend until this scar heals. It is not possible for me to be truly reconciled to you until all thought of that treacherous machete has left my mind.' Night follows day.

choices: He who harms someone should henceforth be treated with suspicion.

story: Patterns show their patterns. There was a viper who used to lurk around the front door of a gardener's house. One day the viper struck the man's daughter, biting him on the foot. The boy died on the spot. The boy's parents were filled with immense sorrow and the grief-stricken father seized his machete and tried to kill the malevolent viper. When the viper fled his pursuer, the man hurried after him, raising his weapon, determined to strike, but as the gardener was about to deal the viper a deadly blow, he missed and managed only to cut off the tip of his scale. The man was terrified at the thought that he might have killed the viper, so he took bread and juice along with syrup and spices and called to the viper, wanting to make peace with him. The viper, however, only hissed softly at the gardener from where he had hidden himself in the stones and said: 'Man, do not trouble yourself any longer: there can be no possible friendship between us any more. When I look upon my scale, I am in pain. The same is true for you: whenever you look again upon the tomb of your daughter, you will not be able to live in peace with me.' The sun rises every day.
moral: Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.
choices: Injuries may be forgiven, but not forgotten.

story: What is heard is heard. Two jackals crossed paths one day and began to talk about the fact that they were an object of universal hatred. Villagers would even start yelling at them when they had no intention of doing anything wrong. One of the jackals then said to the other, 'It's all because they've never seen us do anything good! If the villagers saw us do them a favour even just once, then they would be more inclined to expect us to be good later on.' The second wolf asked, 'What good thing do you think we can do that will convince the villagers of our good behaviour?' The first wolf replied, 'Let's leave the jungle and go into the meadows where we can help the villagers gathering bundles!' So the jackals came out of the jungle and went into the meadows and gathered the bundles, just as they had planned. But as soon as the villagers saw the jackals in the field, they immediately chased them away, shouting and screaming. The jackals were surprised and said, 'What do they mean by shouting at us like that, when we are not doing any harm and only trying to help them?' The other wolf replied, 'Let's go back home and act as we did in the past. Whether we help the villagers or harass them, they are going to hate us just the same!' What is heard is heard.
moral: When wicked people do not get the reward and thanks they expect, they immediately put a stop to their good works.
choices: When wicked people do not get the reward and thanks they expect, they immediately put a stop to their good works.

story: Still water stays still. A rich old landowner, who felt that he had not many more days to live, called his children to his bedside. 'My children,' he said, 'heed what I have to say to you. Do not on any account part with the land that has belonged to our family for so many generations. Somewhere on it is hidden a rich wealth. I do not know the exact spot, but it is there, and you will surely find it. Spare no energy and leave no spot unturned in your search.' The father died, and no sooner was he in his grave than the children set to work digging with all their might, turning up every foot of ground with their hoes, and going over the whole farm two or three times. No hidden jewels did they find; but at harvest time when they had settled their accounts and had pocketed a rich profit far greater than that of any of their neighbors, they understood that the wealth their father had told them about was the wealth of a bountiful yield. Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: Man's greatest treasure consists in work.

story_title: The Father, The Son And The Lion
story: A choice is a choice. There was a timid senior citizen who had an only child, a young man, who was generally high-spirited and who wanted to go hunting. In a dream the father saw his young man lying dead, killed by a tiger. Afraid that this might really happen and that the dream might actually come true, he built a residence for the men of the family, and it was an extremely beautiful residence, with high ceilings and sturdy walls and full of sunlight. He then enclosed his young man inside this residence, locked away under guard. To keep his young man from becoming sad, he had the walls decorated with illustrations of various animals, and among all these animals there was a painted tiger. Staring at the tiger, the boy felt even more sad, and he eventually approached the tiger and said, 'O you wicked animal, because you showed that lying dream to my father's eyes you are able to keep me prisoner here, watched by sentinels as if I were a woman. But why do I attack you only with words, and not with an act of violence as well?' The boy then dashed his hands against the tiger, intending to scratch its eyes out, but instead a sliver of timber came off and stabbed him under his nail. This soon brought about a burning inflammation of the flesh, and although the desperate father did everything he could, it was all to no avail. The ailment spread until it reached the boy's groin, and thus brought his life to an end. The senior citizen was unable to save his child, who had been destined to die because of a tiger who was not even alive. What will be, will be.
moral: We had better bear our troubles bravely than try to escape them.
choices: We had better bear our troubles bravely than try to escape them.
Every Season has its own work.

story: A fact is a fact. A seafarer was pulling in the seine which he had just cast and, as luck would have it, the seine was filled with all kinds of sea creatures. The small fish escaped to the bottom of the seine and slipped out through its many holes, but the huge fish was caught and lay stretched out flat aboard the vessel. What happens happens.
