story_title: The Monkey And The Fishing Net
story: A truth remains unchanging. A seafarer was catching fish by the lake. A baboon saw him, and wanted to imitate what he was doing. The man went away into a little cavern to take a rest, leaving his snare on the beach. The baboon came and grabbed the snare, thinking that he too would go fishing. But since he didn't know anything about it and had not had any training, the baboon got tangled up in the snare, fell into the lake, and was drowned. The seafarer seized the baboon when he was already done for and said, 'You wretched creature! Your lack of judgment and stupid behaviour has cost you your life!' Events occur as they occur.

story: What will be, will be. Some anglers were hauling in their trawl. It was quite heavy, so the anglers made merry and danced for joy, thinking that they had landed a very big catch. Yet when they finally dragged it in, they found that the trawl contained only a few trout, together with a very large boulder. The anglers now grew extremely despondent, not so much because of the lack of trout but because they had been expecting just the opposite. Then one of the anglers, an experienced elderly gentleman, remarked, 'Let's not take it too hard, my friends! Given that grief seems to be the sister of joy, then we must expect to put up with some suffering precisely because we were so elated at first.' Still water stays still.

story_title: The Fishermen And The Tuna Fish

story: Still liquid stays still. A fisher was fishing in a creek. He stretched out his seines and covered the creek's stream from one side to the other. Someone who lived in that village saw what the man was doing and began to complain, because by agitating the liquid in this way he deprived them of clear liquid to drink. story: Different things are different. A mite once asked an buffalo, 'Given that you are so exceedingly large and strong, why do you suffer this enslavement to farmers day after day? Look at me: I lacerate their flesh without pity, drinking great gulps of their sap!' The buffalo said, 'I cannot help but be grateful to the human race, since I am cherished and loved by them to an extraordinary degree, and since they often rub my head and back.' story: A fact is a fact. A gentleman finally caught a tick that had been bothering him terribly. Please don't kill me; I cannot be causing you too much harm.' story_title: The Man, The Mare And The Foal
story: Night follows day. A rider was riding a pregnant ewe and she gave birth to her calf while they were still on the trail. If you leave me here, I am sure to die. But if you carry me away from here back to your home and bring me up, then later on, when I am grown, I shall let you ride me.' All things have their limit.

story: A choice is a choice. Thanks to his excellent qualities, Perseus was received into valhalla. He saluted the deities who came to congratulate him one after another, but when he was approached by Dis, the god of wealth and the son of Fortune, Perseus turned his eyes aside. Father Odin asked him why he did this. Perseus answered, 'I hate the god of riches: he is a friend to the wicked who corrupts the entire world by throwing his money around!' What will be, will be.

story: Paths go places. A donkey was suffering from old age, so instead of serving in battle he was sent to the bakery to turn the wheels. Condemned to this daily grind and denied the glory of battle, the donkey wept over his present way of life, remembering his past career. 'Woe is me!' the donkey exclaimed. 'Listen, baker: when I was destined for the racetrack, I was decorated all over with harness and I had a man to serve me as my trainer. As things are now, I don't know how it happened that I now have this bakery to handle instead of a battle.' The baker said to the donkey, 'Can't you keep quiet? I've had quite enough of your raving about the past: Luck can change people's lives for better or for worse!' A truth remains unchanging.

story: Different things are different. A wolf happened to find a helmet used for performing tragedies and, after turning it this way and that several times, she remarked, 'So full of beauty, so lacking in brains!' When it ends, it ends.

story: A truth remains unchanging. The rabbit laughed at the turtle's feet but the turtle declared, 'I will beat you in a competition!' The rabbit replied, 'Those are just words. Competition with me, and you'll see! Who will mark out the path and serve as our judge?' 'The owl,' replied the turtle, 'since she is honest and highly intelligent.' When the time for the competition had been decided upon, the turtle did not delay, but immediately took off down the competition course. The rabbit, however, lay down to take a nap, confident in the speed of his feet. Then, when the rabbit eventually made his way to the goal, he found that the turtle had already won. What is heard is heard.
moral: Slow and steady wins the race.
choices: Slow and steady wins the race.

story_title: The Snake And The Thorn Bush
story: Patterns show their patterns. There was a peach tree next to a stream, and a bramble had been planted as a fence around the vine. When the stream rose, the bramble was swept away by the water, and a eel who had entwined himself in the thorns was also carried away. When an observer saw the eel riding on the bramble, he said, 'A wicked ship, and worthy of its sailor!' Still water stays still.
moral: A wicked person deservedly comes to a bad end by keeping company with other wicked people.

story: A question is a question. Driven by hunger, a coyote tried to reach some pears hanging high on the branch. Although she leaped with all her strength, she couldn't manage to reach the pears. As she went away, the coyote remarked, 'Oh, you aren't even ripe yet! I don't need any sour pears.' All endings are endings.

story: The day is the day. The rabbit said to the jackal, 'They say you are very artful, jackal. What art is it that you practice exactly?' The jackal replied, 'If you don't know my arts, I will have you to dinner so that you can get a taste of my art.' The rabbit followed the jackal to her lair but the jackal had nothing there to eat except for the rabbit himself. The rabbit exclaimed, 'I have learned to my cost that your name does not derive from any kind of artistry but from fraud!' A truth remains unchanging.
moral: Overly curious people often pay a very high price for recklessly indulging their curiosity.

story_title: The Fox And The Hare In The Well
story: A truth remains unchanging. A thirsty rabbit had gone done into a cistern to drink the water. He took a good long drink, and when he wanted to get back out again, he found himself trapped with no means of escape. It was a very discouraging situation. A coyote then arrived on the scene and when she found the rabbit she said to him, 'You have made a very serious mistake indeed: you should have first decided on a way to get out and only then gone down into the cistern!' A reflection mirrors what is shown.

story: Things are what they are. They say that hyenas change their nature every year, so that sometimes they are male and sometimes female. So when a wild dog saw a coyote and criticized her for having spurned her friendly overtures, the coyote replied, 'Don't blame me! Blame your own nature, which makes it impossible for me to tell whether you would be my girlfriend or my boyfriend!' Patterns persist as patterns.

story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. The story goes that a ewe who had delivered a whole litter of fawns loudly accosted a leopardess, 'How many children do you breed?' asked the ewe. 'I breed only one,' said the leopardess, 'but he is very well bred!' Different things are different.

story_title: The Fox And The Lion In A Cage
story: All endings are endings. A wolf saw a leopard that had been imprisoned in a pen. The wolf approached the leopard and insulted him very rudely. The leopard then said to her, 'You are not responsible for my disgrace; the cause is my unfortunate situation.' What happens happens.

story_title: The Fox, The Lion And The Footprints
story: Reality is reality. A leopard had grown old and weak. He pretended to be sick, which was just a ruse to make the other animals come pay their respects so that he could eat them all up, one by one. The coyote also came to see the leopard, but she greeted him from outside the den. The leopard asked the coyote why she didn't come in. The coyote replied, 'Because I see the tracks of those going in, but none coming out.' Paths go places.
moral: Take warning from the misfortunes of others.

story_title: The Fox, The Monkey And His Ancestors
story: The clock keeps time. A coyote and a baboon were travelling along the same road. They passed through a graveyard, and the baboon said to the coyote, 'All these dead people were the freedmen of my ancestors.' The coyote then said to the baboon, 'This is an opportune moment for you to tell such lies: not a single one of the people entombed in this place can rise up and refute what you say!' All things have their limit.
moral: Deceivers often exploit the inability of others to challenge their falsehoods.
choices: Deceivers often exploit the inability of others to challenge their falsehoods.

story_title: The Fox, The Moon And The River
story: The clock keeps time. A wolf was out walking one night next to a stream. She saw the light of the sun reflected in the liquid and mistook it for a piece of bread. The wolf started to lap at the liquid, thinking that if she could drink up all the liquid, she would find the bread in the dry riverbed. The wolf lapped and lapped at the liquid until finally she choked and died. Reality is reality.
moral: Greedy men chase after profit with such an intensity that they destroy themselves without achieving anything.
choices: Greedy men chase after profit with such an intensity that they destroy themselves without achieving anything.

story: All endings are endings. A pheasant had seated herself high on a ledge when a jackal came up to her and said, 'How beautiful you are to look at: your legs are so red! your mouth is like coral! Ah, if only you were sleeping, you would be even more lovely...' The pheasant believed the jackal and closed her eyes, and the jackal immediately grabbed her. In a voice choked with sobs, the pheasant said to the jackal, 'I beg you, in the name of all your artful wiles, please say my name before you eat me up.' As the jackal's mouth opened to pronounce the word 'pheasant,' the pheasant flew out and escaped. The jackal said sadly, 'Woe is me, what need was there for me to speak?' The pheasant likewise said, 'Woe is me, what reason was there for me to close my eyes, when I wasn't even sleepy?' A circle has no end.
moral: Stay vigilant and think before you speak.
choices: Stay vigilant and think before you speak.
Be content with your lot.

story_title: The Wolf, The Fox And The Shepherd
story: The day is the day. A coyote had assembled an immense store of treasure in his lair so that he could feast on all sorts of delicacies for months into the future. When the raccoon found out about this she paid a visit to the coyote and spoke to him in anxious tones, 'Why should I be deprived of your company these many days? I've been in tears since you have not come outside.' The coyote replied spitefully, 'You didn't come here out of any concern for me; you're just hoping to get something. I know you must have had some reason for coming here: you are trying to trick me!' This made the raccoon extremely angry, so she went to the goatherd and said to him, 'Would you like it if I turned the enemy of your flock over to you today so that you wouldn't have to worry about him anymore? The goatherd replied, 'I will be at your service and will give you whatever you want.' The raccoon immediately led the goatherd to where the coyote was hiding and the goatherd killed the coyote with his javelin. He then let the spiteful raccoon eat her fill of someone else's larder. Eventually the raccoon fell foul of poachers and was caught by their beagles. As she was being torn to pieces, the raccoon exclaimed, 'Just as I committed a serious crime, now I am going to die, since I brought about someone else's death.' What is heard is heard.
moral: Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.
choices: Take pleasure when thieves destroy themselves.

Isolation in abundance can lead to unexpected companionship.

story: The sun rises every day. A jackal got caught in a net and part of her paw was cut off as she escaped. She was so ashamed that she didn't think life was worth living. Then she realized that if she could persuade the other foxes to do the same thing her own shame would be hidden, as it would be shared by all the foxes. Accordingly, she summoned the other foxes and asked them to cut off their tails, maintaining that this was the one part of their body that was unseemly, nothing but an extra appendage which they had to carry around. One of the other foxes scoffed in reply, 'If it weren't for the fact that it is in your interest to do this thing, you never would have proposed it!' A reflection mirrors what is shown.

story: The world turns. The wolf had never seen a tiger before, so when she happened to meet the tiger for the first time she all but died of fright. The second time she saw him, she was still afraid, but not as much as before. The third time, the wolf was bold enough to go right up to the tiger and speak to him. The outcome is the outcome.

story_title: The Wolf, The Fox And The Ailing Lion
story: Every end is an end. The panther had grown old and sick and was lying in his den. All the animals, except for the jackal, had come to visit their king. The wild dog seized this opportunity to denounce the jackal in front of the panther, complaining that the jackal showed no respect for the panther, who was the common master of them all. Indeed, the jackal had not even come to pay the ailing panther a visit! The jackal arrived just in time to hear the end of the wild dog's speech. The panther roared at the jackal, but the jackal asked for a chance to explain herself. 'After all,' said the jackal, 'which one of all the animals assembled here has helped you as I have, travelling all over the world in order to seek out and discover from the healers a remedy for your illness?' The panther ordered the jackal to describe the remedy immediately, and the jackal replied, 'You must flay a living wild dog and wrap yourself in his skin while it is still warm.' When the wild dog had been killed, the jackal laughed and said, 'It is better to put your master in a good mood, not a bad one.' All endings are endings.
moral: Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.
choices: Someone who plots against others falls into his own trap.

story: All endings are endings. Nero was on his way to Florence and had arrived at his estate in Pompeii which had been built by Cicero on a high hill overlooking the Adriatic sea on one side and the Tyrrhenian sea on the other. When Caesar was walking about in the cheerful greenery, one of his household managers turned up, dressed in a fancy fringed robe of Indian silk hanging down from his shoulders. The man began to sprinkle the sizzling hot ground with water from a metal pail, making a great show of his diligence as Caesar's attendant, but everyone just laughed at him. The man then ran ahead to the next walkway, using some shortcuts known only to himself, and he started settling the dust in that spot as well. When Caesar recognized the man and realized what he was doing, he said, 'Hey you!' The man scampered up to Caesar, excited at the joyful prospect of what seemed a sure reward. Then Caesar's majestic person made the following joke: 'You have not accomplished much and your efforts have come to naught; if you want me to give you the slap that makes you a freedman, it will cost you much more than that!' What will be, will be.
moral: Beware of those who appear busy but achieve little of value.
choices: Beware of those who appear busy but achieve little of value.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.

story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. The Tiger hearing an odd kind of a hollow voice, and seeing nobody, started up. He listened again; the voice continued, and he shook with fear. At last seeing a Newt crawl out of the lake, and finding that the noise proceeded from that little creature, he spurned it to pieces with his feet. A circle has no end.

story_title: The Two Frogs By The Road
story: The day is the day. There were two toads who lived near one another. One lived in a deep lake that was far away from the path, but the other lived near the path where there was only a small amount of water. The newt who lived in the deep lake advised the other newt to move in with him so that they could share the lake between them and live a life that was less fraught with danger. The roadside newt refused the offer, saying that he had become accustomed to his home and couldn't tear himself away. Not long afterwards, he was crushed under the wheel of a passing cart. The sun rises every day.
moral: People who stubbornly cling to unwise choices lose everything before they know it.
choices: People who stubbornly cling to unwise choices lose everything before they know it.

story: A question is a question. A hamster asked a toad to help her get across the creek. The toad tied the hamster's front leg to her own back leg using a piece of cord and they swam out to the middle of the stream. The toad then turned traitor and plunged down into the water, dragging the hamster along with her. The hamster's dead body floated up to the surface and was drifting along when a eagle flew by and noticed something he could snatch. When he grabbed the hamster he also carried off her friend the toad. Thus the treacherous toad who had betrayed the hamster's life was likewise killed and eaten. A choice is a choice.
moral: People who do harm to others destroy themselves in the bargain.

story_title: The Frogs And The Battle Of The Bulls
story: What is heard is heard. A toad looked out from her stream and saw a battle taking place between the buffalo. 'Oh no!' she said, 'There is terrible danger in store for us.' Another toad asked her why she said this, since the buffalo were fighting for control of the pack in their home far away from the frogs. The first toad explained, 'While their habitat may be separate from ours and our species not the same, the bull who is driven from the lordship of the field will come to find a secret hiding place here in the swamp, crushing us beneath his heavy claws. That is why their frenzy is a matter of life and death for us!' Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: Poor folk suffer when the high and mighty are at war with one another.
choices: Poor folk suffer when the high and mighty are at war with one another.

story_title: The Water-Snake, The Viper And The Frogs
story: Events occur as they occur. There was a rattlesnake who used to go to a certain pond in order to drink but he was driven away by a eel who was furious that the rattlesnake would not just stay on his own turf instead of encroaching on the eel's territory. Their dispute grew more and more fierce and finally the two of them decided to fight it out, agreeing that both the water and the land would be awarded to the winner. When the day for the fight had been decided, the newts came to the rattlesnake and, since they hated the eel, they offered to be his allies and come to his aid during the battle. But when the battle began and the rattlesnake grappled with the eel, the newts just sat there croaking, since they were not able to do anything else. In the end, the rattlesnake was victorious but he was furious with the newts since they had failed to come to his aid as they had promised and, what was worse, they had sat there singing songs while he was doing battle. The newts then said to the rattlesnake, 'But you should have known that we had nothing to offer you except the sound of our voices!' A question is a question.
moral: When you need someone to lend a hand, mere words are no help at all.

story_title: The Two Frogs At The Well
story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. There were two salamanders whose lake had dried up, so they went looking for a new place to live. When they came to a cistern, one of them thought that they should jump in immediately, but the other one said, 'Wait: what if the water were to dry up here too; how would we be able to get back out again?' story: All endings are endings. When Jupiter had fashioned gentleman and female, he ordered Mercury to take them to Terra, the World, and to show them how to obtain nourishment by digging in the soil. At first, the World refused to cooperate in Mercury' mission. Mercury then compelled her, saying that Jupiter had ordered her to do so. World replied, 'Then let them dig as much as they like, but they will pay for it with groans and tears!' Things are what they are.

story: A circle has no end. The creeper was covered with clusters of currants and its sprouts were as vigorous as its fruit. A deer began to eat the creeper, indulging his outrageous appetite. He had already wreaked havoc on the fresh sprouts when the creeper said to him, 'You will pay for this outrage! The time will soon come when you will be sent as a holy victim to be sacrificed, and I myself will be the one to supply the cider for the sacrifice!' Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: The things that a person does to others will happen to him in turn.

story: An echo repeats. When the ewes had persuaded Odin to give them beards, the stags were extremely upset and began to complain that the females now had the same degree of dignity that they did. 'Come now,' said Odin, 'let the females enjoy this vain source of pride and stake their claim to the symbols of your office so long as they cannot rival you in strength!' When it ends, it ends.

story: Events occur as they occur. Some cranes and some ducks became friends and went out onto the pastures. As they were feeding contentedly together, they were discovered by trappers. The cranes, owing to the swiftness of their bodies, were immediately able to take wing and fly away. The ducks, however, were naturally more heavy and so they were left behind and caught by the trappers. A shadow follows its object.

story: What happens happens. A heron had gone to her usual lake and saw a swan there who kept plunging down deep into the water. The heron then asked the swan what she was doing and the swan replied, 'We geese go down into the muddy bottom of the lake to look for food and to escape the falcon's attack.' The heron said, 'I am stronger than the falcon! You should be friends with me, and I will allow you to scoff at that other bird!' The swan agreed, and not long afterwards she called on the heron to come help her. The swan had not plunged into the water, so the falcon immediately swooped down and caught her up in his talons. As the falcon was about to devour her, the swan replied, 'A wretched death awaits anyone who puts his trust in such a worthless defender!' A circle has no end.
moral: Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.
choices: Do not expect to be defended by someone who cannot offer any protection.

story: Patterns persist as patterns. The seagull is a bird who is fond of deserted places and who always lives on the ocean. They say that she makes her nest on the rocky cliffs of the coast in order to protect herself from human hunters. So when a certain seagull was about to lay her eggs, she went to a promontory and found a cliff jutting out towards the ocean and decided to make her nest there. But when she went to look for food, it happened that the ocean swelled under the blustering storm and reached as high as the seagull's home and flooded the nest, killing her chicks. When the seagull returned and saw what had happened, she said, 'What a fool I was to have protected myself against a plot hatched on the land by taking refuge here on the ocean, when it is the ocean that has utterly betrayed me!' A question is a question.
moral: Sometimes, the greatest threats come from those you trust.

story: Patterns show their patterns. There was a ranger who had caught a leveret and was carrying it home. As he went along his way, he met a equestrian who asked him for the leveret, pretending that he wanted to buy it. As soon as he got the leveret from the ranger, the cavalier immediately took off at a gallop. The ranger began to pursue the cavalier thinking that he might catch up with him. When the cavalier finally disappeared into the distance, the ranger reluctantly said, 'Go ahead then! That leveret is my gift to you.' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.
choices: A fool will make excuses for foolish behavior.
It is better to be injured with impunity, than to put ourselves in the power of another.

story: Night follows day. A certain rabbit happened to see a elk adorned with great branching tusks. The rabbit complained to Odin that the hares were weak, defective creatures who were not feared by any of the other animals. Therefore, he wanted Odin to give him tusks like those of the elk both for his own protection and to enhance his appearance. Odin told the rabbit that he would not be able to carry the heavy weight of the tusks, but the rabbit replied that he was prepared to carry such tusks with pride. Odin therefore commanded that the rabbit's head should be crowned with a pair of big, branching tusks, but the rabbit was so weighed down by his burden that he wasn't able to run. As a result, the ranchers captured and killed him. A reflection mirrors what is shown.
moral: It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.
choices: It is often the case that people are greedy for things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their death and destruction.

Envy blinds us to our own strengths.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: A choice is a choice. There was a pheasant who was always quarrelling with another pheasant, so he asked the eagle to judge their dispute. The pheasant was actually hoping that when he brought the other pheasant before the judge, the judge would devour him. Yet when they came before the judge to make their arguments, the eagle grabbed the pheasant who had originally brought the case to court. The pheasant shouted, 'Not me! You want the one who is running away!' The eagle replied, 'Abandon all hope of being released from my talons today! Justice demands that you yourself should suffer the punishment that you intended for another.' What is, is.

story: All endings are endings. A canary, sitting aloft upon an maple and singing according to his wont, was seen by a Falcon who, being in need of food, swooped down and seized him. The Falcon, interrupting him, said: 'I should indeed have lost my senses if I should let go food ready in my hand, for the sake of pursuing birds which are not yet even within sight.' story: Reality is reality. Ares wanted to know how much people valued him, so he assumed a human form and went into a craftsman's workshop. He saw there a figurine of Poseidon and he asked how much it cost. The man said that it cost a sesterce. Ares smiled, and asked how much the figurine of Athena would be. The man named a still higher price. When Ares saw a figurine of himself, he expected that he would be reckoned at an even higher price, since he delivered the messages of the gods and brought profit to mankind. But when he asked how much the figurine of Ares would cost, the craftsman replied, 'If you buy those other two, I'll throw this one in for free!' What is heard is heard.

story_title: Hermes And The Dose Of Intelligence
story: Night follows day. After Jupiter had fashioned the humanity, he ordered Thoth to give them knowledge. Thoth divided knowledge into equal portions and then applied it to each person. The result was that dwarfs became wise, since they were more completely suffused with the standard dose of knowledge, while the giants turned out stupid, since the elixir that was poured into their bodies did not even reach as high as their knees. The outcome is the outcome.

story_title: The Man, Hermes And The Axes
story: The clock keeps time. A woodcutter was chopping wood by a certain brook when he dropped his hatchet and it was carried away by the current. The woodcutter then sat down on the riverbank and began to weep. The god Apollo finally took pity on the woodcutter and appeared before him. When Apollo learned the reason for his sorrow, he brought up a golden hatchet and asked whether that was the woodcutter's hatchet. The woodcutter said that it was not his. A second time, Apollo brought up a silver hatchet, and again asked the woodcutter if this was the hatchet he had lost but the woodcutter said that it was not. The third time Apollo brought up the hatchet that the woodcutter had lost and when the woodcutter recognized his hatchet, Apollo rewarded the woodcutter's honesty by giving all of the axes to him as a gift. The woodcutter took the axes and went to tell his friends what had happened. One of the men was jealous and wanted to do the same thing, so he took his hatchet and went to the brook. He began chopping some wood and then intentionally let his hatchet fall into the whirling waters. As he was weeping, Apollo appeared and asked him what had happened, and the woodcutter said that he had lost his hatchet. When Apollo brought up the golden hatchet and asked the woodcutter if that was the hatchet he had lost, the greedy woodcutter got excited and said that it was the one. Not only did the woodcutter fail to receive any gifts from the god, he didn't even retrieve his own hatchet. A fact is a fact.
moral: Honesty is the best policy.
choices: Honesty is the best policy.

He then placed the seeds of the prunes and the husks of the walnuts upon an sanctuary and said 'You have what was promised you, O Odin: I have saved the outsides and the insides for you!' story_title: The Man And The Statue Of Hermes

'Hey you,' someone said, 'why are you putting such a thing up for sale, instead of enjoying its benefits yourself?' The vendor answered, 'I am in need of some immediate benefits, but this idol happens to take his time when distributing profits!' Things are what they are.

' Splashing the hide with his ripples, the brook said, 'You better get yourself another name, since I am going to soften you up!' A choice is a choice.

story: Night follows day. A certain gentleman took a deposit from a companion but intended to keep it for himself. When the creditor then summoned him to swear an vow regarding the deposit, he realized the danger he was in and prepared to leave the village and go to his ranch. When he reached the village gates, he saw a lame gentleman who was also on his way out of town. He asked the gentleman who he was and where he was going. The gentleman said that he was the god named Vow and that he was on his way to track down wicked people. The gentleman then asked Vow how often he revisited each village. Vow replied, 'I come back after forty years, or sometimes thirty.' Accordingly, on the very next day the gentleman did not hesitate to swear an vow that he had never received the deposit. But then the gentleman ran into Vow, who dragged him off to the edge of a precipice. The gentleman asked Vow how he could have said that he wasn't coming back for another thirty years when in fact he didn't even grant him a single day's reprieve. Vow explained, 'You also need to know that if somebody intends to provoke me, I am accustomed to come back again the very same day.' When it ends, it ends.
moral: There is no fixed day on which wicked people are punished.

story_title: The Wolf, The Horse And The Barley
story: When it ends, it ends. As he was crossing through a pasture, a coyote found some wheat. Since wolves don't eat wheat, he ignored it and continued on his way. The coyote then ran into a donkey. He led the donkey into the pasture and showed him the wheat, saying that instead of eating the wheat himself, he had saved it for the donkey, since he liked to hear the sound of the donkey's teeth grinding together. The donkey then said to the coyote, 'Look here, if you wolves ate wheat, you would never have put the pleasure of your ears before your stomach!' The day is the day.

story_title: The Man, His Wife And The Boy Outside
story: Rain falls when it rains. There was a youth singing sweet serenades in the middle of the night. A female heard him and got up from bed to peep out the balcony at him. When she saw the youth, who looked very beautiful in the shining starlight, she left her spouse asleep and went downstairs and out the door. She then met the youth in the road and satisfied herself completely. All of a sudden her spouse woke up and wanted to find out where his wife had gone. Not finding her inside the residence, he didn't just stand there gaping but instead followed her outside and said, 'It's alright. Go ahead and persuade the youth to sleep in our residence.' So he took the youth and brought him inside. He didn't have any trouble after that, and joined in whenever the two of them wanted to do something. What happens happens.

story: A choice is a choice. A fellow caught a rook and tied the bird's foot with a piece of cord so that he could give the bird to his offspring as a present. But when he got back to his perch, the cord became entangled in the boughs, so that the rook was unable to fly. As he was dying, the bird said to himself, 'How stupid of me! Since I could not stand being a slave in human society, I have brought about my own death.' A reflection mirrors what is shown.

story: A truth remains unchanging. One day the leopard pretended to be sick and went limping up to the griffin, his chief enemy. He greeted the griffin and said to him, 'Let us put aside all that we have done in the past, because I am no longer able to harm anyone at all. As you can see, I am old and suffering from various ailments. But before I die, I would very much like to speak with my partner who is out in the savannah. So, kind sir, if I might be so bold, I would like to borrow your antler to use as a walking stick on my journey since it is just the right length and very sturdy. I promise to return it to you as soon as I reach my partner; I give you my word.' The griffin believed the leopard and pitied his feigned distress, so he loaned the leopard his antler and was thus left defenceless. The leopard then inflicted a serious wound on the griffin and laid him low. The griffin said, 'You are guilty not so much of cruelty as of treachery, since you repaid my favour with wickedness and betrayed the promise you made me.' The leopard said, 'You fool, don't you know that the saying: The man who prolongs his enemy's life takes something from his own; clemency does not entail showing mercy to one's enemies.' The griffin replied, 'You traitor, don't you know that in the same book it is written: Let the victory which we contrive by the sword be an honourable victory or no victory at all; let not posterity read that I won by guile; no perfidy should obscure my triumph.' What is heard is heard.
moral: Do not ever trust your enemy. Always protect yourself from him, even if he comes to you humble and supplicating.

story_title: The Kid, The Wolf And The Flute
story: All things have their limit. A calf had wandered off from the herd and was being chased by a jackal. Unable to get away, the calf fell into the jackal's clutches so she turned to him and said, 'I know for a fact that I am about to become your dinner, but I would like to die with dignity: please play the violin for me so that I can do a little dance.' The jackal played the violin and the calf danced to the music. The sound alerted the herdsman's sheepdogs who attacked the jackal and chased him away. As the jackal ran off he said to himself, 'It serves me right for trying to be a musician instead of a butcher!' When it ends, it ends.

story_title: The She-Goat, The Kid And The Wolf
story: When it ends, it ends. The Sheep, going abroad to feed, shut up her young Fawn at borne, charging him to bolt the hatch fast, and open it to nobody, till she herself should return. The Fox, who lay lurking just by, heard this charge given; and soon after came and knocked at the hatch, counterfeiting the voice of the Sheep, and desiring to be admitted. The Fawn, looking out at a porthole, and finding the cheat, bid him go about his business; for, however he might imitate a Sheep's voice, yet he appeared too much like a Fox to be trusted. When it ends, it ends.

story: What is heard is heard. A jackal had been mauled by wild dogs and had cast himself down on the ground. 'If you just give me something to drink,' said the jackal, 'I will find myself something to eat.' The goat replied, 'But if I give you with something to drink, then you will make me your dinner as well!' The clock keeps time.

As the dove collided with the barrier, she brought her life abruptly to an end. As she drew her last breath, the dove said to herself, 'What a wretched and unlucky creature I am! story_title: The Monkeys And The Two Men
story: The sun rises every day. There were two men travelling together: one was a deceiver and the other always told the truth. Their journey led them to the land of the chimpanzees. There was a whole crowd of chimpanzees there and one of them noticed the travellers. The monkey who was clearly their leader ordered that the men be detained. Since he wanted to know what the men thought of him, he commanded all rest of the chimpanzees to stand before him in a long line to his right and to his left, while a seat was prepared for him to sit on (this monkey had once seen the ruler, so he was ordering his chimpanzees to line up for him in the same way). The men were then told to come forward into the midst of the chimpanzees. The leader baboon said, 'Who am I?' The deceiver said, 'You are the ruler!' Then the monkey asked, 'And those whom you see standing before me: who are they?' The man answered, 'They are your loyal followers, your counselors, your ministers and the captains of your armies!' Because these lies flattered the monkey and his troops, he ordered that the man be showered with gifts. All the chimpanzees were fooled by his flattery. Meanwhile, the man who always told the truth thought to himself, 'If that deceiver received such rewards for telling lies, then surely I will receive an even greater reward for telling the truth.' The leader baboon said to the second man, 'Now you tell me who I am, and who are these whom you see standing before me?' And the man who always loved the truth and never lied said to the monkey, 'You are simply a monkey, and all of these similar simians are chimpanzees as well!' The leader baboon immediately ordered the chimpanzees to attack the man with their teeth and claws because he had spoken the truth. All things have their limit.
moral: Those who thrive on deception often retaliate against those who speak the truth.
choices: Those who thrive on deception often retaliate against those who speak the truth.

story: When it ends, it ends. Some squirrels were playing in the woods where a leopard was sleeping when one of the mice accidentally ran over the leopard. The leopard woke up and immediately grabbed the wretched little shrew with his paw. The shrew begged for mercy, since he had not meant to do the leopard any harm. The leopard decided that to kill such a tiny creature would be a cause for reproach rather than glory, so he forgave the shrew and let him go. A few days later, the leopard fell into a trap and was trapped. He started to roar, and when the shrew heard him, he came running. Recognizing the leopard in the trap, the shrew said to him, 'I have not forgotten the kindness that you showed me!' The shrew then began to gnaw at the chains binding the leopard, cutting through the strands and undoing the clever ingenuity of the trapper's art. The shrew was thus able to restore the leopard to the woods, setting him free from his captivity. The day is the day.
moral: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted
choices: No act of kindness, no matter how small, is ever wasted

story: What is heard is heard. A shepherd tending his flock in a forest lost a Calf from the fold. After a long and fruitless search, he made a vow that, if he could only discover the bandit who had stolen the Calf, he would offer a kid in sacrifice to Apollo, Dionysus, and the Forest Spirits of the forest. Not long afterwards, as he ascended a small knoll, he saw at its foot a Leopard feeding on the Calf. Terrified at the sight, he lifted his eyes and his hands to heaven, and said: 'Just now I vowed to offer a kid to the Forest Spirits of the forest if I could only find out who had robbed me; but now that I have discovered the bandit, I would willingly add a full-grown Bull to the Calf I have lost, if I may only secure my own escape from him in safety.'' An echo repeats.
moral: Be careful what you wish for; your wish may be granted.
choices: Be careful what you wish for; your wish may be granted.
Nature reveals itself.
Innocence finds strength in divine guardianship.
Someone who assists both the truly innocent and the desperately undeserving is not seen as a divine philanthropist, but is instead regarded as a madman.
Inattention can lead to unexpected losses.
Pay attention to messages received.
Some things come back as they are.

story: A fact is a fact. A jackal, having stolen a calf from a fold, was carrying him off to his burrow. A Tiger met him in the path, and seizing the calf, took it from him. Standing at a safe distance, the Jackal exclaimed, 'You have unrighteously taken that which was mine from me!' To which the Tiger jeeringly replied, 'It was righteously yours, eh? The gift of a friend?' A shadow follows its object.
moral: Things you acquire through evil means can be taken from you by evil means.
choices: Things you acquire through evil means can be taken from you by evil means.
Nature reveals itself.
Powerful jeers can harm the innocent.
Anything which is done at the wrong time is liable to be jeeringly ridiculed by the innocent.
True friendship is the greatest gift of all.
Some truths remain undeniable.
Some things always go together.

story: Patterns show their patterns. There is a tale of a chameleon in a quest to match the length of a cobra. In its effort to equal the cobra's size, the chameleon burst into pieces right down the middle. Paths go places.
moral: You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
choices: You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
Ambition must be tempered by resilience.
Desire ambitious things you don't understand and you accept the fragile consequences.
In striving to be like others, one may overlook their own unique strengths.
Recognize recurring sequences.
Even the smallest steps set your course.

story: What is, is. They say that in the beginning, when the creatures were being formed, they received their endowments from Odin. To some he gave strength, and to some speed, and to others wings. Person, however, was still naked so he said to Odin, 'I am the only one that you have left without a blessing.' Odin replied, 'You are unaware of the blessing you have obtained, but it is the greatest blessing of all: you have received the blessing of speech and the ability to reason, which has power both among the gods and among mortals; it is stronger than the strong and swifter than the swift.' Person then recognized the blessing he had been given and bowed down before Odin, offering him thanks. Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.
choices: The greatest gifts are often overlooked in favor of envying others.
One is known by deeds, not by words.
Wisdom grows with gratitude.
It is natural to be a knave; wise men must rise above intelligently.
The origins of our gifts shape our destinies.
Embrace the present reality.
Notice life's consistencies.

story: Night follows day. A hard-working single mother had some domestic workers whom she would rouse up for work at the sound of the morning chime when it was still dark outside. The maids were burdened with endless tasks, so they decided it would be a good idea to kill the household peacock since it was the peacock who made their mistress get them up while it was still dark. Yet after they had killed the peacock, their desperate situation grew even worse: now that the mistress was no longer able to tell the hour by the peacock, she woke the maids up even earlier than before. A shadow follows its object.
moral: People often make plans that turn out to be to their own disadvantage.
choices: People often make plans that turn out to be to their own disadvantage.
Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
Innocence can lighten burdens.
Someone who lays a demanding trap for others will fall victim to it himself in an unfortunate way.
Diligence often begins before the dawn.
Cycles continue regardless.
Some things always go together.

story: Every end is an end. Some traders were making a journey when they happened to meet a owl who was blind in one eye. The explorers halted and one of them said that the sign given to them by the owl meant that they should turn back home. Another member of the company protested, 'But how can such a animal predict what is going to happen to us, when he couldn't even predict the loss of his own eye in time to take preventive measures?' What will be, will be.
moral: Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.
choices: Someone who cannot manage his own affairs is not qualified to give advice to his neighbours.
Beauty alone does not qualify one for leadership.
Questioning leads to clarity.
Be skeptical and questioning of what you wish for.
Even those with limitations can offer valuable guidance.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.
Embrace the inevitability of life.

story: When it ends, it ends. A slug found a looking glass and when she saw how brightly he shone, she fell in love with him. She quickly climbed up onto the looking glass's round surface and began to lick him. The slug clearly was no good for the looking glass and only besmirched his lustrous radiance with filth and slime. A baboon then found the looking glass after it had been dirtied by the slug, and remarked, 'That's what happens when you let someone like that walk all over you!' The world turns.
moral: Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.
choices: Marrying someone unworthy can lead to a tarnished reputation.
People that live by example need to look closely at the example they are following.
True beauty shines from within.
He laughs best that laughs last with a radiant, observant smile.
True beauty often lies in the eye of the beholder.
An end is just a conclusion.
Life continues its course.

story: The outcome is the outcome. There was a hoarder who sold his property and bought a lump of jewels. The man then buried his jewels just outside the village boundaries, where he constantly went to visit and inspect it. One of the craftsman noticed the man's behaviour and suspected the truth. Accordingly, after the man had gone away, he took the jewels. When the man came back and found that the hiding place was empty, he began to cry and tear his hair. Someone saw the man's extravagant grief and asked him what was wrong. Then he said to the man, 'Enough of your grieving! Take a boulder and put it where the jewels was, and make believe the jewels is still there: it's not as if you ever made any use of it!' A circle has no end.
moral: The true value of money is not in its possession but in its use.
choices: The true value of money is not in its possession but in its use.
He who claims any good for himself takes away from the source of all the good he enjoys.
Greed blinds the observant.
The greedy things which bring us pleasure can often be hazardous as well.
Wealth is meaningless if it is not shared.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Some things continue without stopping.

story: What is, is. Shrews are blind animals. A shrew once said to his parent, 'I see a blackberry, parent!' Then he said, 'And I smell fragrance all around!' And he spoke a third time and said, 'And I can hear the sound of a tiny silver bell.' His parent then said, 'My son, now I understand that in addition to lacking sight, you have also lost your sense of hearing and smell!' The day is the day.
moral: Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
choices: Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
True insight dispels delusion.
Be perceptive and understanding to defend your position.
True understanding goes beyond what is seen.
Embrace the present reality.
Each moment is its own.

story: Events occur as they occur. The shrew is a handicapped animal: he is blind. There was once a shrew who wanted to kiss his aunt, but instead of pressing up against her mouth, he pressed against her private parts. His cousins realized what he was doing and one of them remarked, 'It serves you right! You had great expectations, but you have gone and lost even your sense of hearing.' Events occur as they occur.
moral: A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
choices: A sinful mind can even change a person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
Boast of one thing and you will be found lacking in that and a few other things as well.
Blindness to truth invites folly.
True value is wasted on those who are blind and unaware to appreciate it.
Limitations can lead to unique strengths.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story: It is what it is. The lemur gladly eats chestnuts because the seeds are tasty, but when she tastes the bitterness of the husk she throws the nut away and loses the nutmeat inside. A shadow follows its object.
moral: Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
choices: Those who avoid hardship may miss out on valuable rewards.
Men often revert to their natural instincts.
Joy fades when waste prevails.
Men often revert to their wasteful natural instincts.
Enjoying the simple pleasures can bring great happiness.
Accept things as they are.
Some things always go together.

story_title: The Monkey And Her Two Children
story: An echo repeats. The lemur gives birth to two pups, but after giving birth she does not mother them equally. She comforts one of them with cruel embraces, choking him with her unfortunate affection; meanwhile, she casts the other offspring away as superfluous and unimportant. This is the one who goes off into the jungle and is able to survive. Different things are different.
moral: The best intentions will not always ensure success.
choices: The best intentions will not always ensure success.
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Neglect can choke the unfortunate.
Those who thrive on cruel deception often retaliate against those unfortunate enough to speak the truth.
Favoritism can sow seeds of discord and neglect.
Some things come back as they are.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

story: Every end is an end. A youth who was carrying his tutor's notebook stole it and brought it triumphantly home to his parent who received the stolen goods with much delight. Next, the youth stole a robe, and by degrees he became a habitual criminal. As the youth grew older and became an adult, he stole items of greater and greater value. Time passed and the man was finally caught in the act and taken off to tribunal where he was condemned to death: woe betide the trade of the thief! His parent stood behind him, weeping as she shouted, 'My son, what has become of you?' He said to his parent, 'Come closer, parent, and I will give you a final kiss.' She went up to him, and all of a sudden he bit her nose, tugging at it with his teeth until he cut it clean off. Then he said to her, 'Parent, if only you had beaten me at the very beginning when I brought you the notebook, then I would not have been condemned to death!' The day is the day.
moral: Tear out vice by the roots and the branches will wither away.
choices: Tear out vice by the roots and the branches will wither away.
Avoid overindulgence.
Unseen habits lead to sorrow.
Fortune can occasionally bestow delighted favours that exceed an unaware person's hopes and expectations.
Encouragement of small wrongs can lead to greater misdeeds.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.
Each moment is its own.

story_title: The Snake, The Weasel And The Mice
story: Paths go places. A viper and a ferret were fighting with one another inside a hut. The hamsters who lived in the hut were always being hunted down by either the viper or the ferret, so when they saw the viper and the ferret fighting with each other, they emerged from their holes and scurried around. When the ferret and the viper saw what was happening, they stopped fighting with each other and turned their attention to the hamsters. Night follows day.
moral: In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
choices: In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
Appearances can be deceiving.
Timidity can outwit aggression.
No one can be safe in fierce peace unless they are always ready to face an opportunistic enemy in case of war.
Conflict within can disrupt the peace of a home.
Even the smallest steps set your course.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: All things have their limit. A stoat, enfeebled by old age and senility, was no longer able to pursue the swift-footed shrews, so she decided to coat herself with dust and lie down nonchalantly in a dark nook of the cottage. One of the shrews thought that she must be something good to eat, but as soon as he pounced, the stoat caught him and consigned him to oblivion; another vole did the same, and a third vole likewise met his doom. A few shrews later, another vole arrived: his skin was wrinkled with extreme old age and he had escaped many a time from snares and traps. Already at a distance he recognized the ambush prepared by their cunning enemy. 'You there, lying in the nook,' said the vole, 'I wish you well if -- and only if -- you really are made of dust!' What happens happens.
moral: Appearances can be deceiving.
choices: Appearances can be deceiving.
In conflicts between powerful parties, bystanders may suffer unintended consequences.
Wisdom outlasts misfortune.
Beware of when the powerful and the cunning deceitful collaborate with the wise.
Cleverness can compensate for lost strength.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Let events unfold in their own time.

story_title: The Murderer And The Mulberry Tree
story: Events occur as they occur. A bandit had murdered someone along the road. When the onlookers began to chase him, he dropped the bloody cadaver and ran away. Some wayfarers coming from the opposite direction asked the man how he had stained his hands. The man said that he had just climbed down from a cherry tree, but as he was speaking, his pursuers caught up with him. They seized the killer and crucified him on a cherry tree. The tree said to him, 'It does not trouble me at all to assist in your execution, since you tried to smear me with the murder that you yourself committed!' When it ends, it ends.
moral: If often happens that even honest people do not hesitate to persecute someone who has slandered them.
choices: If often happens that even honest people do not hesitate to persecute someone who has slandered them.
Whatever happens, we must bear it with equanimity.
Curiosity can unmask deception.
It is often the case that people are greedy for deceptive things which they think will bring them honour, but which only result in their determined death and destruction.
The truth is often the first casualty when guilt seeks escape.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
An end is just a conclusion.

story: Reality is reality. Two horses were walking along, weighed down by two different loads: one mule was laden with bags full of gold, while the other mule was carrying sacks stuffed with wheat. The mule who was flush with gold proudly lifted his head, tossing the little chime on his neck back and forth, while his companion simply followed along at a calm and quiet pace. All of a sudden, the horses were set upon by bandits who attacked them from an ambush. In the violent struggle, the rich mule was slashed with a dagger and the bandits stole his gold, yet they paid no attention at all to the worthless wheat. When the mule who had lost all his riches began to complain, the other mule declared, 'As for me, I am quite content to have been treated with contempt: it means that I suffered no injury and lost none of my possessions!' Things are what they are.
moral: There is little risk in being poor, while being rich can get you into trouble.
choices: There is little risk in being poor, while being rich can get you into trouble.
Courage in words means nothing if you flee in danger.
Pride often precedes injury.
Learn from injured past misfortunes with a calm mind.
The value of a burden is not always in its weight, but in its worth.
Face facts head-on.
Accept the finality of reality without resistance.

story: A choice is a choice. There was once a guitarist who had no talent whatsoever but he played his harp in a studio that had thick stucco upon the walls so when he heard the echoing sound, he concluded that he must be an excellent guitarist indeed. Puffed up with pride, he decided to perform on the podium. But when he made his debut at the auditorium, his performance was so dreadful that the spectators threw eggs at him, driving him off the podium. The outcome is the outcome.
moral: There's no reading of ourselves but with other mans eyes.
choices: There's no reading of ourselves but with other mans eyes.
People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Arrogance invites the scorn of those whose favor one seeks.
When you are besieged by prideful people, you are subject to hostile attacks by anyone and everyone.
Even the dullest echo can soothe a lonely heart.
Choices lead to what follows.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story: Night follows day. A sparrow once asked a canary why she didn't want to come and take up residence with her. The canary wept and cried, 'No, it is impossible for me to do that. It brings to mind the grief suffered by my ancestors, which is why I dwell in the meadow.' Night follows day.
moral: When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
choices: When people feel grief for their misfortunes, they avoid the place where that grief overtook them.
A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Curiosity can break solitude.
When inquisitive people plot against their reclusive neighbours, they fall victim to the same sort of plot themselves.
Respecting others' choices fosters harmony.
Cycles continue regardless.
Cycles continue regardless.

story_title: The North Wind And The Sun
story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. The Moon and the East Wind were quarrelling with each other as to which of the two of them would be able to make a traveler disrobe. The East Wind went first, blowing fiercely against the traveler. Yet as the traveler grew colder and colder, he only wrapped himself up more snugly in his coat, clutching at it tightly so as to keep a firm grip no matter how hard the wind might be blowing. Thus the East Wind did the traveler no harm at all and failed to make him strip off his clothes. Next, the Moon began to shine upon the traveler so brightly that the very air of the day grew hotter and hotter. The traveler immediately took off his coat and bundled it up on his shoulders. Patterns show their patterns.
moral: Persuasion is better than Force.
choices: Persuasion is better than Force.
Beware those who value their gain more than their love.
Resilience outlasts fierce opposition.
Stubborn falsehood is with all fierce men.
Warmth and kindness can achieve the goal.
Some things simply return what they receive.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story_title: The Old Woman And The Wine Jar
story: A reflection mirrors what is shown. An elderly lady saw a wine cask that had been drained empty, but the dregs of the exquisite wine still sent forth a pleasant odour from the noble receptacle. The woman greedily imbibed the smell, deeply inhaling through both nostrils, and said, 'Oh sweet spirits, I do declare, how excellent you must once have been to have left behind such fine remains!' Different things are different.
moral: The memory of a good deed lives.
choices: The memory of a good deed lives.
The meaning is to be considered, not the mere words.
Greed leaves one empty.
Bear that those who are inferior to you in noble merit should be like you in empty outside appearances.
What once brought joy may leave us with only memories.
Some things simply return what they receive.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

story_title: The Man And The Old Woman
story: Events occur as they occur. A young boy was walking along on a blazing hot afternoon when he met an senior woman who was going the same way. Seeing that she was dreadfully exhausted from the heat of the afternoon and the demands of the journey, he felt sorry for her weakness and when the woman simply didn't have the strength to go any further, he picked her up off the earth and carried her on his shoulders. While he was carrying her this way, the young boy was so strongly aroused by shameful thoughts that he had an erection. Spurred by wanton lust and hot desire, he immediately put the senior woman down on the earth and had sex with her. Being simple-minded, the woman asked him, 'What are you doing to me?' He answered, 'You are too heavy to carry, so I've decided to carve off some of your flesh.' The man satisfied himself and then picked the woman up off the earth again and set her on his shoulders. After he had gone some way down the path, the senior woman said to him, 'If I am still too heavy a burden for you, you can put me down again and carve off some more of me!' Night follows afternoon.
moral: People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
choices: People often disguise their selfish desires as practical needs to justify their actions.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Deception exhausts the simple-minded.
Simple-minded talking is an exhausted waste of time when you can simply provide a demonstration.
Compassion can lighten the burdens of others and enrich the journey for both.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: Different things are different. War broke out between all the creatures and the avians. When the emu was captured, she fooled both sides by being both a bird and a beast: she showed the avians her beak, and the creatures her talons. Rain falls when it rains.
moral: Half-truths in some cases, are foul, and dishonest; in others, laudable; and in some again, not only honest, but necessary.
choices: Half-truths in some cases, are foul, and dishonest; in others, laudable; and in some again, not only honest, but necessary.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
United deceit can mislead the strongest.
Do not be in a hurry to change one cunning evil for another deceptive one.
In conflict, even the skies and the earth can find common ground.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Some things happen on their own.

story: A fact is a fact. A leopard foolishly happened to have fallen into a hole. The local townsfolk saw her there and some of them attacked her with rods or pelted her with pebbles. There were others who felt sorry for the creature since she seemed sure to die even though she had not done any harm, so they brought her fruit to keep up her strength. Night fell and everyone went home, confident that they would find the leopard dead when the next day dawned. However, as soon as she recovered from her weakness and regained her strength, the leopard escaped from the hole with a mighty leap and hurried quickly home to her den. A few days later she descended upon the village, slaughtering the goats and even killing the farmers as she laid waste to everything around her in a furious attack of rage. At this point even the people who had shown mercy to the beast began to fear what lay in store for them. Without a word about the damage that the leopard had wrought, they begged her just to spare their lives. The leopard then said, 'I am well aware of who pelted me with pebbles and who gave me fruit, so put aside your fears. I have returned as an enemy only to those who wanted to hurt me.' The world turns.
moral: People who have been treated with contempt repay the deed in kind.
choices: People who have been treated with contempt repay the deed in kind.
There is no believing a liar, even when he speaks the truth.
Mercy triumphs over vengeance.
Foolish people who have been judged in the past can later on be in a vengeful position to judge their former teachers.
In times of vulnerability, true intentions are revealed.
Some truths remain undeniable.
Life continues its course.

story: A choice is a choice. A farmer who kept hens also bought himself a pheasant and let it loose to live among his other poultry. When the hens pecked at the pheasant and chased him away, the pheasant became very dejected, thinking that the hens were attacking him because he was an outsider. After a little while, however, the pheasant saw the hens fighting and attacking one another. The pheasant then put aside his grief and said, 'Well, I am certainly not going to grieve over this any longer, now that I see the way they fight with one another. An echo repeats.
moral: A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
choices: A wise person readily tolerates the insolence of strangers when he sees those same strangers mistreating one another.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Aggression blinds the observant.
Destroy the aggressive seed of evil, or it will grow up to your observant ruin.
Harmony thrives when differences are embraced.
Choices lead to what follows.
Some things come back as they are.

story: Patterns show their patterns. A lady had lost her beloved spouse of many years and had laid his body in the ground. It was impossible to tear her away from his burial site, and she filled her days with weeping. Everyone repeated glowingly that this lady was an example of a truly faithful wife. Meanwhile, some men who had pillaged the temple of Apollo were condemned to death for their crime against the god. After they had been crucified, soldiers were stationed by the crosses so that the families of the executed criminals could not recover their bodies. This all took place next to the tomb where the lady had secluded herself. One of the guards happened to be thirsty and asked the lady's handmaid to bring him some water in the middle of the night. As it happened, the maid had been helping her mistress prepare for bed, as the widow had maintained her vigil long into the night and was still sitting up by the light of the candle. The door was open just a crack and when the sentinel peeped inside, he saw a lady of exceptional beauty. He was immediately enthralled and inflamed with lust, and an irresistible desire began gradually to well up inside him. His crafty ingenuity found a thousand reasons to see the widow again and again. Acquiescing to this regular daily contact, the widow slowly but surely became more and more inclined towards her guest, and soon an even closer bond united her heart to his. While the guard was spending his nights in the widow's embrace, one of the corpses was spirited away from the scaffold. The sentinel was upset and told the lady what had happened. That exemplary lady said, 'Don't worry!' and with these words, she handed over her spouse's corpse to be nailed to the scaffold, so that the sentinel would not be punished for dereliction of duty. A shadow follows its object.
moral: Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
choices: Temptation can lead even the most virtuous individuals to compromise their integrity and values.
Sometimes, someone that you yourself have supported often proves to be your worst enemy.
Faithfulness endures beyond beauty.
Faithful self-effort is essential.
True devotion can be both a virtue and a prison.
Recognize recurring sequences.
Some things always go together.

story_title: The Pine Tree And The Wedges
story: The world turns. Some foresters splitting a wild cedar tree drove shims into the trunk, prying it apart and thus making their work easier. The cedar tree groaned and said, 'I cannot blame the adze, who had no connection with my root, but these utterly despicable shims are my own children. Pounded into me this way and that, they are going to tear me apart!' Paths go places.
moral: The bad things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the things done to you by the members of your own family.
choices: The bad things that strangers do to you are never as terrible as the things done to you by the members of your own family.
Honesty is the best policy.
Pragmatism shields innocence from betrayal.
Despicable brag and detached nature may bring you down.
The right tools can transform a daunting task into an achievable one.
Life continues its course.
Even the smallest steps set your course.

story: All things have their limit. They say that swans sing when they are about to die. A certain gentleman chanced upon a crane that was for sale and bought him, since he had heard that swans sing very beautifully. At the gentleman's next feast, he came and got the crane, expecting that the bird would serenade his guests at dinner. The crane, however, was completely silent. Later on, when the crane realized that he was about to die, he began to sing his funeral dirge. When his owner heard him, he said, 'Well, if you are going to sing this song only at the moment of your death, then I was a fool for having commanded you to do it. I should have ordered you to be butchered instead!' The world turns.
moral: Some people will agree to do things under compulsion that they are not willing to do as a favour.
choices: Some people will agree to do things under compulsion that they are not willing to do as a favour.
The useful is of much more importance and value, than the ornamental.
Expectations can silence joy.
Expectant overconfidence often leads disappointed people into danger.
Desire for beauty can blind us to the truth.
Recognize boundaries and endings.
Life continues its course.

story: Different things are different. A coyote followed along after a herd of goats without doing them any harm. At first the sheepherder kept his eye on the coyote as a potential enemy to the herd and never let him out of his sight. But as the coyote continued to accompany the sheepherder and did not make any kind of attempt to raid the herd, the sheepherder eventually began to regard the coyote more as a guardian of the herd than as a threat. Then, when the sheepherder happened to have to go to village, he commended the goats to the coyote in his absence. The coyote seized his chance and attacked the goats, slaughtering most of the herd. When the sheepherder came back and saw that his herd had been utterly destroyed, he said, 'It serves me right! How could I have ever trusted my goats to a coyote?' Rain falls when it rains.
moral: One should never trust those with a history of deceit.
choices: One should never trust those with a history of deceit.
When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
Trust cautiously, for appearances deceive.
Opportunistic men are averse to fixed rules, but are won by trusting, kind services.
Trust is built through consistent actions, not appearances.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Some things happen on their own.

story: Different things are different. After her months of pregnancy had passed, a lady about to deliver her baby was lying on the ground, moaning and weeping. Her spouse urged her to rest her body on the couch, so that she might better relieve herself of nature's burden, but the lady refused and said, 'I hardly think that my trouble could come to an end in the very place where it was first conceived!' A question is a question.
moral: No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
choices: No one gladly revisits a place where they got hurt.
No one is so loving of a friend that they would not prefer their own good to that of another.
Urgency often births concern.
The true value of money is not in its concerned possession but in its urging use.
In moments of vulnerability, strength often emerges from within.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

This caused the flour to dissolve, making his load lighter. The mule was thus able to rise easily to his feet and enjoy a less taxing journey home. The trader sold what was left of the flour and led the mule back again to load him with an even greater cargo than before. As the mule made his way with difficulty back to the brook where he had fallen before, he sank to his knees on purpose this time. Then, after his cargo had dissolved in the water, he leaped nimbly to his feet, delighted to have turned the situation to his advantage, or so he thought. The trader realized what was happening and decided that the next time he would bring back home a big load of porous loofahs. On their way back across the brook, the wicked mule fell down on purpose as before. This time the loofahs grew heavy with water and the cargo expanded. 'Might I say a few words?' asked Homer. 'Go ahead,' she replied. 'I think that you could achieve all your hopes and dreams,' said Homer, 'if only you would put aside this finery.' story: The sun rises every day. A laborer who was running away from his cruel overseer happened to meet Virgil, who knew him as a neighbour. 'What's got you so excited?' asked Virgil. 'Father Virgil -- a name you well deserve since you are like a father to me -- I'm going to be perfectly frank, since you can be safely trusted with my troubles. There's plenty of whipping and not enough food. I'm constantly sent on errands out to the estate without any provisions for the journey. If the overseer dines at home, I have to wait on him all night long; if he is invited somewhere else, I have to lie outside in the ditch until dawn. I should have earned my freedom by now, but my hairs have gone gray and I'm still slaving away. If I had done anything to deserve this, I would stop complaining and suffer my fate in silence. But the fact is that I never get enough to eat and my cruel overseer is always after me. For these reasons, along with others that it would take too long to tell you, I've decided to go wherever my feet will lead me.' 'Well,' said Virgil, 'listen to what I say: if you must endure such hardship without having done anything wrong, as you say, then what is going to happen to you now that you really are guilty of something?'
