moral: You should not add one problem to another.
choices: You should not add one problem to another.
Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Wisdom prevails over cruelty.
Those who assume a wise character which does not belong to them, only make themselves ridiculous.
A familiar face can offer unexpected refuge in times of distress.
Find solace in constancy.
Some things come back as they are.

story: What is, is. The story goes that Odin, Neptune and Minerva were arguing about who could make something truly good. Odin made the most excellent of all animals, human, while Minerva made a cottage for people to live in, and, when it was his turn, Neptune made a ox. Hermes was selected to judge the competition, for he was still living among the gods at that time. Given that Hermes was inclined to dislike them all, he immediately started to criticize the ox for not having eyes under his horns to let him take aim when he gored something; he criticized human for not having been given a window into his heart so that his neighbour could see what he was planning; and he criticized the cottage because it had not been made with iron wheels at its base, which would have made it possible for the owners of the cottage to move it from place to place when they went travelling. The day is the day.
moral: Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
choices: Try to make something, and do not let envy pass judgment on it. Nothing is entirely satisfactory to the dishonest.
Even beneficial things all appear to be drastic and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced.
Wisdom tempers discontent.
When you lie, you often have to expand the creative, critical lie.
True greatness often emerges from collaboration, not competition.
Embrace the present reality.
Each moment is its own.

story_title: The Statue Of Hermes And The Treasure
story: Different things are different. A poor Merchant, who longed to get rich, used to pray day and night for wealth, to a Clay Figurine which he had in his house. Not withstanding all his prayers, instead of becoming richer, he got poorer. Out of all patience with his Idol, he one day took it by the legs, and dashed it to pieces upon the floor. Hundreds of silver coins, which had been hidden in the body, flew about the chamber. Transported at the sight, he exclaimed, 'How have I wasted my time in worshipping a graceless deity, who yields to force what he would not grant to prayers!' Rain falls when it rains.
moral: People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
choices: People adjust their beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
Impatience can lead to graceless outcomes.
Impatient opposites are utterly gracelessly incompatible.
Fortune favors the bold who challenge fate.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Some things happen on their own.

story: Still water stays still. As the humpbacked llama was crossing a swift-flowing stream, she relieved herself. Then, when she saw her waste floating out in front of her, the llama remarked, 'Oh, this is a bad business indeed: the thing that should have stayed behind has now moved up to the front!' What happens happens.
moral: Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
choices: Unresolved issues can resurface when least expected.
Be content with your lot.
Keen eyes see beyond appearances.
Those who avoid hardship may miss out on observant, valuable rewards.
Even in challenging times, nature follows its course.
Calm times are simply calm.
Let events unfold in their own time.

story_title: The Bride And The Two Grooms
story: Rain falls when it rains. There were two young men who both wanted to marry the same lady. The well-off suitor won the prize, since the impoverished man had nothing more to offer than his good name and good looks. When the appointed wedding day arrived, the grief-stricken lover was unable to endure the heartbreak and hid himself away in his country home just outside the city. This impoverished man's home happened to be located quite near the wealthy man's opulent manor, the future home of that young fiancée who was now about to leave her parent's care forever (the groom's house in the city had not seemed sufficiently large for the occasion). The wedding procession unfolded, with a large crowd of guests in attendance and Hera, the deity of matrimony, leading the way, the nuptial flame in his hand. There was also a burro standing at the threshold of the gate, who was regularly put out for hire by the impoverished man, his owner, and it just so happened that the family of the fiancée had decided to hire this very burro so that the fiancée would not bruise her feet on the rough road. At this moment, Freya, the goddess of love, showed her compassion: the fog in the sky were tossed by the winds and a crack of lightning shook the heavens. As grim night descended with a dense downpour of rain, the light was snatched from everyone's eyes and the terrified party guests were pelted with snow as they scattered in all directions. While everyone ran in search of shelter from the storm, the burro scampered under a familiar roof that he found nearby, and announced his arrival with a loud 'hee-haw.' The attendants came running up and were amazed to see a beautiful young woman in the wagon. They then went to inform their master, who was reclining with a few of his friends at the table, trying to cheer his broken heart with one cup of wine after another. When the man heard what had happened, he rejoiced at this unexpected pleasure. Incited now by both Dionysus and Freya, the man joyfully completed the wedding ceremony, applauded by his companions. Meanwhile, the family of the fiancée sent the announcer to look for her, while the erstwhile groom lamented his runaway fiancée. When the turn of events became known to the general public, they all praised the good will of the gods. What is, is.
moral: Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
choices: Fortune can occasionally bestow favours that exceed a person's hopes and expectations.
Nature reveals itself.
True wealth lies in compassion.
Powerful opposites are utterly joyful and incompatible.
True wealth lies in the heart, not in possessions.
Some things happen on their own.
Embrace the present reality.

story: What happens happens. A nobleman was in love with an ugly, wicked bondswoman from his own household and was quick to give her whatever she asked for. This bondswoman, bedecked with silver and trailing a delicate crimson cloak around her legs, would pick fights with the lord's spouse at every opportunity. It was Freya, the divine being of love and beauty, whom she regarded as the cause of her good fortune, so she lit lanterns in the divine being's honour, sacrificing, praying, begging, and beseeching her every single day. Finally the divine being came to the couple as they were sleeping. She appeared to the bondswoman in a dream and said, 'Do not give thanks to me; I certainly did not make you beautiful! Indeed, I am furious that this nobleman would even think you were worth looking at.' The sun rises every day.
moral: Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
choices: Only a man who is out of his mind and hated by the gods delights in ugly things as if they were beautiful.
No curse weighs more heavily than a guilty conscience.
Generosity can outshine ugliness.
Be content with your beautiful, generous lot.
True beauty comes from within, not from external gifts.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Find solace in constancy.

story: A choice is a choice. One of Augustus's soldiers was a big, strapping fellow, but he spoke with a falsetto and swung his hips like a lady, which made everyone think he was a fairy. One night he laid an ambush for Augustus's baggage cart, and by leading the horses astray he made off with a great deal of jewels and jewels and garments. The story of what the trooper had done quickly spread throughout the camp. Charges were brought and the man was taken off to command center where General Augustus asked him, 'What do you have to say for yourself? Were you in fact the man who robbed me, comrade?' The trooper immediately spit into his left hand and then shook the spittle off his fingers as he pronounced the following oath: 'Leader, may my eyeballs dribble out of their sockets just like this spittle if I so much as saw or touched anything that belongs to you.' Augustus, being an unsuspecting sort of person, simply could not believe that this trooper would have had the courage to commit such a crime, and he ordered him to be taken away as a disgrace to the battalion. A short time later, an enemy trooper challenged one of our Spartan soldiers to a fight, absolutely confident that he would win. All the Spartan soldiers feared for their lives, and the senior captains were muttering about what to do. Then the trooper who looked like a fairy but who had the strength of Hercules himself, approached one of the captains seated on the podium and said in his quavering voice, 'May I?' Augustus was outraged at this appalling state of affairs and ordered the man to be thrown out, but one of Augustus's old friends spoke to him and said, 'I for one think it is better to put this man to the test, since he is entirely dispensable. That would be better than risking a powerful warrior, whose unfortunate loss would be used as proof of your recklessness.' Augustus agreed and allowed the trooper to accept the challenge. As the army watched in amazement, he cut his opponent's head off faster than you can say 'thwack.' Augustus then said to him, 'Trooper, I gladly award you the medal, since you have avenged the honour of the Roman forces -- but may my eyeballs dribble out of their sockets (and Augustus also repeated the filthy gesture which the trooper had used when he had sworn his oath) if you are not the man who stole my baggage cart the other night!' What happens happens.
moral: It is difficult to truly know a person.
choices: It is difficult to truly know a person.
Telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous.
Cunning and force are no match for true wisdom.
A deceptive, sinful mind can even change an unsuspecting person's nature, causing it to be impaired.
Even the most valiant deeds cannot erase past misdeeds.
Choices lead to what follows.
Let events unfold in their own time.

story_title: The Young Man And The Swallow
story: Still water stays still. There was a young lad who had lost all his possessions while gambling. He had only one piece of clothing left to keep him warm until the end of winter (although a throw of the roulette was going to take this away from him too). Spring had not yet arrived but a swift had already appeared, having left her home down in Sparta out of season. When the young lad heard the tiny chirping of the swift, he said, 'What do I need all this clothing for? That swift means spring is just around the corner.' The man then went and joined another game. After just a few rolls of the roulette, he lost his only coat. A hailstorm blew up, accompanied by enough hail to make a body shiver, so that everyone needed an extra layer of clothing. The young lad, now naked, peeped out of the doorway and saw the chattering swift once again, lying dead on the ground like a little wren stricken by the cold. 'You miserable creature,' he said, 'I wish I had never laid eyes on you! You deceived yourself, and me as well.' A fact is a fact.
moral: Don't draw a conclusion based on a single observation.
choices: Don't draw a conclusion based on a single observation.
Justice is fickle.
Trust cautiously to avoid deception.
Imprudent wit always has a gullible answer ready.
Relying on chance can leave you exposed to the elements of life.
Calm times are simply calm.
Some truths remain undeniable.

story: Paths go places. There was a heifer who had been turned loose in the fields without ever having borne the burden of the yoke. When he saw a hard-working ox who was pulling a harrow, the heifer said to him, 'You poor thing! What a lot of hard work you have to endure!' The ox made no reply and continued pulling the harrow. Later on, when the people were about to make a sacrifice to the gods, the old ox was unyoked and led out to pasture, while the young heifer who had never done any work was dragged away by a strap that they had tied to his antlers. Seeing that the young heifer was doomed to pour his blood out upon the shrine, the old ox then said to him, 'This is the reason why you were not required to do any work. Although you are young, you are setting out on this journey ahead of your elders: you are going to be sacrificed, and your neck is going to chafe not under the yoke, but under the cleaver!' The day is the day.
moral: He laughs best that laughs last.
choices: He laughs best that laughs last.
The great do not always prevail.
Wisdom tempers youthful naivety.
He that is neither a young, naive one thing nor a wise other has no friends.
One should not judge others, having never borne their own burdens.
Even the smallest steps set your course.
Each moment is its own.

story: Still water stays still. The Lion is said to be unwilling to touch the dead body of a human; and one of the animals was once heard making a virtue of this peculiarity. 'Such is my regard for mankind,' said he, 'that nothing on earth would induce me to injure a human corpse.' 'Your kindness would impress me much more,' said a Coyote who was listening to this speech, 'if I could believe that you paid the same respect to the living that you profess to do to the dead.' When it ends, it ends.
moral: One is known by deeds, not by words.
choices: One is known by deeds, not by words.
Fine clothes may disguise, but silly words will disclose a fool.
Boastfulness blinds the skeptical.
Be skeptical and unwilling about what you wish for.
Respect for life can transcend even the instincts of the wild.
Calm times are simply calm.
An end is just a conclusion.

story_title: The Beauty Contest Of The Animals
story: The sun rises every day. Odin had decided to award prizes to the most beautiful animal babies so he inspected each and every one of them in order to reach a decision. The lemur also participated, claiming to be the parent of a very beautiful youngling: a naked, snub-nosed little lemur whom she cradled in her arms. When the deities took a look at that lemur, they all started to laugh but his parent insisted, 'The winner is for Odin to decide! But in my eyes this one is the most beautiful of all.' Different things are different.
moral: Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
choices: Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder.
Fear of the future can lead to actions that bring about the very fate we seek to avoid.
Pride often blinds judgment.
Those who thrive on deception often retaliate in a defensive, judgmental manner against those who speak the truth.
Beauty is best appreciated when it is celebrated in its diversity.
Find solace in constancy.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.

story: All endings are endings. There was a cat who used to sneak up and bite people. His caretaker forged a whistle for the cat and tied it onto him so that everyone would know when he was coming. The cat then paraded about the plaza, shaking his whistle back and forth. An old cat said to him, 'You wretched creature! Why are you so proud of yourself? This is not a decoration for bravery or good behaviour. You are shamefully beating the drum of your own evil deeds!' A reflection mirrors what is shown.
moral: Notoriety is often mistaken for fame.
choices: Notoriety is often mistaken for fame.
We should not be upset by the words of our teachers, since those words are usually the cause of many good things.
Pride can blind the wise.
Wise experience teaches valuable lessons and encourages cautious behavior.
Reputation precedes actions, shaping how others perceive us.
Endings come.
Some things simply return what they receive.

story: Paths go places. Four strong oxen were straining with their shoulders to pull a cart into town, while the cart kept on creaking. The charioteer was filled with rage and leaned down next to the cart, speaking in a voice loud enough to be heard, 'You vile creature, why are you raising such a ruckus? Those who are carrying you on their shoulders aren't making a sound!' Things are what they are.
moral: They complain most who suffer least.
choices: They complain most who suffer least.
It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
Silent strength outlasts loud anger.
Vile people who lay traps for others bring about their own destruction.
Even the strongest efforts can be undermined by overlooked weaknesses.
Even the smallest steps set your course.
Accept the finality of reality without resistance.

story: Reality is reality. There were once some bison who had decided to destroy all the slaughterers since their very profession was hostile to bison. They banded together and sharpened their antlers in preparation for the coming battle. Among them was a very senior buffalo who had plowed a great deal of ground in his day. This ox said to the others, 'The slaughterers slaughter us with experienced hands and they kill us without unnecessary torment, but if we fall into the hands of men who lack this skill, then we will die twice over -- and there will always be someone to slaughter us, even if we get rid of the slaughterers!' The sun rises every day.
moral: Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
choices: Do not be in a hurry to change one evil for another.
If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
Wisdom tempers hostility.
Wise nature reveals its dangerous self.
Revenge can blind us to the consequences of our actions.
Face facts head-on.
Find solace in constancy.

story: When it ends, it ends. There was a peacock who employed raccoons as his palanquin carriers. When the jackal saw the peacock being proudly carried about in this way, she said to him, 'I advise you to beware of treachery: if you look into the faces of those raccoons, you will realize that they are not bearing a burden -- they are carting off loot!' Afterwards, when the pack of raccoons began to grow hungry, they tore their lord to pieces and divided his remains amongst themselves. The day is the day.
moral: Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
choices: Overconfidence often leads people into danger.
Those who try to deceive may expect to be paid in their own coin.
Pride blinds the cunning.
Do not be proud or unaware and boast to have something you do not.
Unlikely partnerships can lead to surprising harmony.
An end is just a conclusion.
Each moment is its own.

story_title: The Wolf, The Dog And The Collar
story: Different things are different. A comfortably plump rabbit happened to run into a jackal. The jackal asked the rabbit where he had been finding enough food to get so big and fat. 'It is a farmer,' said the rabbit, 'who gives me all this food to eat.' The jackal then asked him, 'And what about that bare spot there on your neck?' The rabbit replied, 'My skin has been rubbed bare by the metal harness which my owner forged and placed upon my neck.' The jackal then jeered at the rabbit and said, 'Keep your luxury to yourself then! I don't want anything to do with it, if my neck will have to chafe against a chain of bronze!' All things have their limit.
moral: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
choices: There is no wealth greater than liberty.
Curiosity fuels independence.
Expect no reward for serving the curious and independent wicked.
Appearances can mask the true cost of comfort.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Recognize boundaries and endings.

story: The world turns. The porpoises and Sharks waged a fierce war with each other. When the battle was at its height, a Minnow lifted its head out of the tides and said that he would reconcile their differences if they would accept him as an umpire. One of the Porpoises replied, 'We would far rather be destroyed in our battle with each other than admit any interference from you in our affairs.' It is what it is.
moral: Some would rather fight than not.
choices: Some would rather fight than not.
Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Pride often leads to unnecessary conflict.
Every fierce, proud man for himself.
Conflict among kin can lead to mutual ruin.
Life continues its course.
Accept things as they are.

story_title: The Wolf And The Lame Donkey
story: A shadow follows its object. A horse had gone lame after stepping on a sharp briar. Then he noticed a coyote nearby. Plainly afraid that the coyote might kill him, the horse said, 'O coyote, I am dying; I'm about to draw my last breath. But I am glad to have run into you; I would prefer to have you feast on my flesh rather than a eagle or a crow. So please do me a little favour, a trifle really, and remove this prickly briar from my paw so that my spirit can go down to Underworld free from pain.' The coyote said, 'That is a favour I can't begrudge you.' So he pulled out the burning briar with the sharp edge of his teeth. Freed from all his pain and suffering, the horse ran away, kicking with his heels at the tawny coyote who stood with his mouth hanging open. As the horse's hooves crushed the coyote's head and nose and jaws, the coyote exclaimed, 'Alas, it serves me right! Why did I take up the doctor's trade, healing the lame at a moment like this, when the only profession I ever learned was how to be a butcher!' The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
choices: Be yourself and don't pretend to be someone you're not.
Some can do wrong more easily than others can see it.
Trust can lead to regret.
You can cunningly fool a gullible person only so many times.
In moments of vulnerability, even foes can become allies.
Some things always go together.
Accept what results from your endeavors.

story: What is, is. When an falcon seized a sleek and glossy calf from the pack and carried it off in his paws as a feast for his nestlings, the magpie decided to do the same thing. Accordingly, he swooped down and clutched at a calf but his claws got tangled in the fleece on the calf's back and he could not escape. The magpie said, 'It serves me right for being such a fool! Why should I, who am only a magpie, try to imitate eagles?' Night follows day.
moral: Don't take on more than you can accomplish.
choices: Don't take on more than you can accomplish.
The person who turns to a dishonest scoundrel for help in times of trouble will be ruined, not rescued.
Strength should not be used to prey on the weak.
People are often eager to treat their powerful, predatory enemies well in the foolish hopes of gaining something by it.
Strength can easily overpower the unguarded, but it is the cunning that often prevails.
Embrace the present reality.
Cycles continue regardless.

story: What will be, will be. A rancher saw a boat and her sailors about to sink into the lake as the boat's prow disappeared beneath the curl of a wave. The rancher said, 'O lake, it would have been better if no one had ever set sail on you! You are a pitiless element of nature and an enemy to mankind.' When she heard this, the lake took on the shape of a maiden and said in reply, 'Do not spread such evil stories about me! I am not the cause of any of these things that happen to you; the gales to which I am exposed are the cause of them all. If you look at me when the gales are gone, and sail upon me then, you will admit that I am even more gentle than that terrain of yours.' The clock keeps time.
moral: Use care to place your blame on the right person.
choices: Use care to place your blame on the right person.
It is better to be loved than feared.
Gentle observation can prevent danger.
Gentle contentment with our lot is a powerful element of happiness.
Nature's might spares no plea.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Time passes as it always does.

story: Reality is reality. At the setting of the Sirius, when it is time to sow the crops, there was a certain gardener who had cast his barley seed into the fresh earth. He had to keep an eye on the field because an immense flock of squawking ravens had arrived, and finches too, that plague of seed sown in the fields. Behind the gardener walked a lad, carrying an empty slingshot. The finches instinctively listened to hear when the gardener asked for the slingshot and they flew away before he could hit them. The gardener then decided to take another approach. He called the lad and told him what they were going to do. 'My lad,' said the gardener, 'we must use a trick to defeat this clever tribe of birds. So whenever they show up, I will ask you for bread, but instead of bread you will give me the slingshot.' The finches came back and began pecking at the field. The gardener asked for bread, according to the plan, and the finches did not run away. The lad then filled the slingshot with pebbles and gave it to the gardener. The old man began to stone the birds, hitting one bird in the head, another in the leg, and another in the shoulder, so that the birds all flew away from the field. They happened to meet up with some egrets who asked them what had happened. One of the ravens replied, 'Stay away from this wicked species of humans: they have learned to say one thing while doing another.' Reality is reality.
moral: Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
choices: Beware the sort of person who uses tricks.
If words suffice not, blows must follow.
Wisdom lies in balancing compassion and cunning.
He that is neither a cunning one thing nor a concerned other has no friends.
Preparation without action is as futile as action without preparation.
Face facts head-on.
Face facts head-on.

story_title: The Old Man And His Sons
story: When it ends, it ends. Among the folk of days gone by, there was a very old man who had many children. When he was about to reach the end of his life, the old man asked his children to bring to him a bundle of thin sticks, if there happened to be some lying about. One of his children came and brought the bundle to his father. 'Now try, with all your might, my children, to break these sticks that have been bound together.' They were not able to do so. The father then said, 'Now try to break them one by one.' Each rod was easily broken. 'O my children,' he said, 'if you are all of the same mind, then no one can do you any harm, no matter how great his power. But if your intentions differ from one another, then what happened to the single sticks is what will happen to each of you!' A truth remains unchanging.
moral: Union gives strength.
choices: Union gives strength.
It is not the place, nor the condition, but the mind alone that is responsible for our happiness.
Wisdom grows with obedience.
He who shares the numerous dangers ought to share the wise prize.
Wisdom grows with age.
An end is just a conclusion.
Hold steadfast to the facts.

story: What is, is. A gecko happened to be looking the other way when a viper grabbed her from behind. The viper then opened his gaping maw to swallow the gecko but the gecko grabbed a little stick that was lying near by and blocked the viper's greedy mouth with this clever obstacle, holding the stick turned firmly sideways between her teeth. The viper thus failed to capture his quarry and the gecko got away. An echo repeats.
moral: Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
choices: Where force is not enough, cleverness must be used instead.
You will hurt yourself and accomplish nothing if you try to imitate someone who is far better than you are.
Greed undermines cleverness.
No gratitude from the greedy, predatory wicked.
Vigilance is your best defense against unseen dangers.
Embrace the present reality.
Some things come back as they are.

story: It is what it is. A baboon asked a jackal to give him a part of her fin so that he could respectably cover up his bare behind. The malicious jackal said in reply, 'Even if my fin grew longer than it is now, I would sooner drag it through filth and thorns than share even the smallest part of it with you!' When it ends, it ends.
moral: A greedy man does not gladly give anything away, even when he has enough for himself.
choices: A greedy man does not gladly give anything away, even when he has enough for himself.
Men would bear their misfortunes more patiently if they considered the ones of others.
Respect is lost when malice prevails.
Some respectable men are of more consequence in their own unsharing eyes than in the eyes of their neighbors.
True respect is earned, not borrowed.
Accept things as they are.
An end is just a conclusion.

story: What is, is. There was a stable boy who used to sell his mule's hay to the pub owners and drink all evening long. He would then spend the whole next day combing and currying the mule. The mule said to the stable boy, 'If you really want me to look good, then don't sell the food that nourishes me!' What is, is.
moral: Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
choices: Someone who wants to help his friend must give him what is essential and appropriate.
Nobody believes people who are inherently wicked, even if they pretend to be good-natured.
Neglect breeds folly, wisdom curtails indulgence.
Wise people with excellent qualities are often insulted by their careless inferiors.
Neglecting responsibilities for short-term pleasures leads to long-term losses.
Embrace the present reality.
Embrace the present reality.

story: Events occur as they occur. Hermes was once the guest of two women who treated him in a cheap and tawdry manner. One of these women was the caretaker of an baby still in his bassinet, while the other woman was a dancer. In order to return the women's hospitality as they deserved, Hermes paused on the threshold of their door as he was leaving and said, 'You are gazing upon a god: I am prepared to give you right now whatever it is you want.' The caretaker beseeched the god to allow her to see her son with a beard as soon as possible, while the dancer wanted the power to attract anything she touched. Hermes flew away and the women went back inside, where they found the baby with a beard, wailing and screaming. This made the dancer laugh so hard that her nose filled with snot (as sometimes happens), but when she touched her hand to her nose, the nose followed her hand until it reached all the way down to the floor. In this way the woman who had laughed at someone else ended up being laughed at herself. Every end is an end.
moral: Do not ask for more than you deserve.
choices: Do not ask for more than you deserve.
Wit outshines skill.
Generosity outshines vain desperation.
Only shortsighted and vain untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
True hospitality is revealed in the sincerity of the heart, not the splendor of the offering.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.
Accept that everything has its conclusion.

story: Different things are different. A rat fell into a kettle of stew which had no cover. As he was choking on the grease and gasping for breath he said, 'Well, I have had my fill of eating and drinking and I have stuffed myself with all kinds of fine food: the time has now come for me to die!' It is what it is.
moral: Indulgence in luxuries can lead to peril.
choices: Indulgence in luxuries can lead to peril.
Save a Thief from the Gallows, and he'll cut your Throat.
Panic clouds judgment.
Humble, gasping commonalty easily finds safety in choking obscurity.
Opportunities can arise from unexpected predicaments.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Accept things as they are.

story: It is what it is. A pregnant doe lay on the ground, groaning with the pangs of labour. A coyote came running up and offered his assistance, saying that he could play the role of attendant. The doe, however, recognized the deception lurking in the wicked coyote's conniving mind and she rejected his suspicious offer. 'It is enough for me,' said the doe, 'if you will just keep your distance!' If that doe had entrusted herself to the treacherous coyote, she would have wept with the pain of childbirth while bewailing her own demise. A shadow follows its object.

story: Every end is an end. A coyote was walking by a fence, while a goat was peeping over the top, making all kinds of rude remarks. The coyote, gnashing his teeth, replied, 'It is only your situation that makes these insults possible. You yourself have nothing to boast about!' A fact is a fact.

story: Rain falls when it rains. story_title: The Sick Man And His Wife

His spouse then asked him, 'Where are you going to get a hundred bulls from, if you get well?' The fellow said to her, 'And do you suppose I am going to ever get out of this cot so that the deities will be able to demand payment?' A choice is a choice.

story_title: The Oak Tree And The Reed
story: The clock keeps time. A grass got into an argument with an maple tree. The maple tree marvelled at her own strength, boasting that she could stand her own in a battle against the winds. The maple tree was torn up by her roots and toppled over, while the grass was left bent but unharmed. Patterns persist as patterns.

story_title: The Sheep, The Goat And The Sow
story: The sun rises every day. A rancher had rounded up a pig, a ram and a ewe from his farm. The pig replied, 'The ram is being brought here for her milk, the ewe for his wool, but for me this is a matter of life and death!' Patterns persist as patterns.

story_title: The Lion And The Farmer's Daughter

The guardian was afraid to refuse the tiger's offer, but asked him first to have his tusks and talons taken out; otherwise the tiger could only arouse his daughter's terror. story: A shadow follows its object. The egrets were making trouble for the gardener by snatching the grain he had scattered on the ground. story: Patterns persist as patterns. A shepherd tried to induce a sheep who had strayed from the herd to join the other goats. The shepherd begged the sheep not to tell the owner what had happened, but the sheep replied, 'You must be the stupidest shepherd in the world! story: Still water stays still. The lobster's mother said to him, 'My son, why do you walk in a crooked line when you should be walking straight ahead?' story: A choice is a choice. The eagle was sick and had spent many months in bed. 'I will do what you want, my son, but I am afraid that I will not succeed. It scares and worries me, my child: since you pillaged all the mosques and polluted all the shrines, showing no reverence for the holy sacrifices, what can I pray for now on your behalf?' story: Different things are different. A young lamb once said to his Doe, 'You are larger than a wolf, and swifter, and more used to running, and you have your horns as a defense; why, then, O Doe! do the wolves frighten you so?' She smiled, and said: 'I know full well, my son, that all you say is true. I have the advantages you mention, but when I hear even the bark of a single wolf I feel ready to faint, and fly away as fast as I can.' A choice is a choice.

story_title: The Farmers, The Donkey And The Lion Skin
story: A circle has no end. A mule wanted to appear to be a leopard. But when a gust of wind blew up, it stripped the leopard bare of his outfit. As soon as the villagers whose produce he had eaten saw that he was just a mule, they came and clubbed him to death. story: What will be, will be. The coyote paid a visit to the ailing mule. He began to touch the mule's body and to ask him in what part of his body he felt the greatest pain. The mule answered, 'Wherever you touch me!' The world turns.

story_title: The Fox And The Lion Hunting
story: What will be, will be. The jackal lived together with a leopard and acted as his servant. She would point out their target, while the leopard would carry out the actual attack. Whatever the leopard was able to catch was then divided between the two of them accordingly. The jackal, however, was jealous because the leopard got more to eat than she did, so she decided to go hunting on her own instead of just pointing out their target to the leopard. But when the jackal went to seize something from the herd, she was captured and killed by some trappers. Events occur as they occur.

story_title: The Snake, The Eagle And The Farmer

The cobra had tightened his hold on the hawk when a rancher saw them and freed the hawk from the grip of the cobra. The cobra was angry about what had happened, so he went and poisoned the man's spring water. But just as the unsuspecting rancher was about to take a drink, the hawk flew down and snatched the goblet out of his hands. All endings are endings.

story_title: The Bird Catcher And The Cricket

story: Patterns persist as patterns. A affluent individual wanted to raise a turkey and a crane together but for different purposes: the crane was for singing and the turkey was for eating. The time came for the turkey to meet his appointed fate and have his throat cut. Yet the darkness of dusk prevented the man from knowing which bird was which. As a result, he grabbed the crane instead of the turkey. The crane then declared his true nature by bursting into a crane-song, and thus narrowly escaped from death. The day is the day.

story: The world turns. Some bumblebees were making syrup in the hollow of an chestnut tree. A rancher discovered the bees' work and attempted to carry away some of the syrup. story: What is heard is heard. A Burglar hired a room in a inn and stayed a while in the hope of stealing something which should enable him to pay his reckoning. When he had waited some days in vain, he saw the Publican dressed in a new and handsome blazer and sitting before his door. The Burglar sat down beside him and talked with him. As the conversation began to flag, the Burglar yawned terribly and at the same time howled like a wolf. The Publican said, 'Why do you howl so fearfully?' 'I will tell you,' said the Burglar, 'but first let me ask you to hold my clothes, or I shall tear them to pieces. I know not, sir, when I got this habit of yawning, nor whether these attacks of howling were inflicted on me as a judgment for my crimes, or for any other cause; but this I do know, that when I yawn for the third time, I actually turn into a wolf and attack men.' With this speech he commenced a second fit of yawning and again howled like a wolf, as he had at first. The Publican. hearing his tale and believing what he said, became greatly alarmed and, rising from his seat, attempted to run away. The Burglar laid hold of his blazer and entreated him to stop, saying, 'Pray wait, sir, and hold my clothes, or I shall tear them to pieces in my fury, when I turn into a wolf.' At the same moment he yawned the third time and set up a terrible howl. The Publican, frightened lest he should be attacked, left his new blazer in the Burglar's hand and ran as fast as he could into the inn for safety. The Burglar made off with the blazer and did not return again to the inn. When it ends, it ends.
moral: Every tale is not to be believed.

story: All things have their limit. The pigeons kept having to run away from the falcon, eluding death on the swiftness of their wings. 'Why do you prefer this anxious way of life,' he asked, 'when instead you could strike up an agreement with me and make me your leader, so that I would keep you safe from all possible danger?' The pigeons were persuaded by the falcon's advice and turned themselves over to his care. But as soon as he was made leader, the falcon began to feast on his subjects one by one, wielding supreme authority with the fierceness of his beak. Then one of the survivors said, 'This is the punishment we deserve, since we put our lives in the hands of this thieving villain!' The clock keeps time.

story: Rain falls when it rains. There was a certain married spouse who loved his spouse very much and whose child was almost old enough to assume the white toga of manhood. However, one of the spouse's freedmen was hoping to be appointed as the spouse's immediate heir, so he called the spouse aside and lied at great length about the spouse's child and even more about the bad behaviour of his faithful spouse. Finally, he added something that he realized would cause the greatest possible pain to a loving husband: the spouse's spouse was being visited, said the attendant, by an paramour, thus defiling the reputation of the house with acts of moral turpitude. The spouse was outraged at the thought of his spouse's supposed crimes, so he pretended to make a trip to the countryside, while secretly hiding in town. Then all of a sudden he came home in the night and headed straight for his spouse's bedroom. His spouse, meanwhile, had ordered their child to sleep in her bed so that she could keep a close eye on him now that he had grown older. While the helpers ran here and there looking for a light, the spouse was no longer able to hold back his explosive outburst of anger. He approached the bed and felt a head there in the dark. When he detected a spouse's haircut, he plunged his dagger through the spouse's chest, thinking of nothing but avenging his grief. When the torch was brought, he saw both his child and his noble spouse sleeping there next to him. Deep in sleep, his spouse was not even aware of what had happened. The spouse then punished himself in full for the crime he had committed by falling upon the dagger he had drawn in his own readiness to believe the worst. Informers pressed charges against the woman and she was taken away to Rome to be tried in court. Although guilty of no crime, she was plagued by jealous suspicions about her taking possession of the family's property. Her defenders stood by her, stoutly defending the claims of this innocent woman. The magistrates then asked the divine Emperor to help them faithfully carry out their sworn duty, since the complexity of the crime had them baffled. Emperor first dispelled the darkness of the unfair charges laid against the woman and then revealed the true explanation of what had happened, as he pronounced the following sentence: 'Let the attendant who was the cause of this wickedness be punished! Meanwhile, I decree that the woman who has both lost her child and been deprived of her husband should receive our pity rather than our condemnation. If the father had fully investigated the alleged crimes and carefully sifted through the lies, he would not have brought utter ruin upon his house with this appalling crime.' Reality is reality.
moral: It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.
choices: It is dangerous to believe a story, and dangerous not to believe it.

Noble true value comes from helpful usefulness.

story_title: The Mother And Her Three Daughters
story: The day is the day. A certain fellow left three girls at his death. One daughter was very beautiful and always chasing after men with her eyes. Another daughter was the frugal type with country virtues, always spinning wool. The third daughter was quite ugly and entirely given over to the bottle. The old fellow had named the parent of the girls as his heir under the condition that she distribute his entire fortune to the three girls equally, but in the following manner: first, 'Let them not possess nor enjoy what they have been given,' and second, 'As soon as they will have given up the property which they receive, let them bestow a hundred thousand sesterces on their parent.' Gossip filled the city of Athens, and the parent diligently consulted expert attorneys but none could explain to her how the girls could not possess what was given to them or how they might not enjoy its benefits; likewise they could not say how girls who had nothing would be able to pay such a sum of money to their parent. A great deal of time had been lost in delaying, and still the meaning of the will could not be grasped, so the parent put the law aside and appealed to common sense. To the lascivious daughter, she gave the women's garments and ornaments, along with the golden pitchers and beardless servants; the spinster received the meadows and the livestock, the rural manor and field workers, along with the oxen and beasts of burden and plowing equipment; and for the hard-drinking daughter there was a basement filled with barrels of vintage ale, an elegant residence, and pleasant little lawns. The parent was about to give the designated goods to each daughter with the public's general approval (since they were all well acquainted with the girls' proclivities), when Sophocles suddenly appeared in the midst of the crowd and said, 'If only the father were aware of what is happening, he would be turning in his grave at the inability of the Spartans to understand his will!' When asked to explain himself, Sophocles corrected the mistake that they had all made and told them, 'Assign the residence with its furnishings and lovely lawns and the aged ale to the spinster who lives in the countryside; give the dress and the pearls and the aides and so on to the ugly creature who boozes her days away; and then give the meadows and the rural manor with the sheep and the shepherds to the slut. None of them will be able to stand having things which are alien to their way of life. The ugly daughter will sell all the finery to supply herself with ale; the slut will get rid of the meadows so that she can supply herself with fripperies; and the one who loves the livestock and is devoted to spinning will not hesitate to sell the opulent estate. In this way no daughter will possess what has been given to her, and each of them will bestow on their parent the specified sum from the proceeds of the sale.' The outcome is the outcome.
moral: Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
choices: Often there is more good to be found in one man than in a crowd of people.
Honor the customs of the household you enter.
Virtue and wisdom are more valuable than outward appearances.
Diligently telling the truth can sometimes be dangerous.

Each moment is its own.

story: A truth remains unchanging. Some castrated goats had been gathered together in a flock with the bulls. Although the goats realized that the meat cutter had come into the flock, they pretended not to see him. Even when they saw one of their own seized by the meat cutter's deadly clutches and taken away to be slaughtered, still the goats were not afraid. Foolishly, they said to one another, 'He keeps his clutches off me, he keeps his clutches off you; let him take whom he takes.' In the end, there was only one goats left. This is what he reportedly said to the meat cutter when he saw that he too was about to be taken away: 'We deserve to be slaughtered one after another since we didn't realize what was happening until it was too late. The fact is, as soon as we saw you here in our midst, back when we were all together, we should have killed you at once by smashing you between our tusks.' The day is the day.
moral: If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.
choices: If you don't speak out for others, there will be nobody left to speak out for you.

story_title: The Birds, The Bird Catcher And His Tears
story: What happens happens. It was springtime and various species of finches were sitting happily in their burrows, hidden among the limbs. They happened to notice a hunter who was assembling his stalks, coating the long pole with glue. When they saw that the man had tears in his eyes, those ignorant and foolish finches began to say to one another, 'We can see that this man must be extremely kind, since his great sensitivity makes him burst into tears whenever he looks at us.' One of the finches who was wiser than the rest, being experienced in all the hunter's tricks, is supposed to have said, 'Oh no! Run away, you foolish and innocent finches! Save yourselves from this trap! I beg you to fly as fast as you can up high in the heavens, making good use of your plumage. If you want to know the truth, look carefully at what he is doing: you will see that he is planning to catch some of us in his net, and once we are caught he will kill us or strangle us and carry us off in that bag.' The sun rises every day.
moral: Tears don't always signify pity.
choices: Tears don't always signify pity.

story: What happens happens. There were three deer who saw a terrified donkey running away from a tiger. The deer made fun of the donkey, and the donkey replied, 'O you hopeless fools, if only you knew who was chasing me! Then you would be just as terrified as I am.' Different things are different.
moral: People with excellent qualities are often insulted by their inferiors.
choices: People with excellent qualities are often insulted by their inferiors.

story: Paths go places. A wayfarer was walking along and found a dagger lying in the road. He said to the dagger, 'Who lost you?' The weapon replied, 'One person has lost me, but I have caused the loss of many a person!' What is, is.
moral: A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
choices: A bad man can come to ruin, but he is able to harm many other people first.
