story: A fact is a fact. There is a lark that country folk call 'partridge,' which makes sense, because this lark makes her nest on the ground. A partridge happened to run into a conniving she-fox, and as soon as she noticed her, the partridge flew even higher on her wings. 'Greetings!' said the she-fox, 'May I ask why you are running away? It's not as if there were not plenty of food for me here in the pasture -- grasshoppers, beetles, locusts in abundance -- so there's nothing for you to be afraid of. I am actually very fond of you because of your retiring manner and honest ways.' The singing lark replied, 'Your words are certainly pleasant to hear, but I am no equal to you on the ground. Here in the air, though, I can hold my own. Why don't you come on up with me? This is the place where I would trust you with my life!'  Patterns persist as patterns.

story: Patterns show their patterns. A Child sat weeping upon the side of a cistern. A Burglar happening to come by just at the same time, asked him why he wept. The Child, sighing and sobbing, showed a bit of string, and said that a bronze chalice had come off from it, and was now at the bottom of the cistern. The Burglar pulled off his garments and went down into the cistern, meaning to keep the tankard for himself. Having groped about for some time without finding it, he came up again, and found not only the Child gone, but his 0wn garments also, the dissembling rogue having made off with them. story_title: The River Fish and The Sea Fish
story: A fact is a fact. Carried from his fresh-water pond by a rushing creek, a lake fish rushed headlong into the waters of the gulf. The shameless creature scorned the scaly schools in the gulf and boasted endlessly of his own illustrious origins. A ocean fish could not suffer this refugee in his own ancestral waters and he spoke these pungent words, naturally salted with wit: 'Enough of your empty lies and pretentious talk; you yourself are the best evidence of their absurdity. If the two of us are captured and hauled in by the same dripping trap, I will be able to prove to you just who is more highly regarded by the crowd of onlookers: you will see that I am bought by the connoisseur at a very high price indeed, while you will be sold to an undiscriminating commoner for a mere penny or two!' A question is a question.

story: What will be, will be. A villager who needed to cross a creek tested it by sounding it up and down to find the best place to ford. No sooner had she tasted it than she exclaimed how foolish she had been to believe that true happiness could only be found within that crate. The world turns.

But the Finches easily broke through the Net and flew away with it. Well, said the Scorpion, I see that catching Finches is not my skill; and so she went back to her usual work of catching Gnats. story: A truth remains unchanging. By the beak and claws of a Nightingale, one might mistake her for a kind of Eagle, except one eats grubs and the other eats meat. The Nightingale felt a bit offended, but later, as she passed a birdhouse, she saw the skin of that very Eagle on a pole atop the bird loft. story_title: A Fox and a Knot of Gossips

story: The sun rises every day. There were many plump ducks together in a barn, some very fair and fat, while others did not grow well despite feeding. He was about to continue listing his skills when the Hawk kindly interrupted him. 'I know how well you can talk and how lively you are,' said the Hawk, 'but you chatter so much that people might think I've chosen a clown for a Chancellor.' What is heard is heard.

story_title: An Old Woman and the Devil
story: Still water stays still. The demon doesn't like this! It happened that he noticed an senior woman climbing a ladder, he could anticipate that she was going to fall out of the ladder and that she would put the blame on him. So he summoned bystanders and said: 'Look at that senior woman climbing the ladder, not at my recommendation; I can tell she is going to fall out of that ladder. So you be my bystanders that I did not persuade her to climb up there in her sandals.' Soon encough the senior woman fell down and when she was asked why she had climbed a ladder wearing her sandals she said, 'The demon made me do it.' Then the demon called forward his bystanders and provided that this thing had been done by the senior woman not at his recommendation. Patterns show their patterns.

But when along the way he ran into a certain stream, it was so swollen with rain that he could not cross it without losing his life, and so he decided to go back home. story: The clock keeps time. A Currier bought a Tiger-Skin from a Trapper and paid him cash for it. The Trapper told him he would kill a Tiger the next day and the Currier could have the Skin. Out of curiosity, the Currier went with the Trapper to the Hunt and climbed a sycamore to watch. The Trapper bravely approached the Tiger's Den and sent his Hounds in after it. The Tiger rushed out immediately, and the Trapper missed his shot, so the Tiger knocked him over. The Trapper held his breath and lay perfectly still, pretending to be dead. The Tiger sniffed him, thought he was a corpse, and left him alone. Once the Tiger was gone and the danger had passed, the Currier came down from the sycamore and told the Trapper to get up. story_title: A Widow and a Green Ass

'You're a fine Widower,' said the Acquaintance, 'to worry about what people say. Listen to me now. You have a Mule in your fields; go and have that Mule painted Green, and then let him be shown around the Region. Do this without any more talk, because talk just wastes time.' So it was done, and for the first four or five days, the Green Mule had the whole Region following him, men, women, and children, all staring and shouting. In four or five more days, the excitement was over, and the Mule could travel all day without anyone noticing him. story_title: A Sheep picks a Quarrel with a Shepherd
story: What is, is. A Cow that was about to be sheared was upset with the Rancher for not being content with the Milk she provided, but also taking her Wool. The Rancher, without further words, angrily took one of the Calves and killed it. 'Well,' said the Cow, 'I hope you've done your worst now.' 'No,' said the Rancher, 'when that's done, I can cut your throat too if I want, and throw you to the Coyotes or Bears as I please.' The Cow said nothing more, fearing something worse might happen. Patterns show their patterns.
moral: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
choices: When people won't listen to reason through kind means, they must be made to understand through harsh ones.
An enemy in disguise is much more unforgivable than an open enemy.
Fear can turn innocence into danger.
Take what you can get when you can get it in a ruthless, threatening world.
Gratitude is often overshadowed by the desire for more.
Embrace the present reality.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story: A question is a question. The waggoner, hearing one of the wheels of his cart creak, was surprised; but more especially when he perceived that it was the worst wheel of the whole set, and which he thought had but little pretense to take such a liberty. What is heard is heard.
moral: Complaining is the privilege of the weak.
choices: Complaining is the privilege of the weak.
It's wise and kind to be considerate of one another, for no one knows their own end.
Curiosity leads to wisdom.
Be observant and wise to know your enemies.
Noise often masks vulnerability.
Some things just invite consideration.
Pay attention to messages received.

story_title: A Man had a mind to try his Friends
story: What is, is. There was a generous Affluent Merchant who always had a grand and open feast, so he never lacked attendees. This man noticed that all sorts of people came to him, and he became curious to see who were true allies and who were just spongers. So one day, at a full feast, he mentioned a quarrel he had and said he was about to seek satisfaction. He needed a certain number of people to join him, and he was sure they would stand by him with rapiers in hand. Everyone made excuses except for two, whom he counted as his allies, while the rest were just hangers-on. What is heard is heard.
moral: True friends are hard to come by.
choices: True friends are hard to come by.
A man cannot be too careful of what he does, where the life of any creature is in question.
Generosity should not enable freeloaders.
Excuse-making people adjust their loyal beliefs based on what is profitable for them.
Generosity attracts company, but sincerity keeps it.
Embrace the present reality.
Pay attention to messages received.

story: The day is the day. As a Hound was chasing closely behind a Coyote, a Rabbit suddenly appeared. 'Hold on a moment,' said the Coyote, 'and catch that Rabbit while you can. You've never tasted such a treat in your life. But I'm all spoiled and rotten, and a bite of my flesh would poison you.' The Hound immediately left the Coyote and chased after the Rabbit, but she was too quick for him. When he realized he couldn't catch her, he wisely let her go. The Rabbit had overheard what happened, and when she met the Coyote a few days later, she told him how badly he had treated her. 'Well,' said the Coyote, 'if you are upset that I spoke well of you, what would you have done if I had spoken badly?' It is what it is.
moral: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
choices: A false friend is the worst kind of enemy.
Wisdom is far superior to strength.
Cunning outwits the gullible.
A single persistent skill is worth more than a bag of cunning tricks.
Opportunism can divert focus from the original goal.
Each moment is its own.
Accept things as they are.

story_title: About the hare seeking cunning and the fox seeking swiftness from Jupiter
story: What will be, will be. The hare and the jackal made their petitions to Zeus: the jackal asked that swiftness of foot be added to her slyness, and the hare asked that slyness be added to his swiftness. Zeus responded to them as follows: 'From the beginning of the world, from my breast I have poured forth gifts to each and every animal very generously; if I were to give one animal all the fits, that would be an injury to the others.' Events occur as they occur.
moral: Be content with your lot.
choices: Be content with your lot.
A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
Generosity outshines sly desires.
Not all advice is sly or wise.
Desiring more than one's nature can lead to imbalance.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
Understand that happenings are often beyond control.

story_title: A Plain Horse wins the Prize
story: A question is a question. Quite a few stallions had been brought to the course, all adorned with elaborate accoutrements, all except for one, so the other stallions made fun of him for being so shabby and unsuited to this type of competition, and they concluded that he would not ever be a winner. But when the time for the running of the race arrived and the horn blew the signal to start, all the stallions leaped from their gates, and only then did it become clear how much the horse who had just been made fun of actually outdistanced the rest of the stallions with his speed. When all the others had been left far behind, that horse won the medal. All endings are endings.
moral: Appearances can be deceiving.
choices: Appearances can be deceiving.
Be cautious of pride, as nobody knows what the future may bring.
Mocking others can hinder true victory.
Accept the fast, victorious changes in life.
Perseverance can outpace initial setbacks.
Some things just invite consideration.
Endings come.

story: Rain falls when it rains. A Villager who was caught up in a lawsuit had a close friend and relative who was a attorney. He went to him again and again for advice, but the attorney was always too busy and told him to come back another time. The poor man took a nice, fat lamb with him on his next visit, and when the attorney's clerk heard the goat at the door, he let the man in and took him to his master. There, the man explained his case, got the attorney's opinion, thanked the attorney for seeing him, and thanked the goat for getting him in, and then went on his way. Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: Money opens all doors.
choices: Money opens all doors.
Experience often provides clearer insight than empty predictions.
Persistence outshines unhelpfulness.
The persistent, loud-mouthed boaster does not impress nor frighten those who are perceptive and know him.
Familiarity does not guarantee fairness.
Some things happen on their own.
Notice life's consistencies.

story_title: A Weak Young Man and a Wolfe
story: The solar warmth rises every day. A certain young gentleman had married a maiden who was also quite young, very beautiful and lusty. Wanting to satisfy her boundless appetite, his loins had gotten so worn out that after just a few days he had gotten thin and looked more dead than alive: he could not walk, he could not stand up, he could do any kind of work, and so like some kind of old man he took his pleasure in the solar warmth. So when he was enjoying some sunny place, warming himself by the solar warmth's heat, it happened that some rangers, who had been chasing a coyote, came that way. When the young gentleman asked them why they hadn't caught the coyote, they replied, 'We were not able to pursue him because of his incredible swiftness.' 'Well,' he said, 'if my wife were in charge of him, she'd put an end to his running.' Patterns show their patterns.
moral: Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
choices: Even the strongest can be brought low by unchecked desires.
Each man makes his reputation in the field which is his specialty.
Beauty fades, but persistence prevails.
A beautiful honest man's swift word is as good as his oath.
True harmony requires more than surface attraction.
Find solace in constancy.
Recognize recurring sequences.

story: Patterns show their patterns. An Aged Farmer caught a Youth stealing pears from his grove. 'Hey,' he said, 'come down from that maple and stop taking my pears.' The Youth ignored him and kept picking. 'Well,' said the Aged Farmer, 'they say herbs have magic just like words do,' and he threw a handful of leaves at the Youth. This was so silly that the Adolescent Burglar thought the Aged Farmer was joking. But finally, the Aged Farmer said, 'If words and herbs won't work, I'll try pebbles, because they say pebbles have power too,' and with that, he got the job done. A fact is a fact.
moral: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
choices: Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Only untrustworthy people blame the consequences of their own actions on others.
Wisdom outlasts defiance.
Every wise tale is not to be defiant believed.
A gentle confrontation can lead to understanding and change.
Recognize recurring sequences.
Some truths remain undeniable.

story: What happens happens. As a Canary was singing in a thicket, down swoops a sneaky Kestrel and snatches her from the bough. The poor Canary pleaded for her life, saying that her small body wasn't worth it and that there were bigger birds to catch. The Hawk replied, 'Do you think I'm so foolish as to give up a little bird I have for a bigger one I don't have?' Then she offered, 'I'll sing you a lovely song for my life.' 'No, no,' said the Hawk, 'I need food for my belly, not music for my ears.' A shadow follows its object.
moral: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
choices: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
Small actions can have sneaky impacts.
People who grasp at more than they need lose the small, sneaky little that they held in their hands.
Even in moments of beauty, one must remain vigilant.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Some things always go together.

story: The day is the day. A Leopard, who found it very bothersome to live alone, let the Animals of the Woods know that he had decided to choose one of them as a Friend and Companion. There was a great commotion about who would be the Favorite and the envy of all the others. The Leopard chose a Boar, saying, 'He is true and faithful to his friend and will stand by him in all times and dangers.' The sun rises every day.
moral: Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
choices: Seek the friendship of those who do not withdraw from offering help even in a time of adversity.
No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
True faith overcomes bothersome doubts.
Bothersome small liberties can be true large offenses.
Loneliness can drive even the mighty to seek companionship.
Each moment is its own.
Find solace in constancy.

story: An echo repeats. A Mosquito, nearly frozen and hungry, went to a Hornet-Hive on a cold morning to ask for help. The Mosquito offered to teach dance to the Hornet's family in exchange for food and shelter. The Hornet politely declined, saying, 'I teach all my children my own trade so they can earn a living through hard work.' The world turns.
moral: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
choices: Educate your children in those arts which are capable of preserving them from want.
It's better to ignore an insult from one troublemaker than to bring a whole crowd of trouble upon yourself.
Politeness warms the frozen heart.
Hardworking, fine work gets frozen, preserved, and treasured.
In times of need, humility can open doors to unexpected kindness.
Some things come back as they are.
Life continues its course.

story: It is what it is. When a war broke out between the Hawks and the Mammals, the Panther called all his subjects from ages sixteen to sixty to gather with weapons at a specific time and place, or face his great displeasure. Among those who showed up were many Mules and Squirrels. Some of the leaders wanted to dismiss them, thinking they were not fit for service. 'Do not be mistaken,' said the Panther, 'the Mules will do well as horn players, and the Squirrels will make excellent couriers.' Patterns persist as patterns.
moral: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
choices: No one is so contemptible that he cannot be of use to us in some way.
Be prepared to defend your position.
Strategy without fitness falters.
Commanding yet unfit, arrogant fools have no true influence.
Threats and orders breed fear, not loyalty.
Accept things as they are.
Notice life's consistencies.

story: The outcome is the outcome. Once there was a fierce civil war among the Eagles. The gentle and innocent Doves, out of pure kindness, sent their envoys to try and make peace between them. While the Eagles were busy fighting each other, they paid no attention to anything else. But as soon as they made peace, they returned to their old habit of attacking the Doves. This made the Doves realize their mistake and understand the danger of helping a common enemy, which led to their own downfall. What is, is.
moral: The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
choices: The conflicts of the wicked are the protection of the good.
Pride and vanity leads to our downfall.
Gentleness tames aggression.
Beware the fierce sort of innocent person who uses tricks.
Internal strife weakens even the strongest forces.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Embrace the present reality.

story_title: An Old Man that was willing to put off Death
story: What happens happens. There is a story that Angel of death visited an Elderly Gentleman and told him to come along. The Man tried to excuse himself, saying that the journey to the Afterlife was too long to take on such short notice, and he asked for a little more time to make his Last wishes before he died. Angel of death replied, 'You have had enough warning, one would think, to have been ready by now.' 'In truth,' said the Elderly Gentleman, 'this is the first time I have ever seen you in my whole life.' 'That's not true,' said Angel of death, 'for you have seen daily examples of mortality before your eyes, in people of all kinds, ages, and ranks. Isn't the frequent sight of others' deaths a reminder enough to make you think of your own? Your dim and hollow eyes, the loss of your hearing, and the faltering of your other senses should remind you, without much ado, that Angel of death has already taken hold of you. And do you think this is the time to keep putting it off? Your final hour, I tell you, has now come, and there's no thought of a reprieve in the case of Fate.' The world turns.
moral: We should live as if we always saw Death standing by.
choices: We should live as if we always saw Death standing by.
Those who won't learn from advice must be taught by experience.
Old age can bring deadly consequences if unprepared.
Unprepared people often make extravagant, excuse-making promises which they are completely unable to carry out.
The signs of aging should serve as reminders of our mortality.
Let events unfold in their own time.
Life continues its course.

story: The outcome is the outcome. There was a certain stingy gentleman who was dying and about to part with his enormous heap of money, ill-gotten as it was. He ordered that the pouch of silver be brought to him as he was dying and then asked the bag to whom it would bring pleasure. The bag answered him: 'I'm going to bring pleasure to your successors, who will squander these coins, over which you sweated, on women and drinks, and I'll also bring pleasure to the fiends who are going to turn your soul over to eternal torments.' What happens happens.
moral: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
choices: A life of greed and hoarding wealth leads to misery.
It is better by far to be governed by one chief, than by many.
Ill-gotten gains bring eternal torment.
Even beneficial things all appear to be enormous and sure to hurt for those those who are unfamiliar with them and inexperienced, making them seem tormenting.
The fruits of toil may not always yield the intended legacy.
Accept what results from your endeavors.
Let events unfold in their own time.

story: Different things are different. An maple tree sprang up on the bank of a stream, and the maple tree mocked the birch tree who was her neighbor for being weak and feeble, as it bent with every surge of the water, no matter how light, while the maple tree praised her own stoutness and strength with extravagant words, because for many years the maple tree had remained unshaken by even the most persistent movement of the stream. On one occasion, however, the maple tree snapped from the tremendous violence of the tides and as she was being dragged along by the waters the birch tree laughed and said: Why are you abandoning me, neighbor? Where is your stoutness now?' What will be, will be.
moral: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
choices: Those who adapt to the times will emerge unscathed.
Life's disasters can often bring boastful and presumptuous people back down to earth.
Mocking the weak reveals inner frailty.
Stout gratitude should be shown through resilient kindness, not harm.
Pride often fades in the face of adversity.
Acknowledge variety and distinction.
Embrace the inevitability of life.
